description:
Boyfriend and I are from Seattle and Vancouver, down for the long holiday. First off, auntie who calls out the numbers bingo-style in canto and English, laici for her! We got sat fairly quickly as a party of two and literally IMMEDIATELY got served. Char siu bao was juicy not dry. Siu mai was very generous. Har gao wrapping was thin and not soggy or chewy, perfect. Fried noodles had the ideal texture and didn't taste drowned like msg. Gailan was good. Xiao Long Bao coulda used more broth and more flavor but it was meaty. Boyfriend loved the lobster noodles. So good. The egg tarts were delicious. So flaky! This was our only meal of the day. Literally so full and satisfied!!! Also, the decor was so kitschy I loved it! 

Restrooms need more attention but otherwise a wonderful experience! Mgoi!
author: Davie S.

description:
Family has been coming to this place for decades 30+ years
Always the meeting place for family and relatives. Grandma lived up the street for 40+ years.

The familiar faces have changed over the years. We were disgusted last weekend when we discovered flies in the soy sauce container.  We first thought it was just a fluke but then noticed flies in our food as well.  Little guys with wings everywhere. In the food and in the containers of soy and hot sauce. Don't even want to think of what is going on in the kitchen.

Bathrooms have always been wet, moldy and disgusting but just thought that's just China Town.  Seems like after so much success and time the restrooms would have been updated or at least the new immigrants would learn how to use the latrine. 

Waiter insisted we pay the bill but we wouldn't as flies were not ordered.
Too bad,  we are done with this place. Its had a good run the owners are wealthy but maybe time to turn over to new management. Oh yea the old lady who collects the money is unfriendly. Seen her for years and never received a hello or a thank you.  

Good little mom and pop dim sum place up the street price is a third of what New Asia charges
author: Yelp E.

description:
Food: It wasn't my favorite. The vegetables were overly greasy. The vegetarian noodles were my favorite thing here, but I still felt they were too oily. I kept asking for meatless dumplings, but the servers kept giving me conflicting answers on whether they had any. I ended up with pork dumplings, which was a nasty surprise. The sesame buns were great, though. 
Logistics: no parking, no bike rack. 
Service: the servers kept bringing out the same things that no one wanted. It was hard to get something more desirable. 
Atmosphere: it's a very traditional Chinese dim sum place, with a huge room, big tables and dim sum carts. I did find the bright Vegas lights unappealing.
author: Elizabeth G.

description: This restaurant is not the best but can improve.The carpet is sticky and moldy.The bathroom is small,wet,and moldy.the plates are dirty with mold.The air conditioning is filled with dust. A fly landed on my plate.
author: Crystal T.

description:
This restaurant is in the heart of SF Chinatown.  So, parking is always a challenge. 
It has been around for a long time. So, the decor really showed (old and worn out), and the restroom was dark & not well maintained :(

As for the food, they served Dim Sum on carts during lunch hours. Tea is charged whether you want it or not. Many of the traditional dim sum dishes can be found here. In general, they were quite good. Don't expect to find any new creative dim sum, or new variety (e.g., fusion dishes) here though. They do have some rice and noodle dishes besides dim sum for lunch.
We saw their lobster noodles on many tables that day. So, we decided to order. It was good. The lobster was quite fresh. The meat was still firmed and juicy sweet. The noodles absorbed the sauce of the lobster, ginger, and scallions. Great flavor. Definitely the highlight of our lunch.
author: Andrew L.

description: You know what, by Seattle standards this is a 4 star, by Guangzhou standards this is a 2 star.. first of all, it's hard to find good dimsum around anymore, good dimsum chefs come and go so often, they take trade secrets with them; which brings me to this review this place is so far, as of September 2018 pretty damn good; you do you order stir fry when they specialize in making dim sum. It's no din Tai Fung, or hakkasan, but for price, value, and most importantly, quality and good taste.. this place deserves a worthwhile detour. Just look at this place! It's packed with people ! And there's a wait.. that means it must be good.! Now I wanted to say I have NOT ordered Chinese food here , I did say the dim sum is good, I didn't say anything or try the Chinese dishes here!
author: Jay H.

description:
New Asia is located in San Francisco Chinatown on Pacific.

I've been here many times, but I hadn't posted a review of it on Yelp -- until today.  I happened to be in the city today, and I decided to make a walk there for brunch.  Luckily, the weather was beautiful -- high 60s and sunny.  And since it was a Tuesday, there was hardly any traffic.

As for the restaurant, it was relatively full of elderly folks getting breakfast and talking and youngsters on their lunch break.  I managed to get a table with ease.

This is one of the few Dim Sum places that still wheel out the food on steam trays during the weekdays, which is a plus.  Cantonese is spoken FYI, so it's helpful when ordering.

Food was delicious, and the service was good.  For a full service Dim Sum experience in SF Chinatown, this is the go-to place.
author: Kenneth L.

description:
Pretty unique dim sum restaurant - the first floor consists of tables surrounding a center stage where singers and bands play at night while the second floor is made up balcony-view tables. 

This is my first time coming here for dim sum around lunch time and while the service/staff are extremely friendly, the food doesn't taste that fresh. We got a variety of dishes and a majority of them made me feel like I was eating large amounts of oil and sodium, which is pretty expected of Chinese dim sum restaurants I suppose, but I've definitely had much better dim sum. 

The cleanliness of New Asia is also questionable, which I was already suspecting because it is located in Chinatown. But, I know I won't be coming back because I felt like I wasn't eating in a clean environment, hence why I'm giving this place 2 stars :/
author: Fiona G.

description:
New Asia can be a bit intimidating if you don't speak cantonese. Once you walk in, you'll see that it's a big banquet hall with some old school colorful lighting. Weekends can get pretty packed, but we were able to get seated pretty quickly (less than 5 minutes). Once seated, the dim sum carts all seem to rush over and offer various dim sum. It is a bit difficult to find the prices for each dish (I think there may be a menu of most of the items on some tables?), but I thought our overall bill was very reasonable. Expect to pay around $10-20/ person after tax and tip and they even take credit cards.

It's nice to get to eat inside and avoid some of the hustle and bustle on pacific in Chinatown, and don't be afraid to say no to the offerings as the plates can add up fast. 

My favorite dim sum here was the jin deui (sesame ball) and char siu (roast pork). Wasn't able to try any of the noddle or soup items, but from I did try, the dim sum can be hit or miss as some dishes may have just been made or sitting on the carts for a bit. They also served hot Jasmine tea with actual tea leaves, not bagged, which is always great.

I have to say it is pretty convenient to come in here, get served almost immediately, and gaze at all the appetizing food as it passes you by, and pick out food to share with your table mates.
author: Kenny L.

description:
New Asia is my gold standard for dim sum restaurants.  And, no, I'm not referring to the value of precious metals; I'm talking about the glitzy, gaudy decor - gold pillars, crystal chandeliers, multi-color LED lights - that seems to characterize these culinary relics of a bygone era.  That shiny veneer belies expensive, mediocre food.  Even so, it's a popular stop for locals and tourists alike.

At New Asia, you're likely paying more for experience - large banquet hall filled with people speaking Cantonese and middle-aged ladies pushing dim sum carts - than quality food.  Prices are high compared to places I've grown accustomed to in SGV and HK, and you should expect to pay $5+ per dish. If you order noodle dishes off the regular menu, you're looking at $14-20 per plate.  Food tends to be inconsistent: it can be perfectly cooked or disgustingly greasy depending on the day and time.  Stick to your favorites, and you'll likely make it out without a stomachache or headache.  Whatever you do, don't look in the kitchen!  On our most recent visit, we ordered five dishes ($40 incl. tax and tip).  The winning dish was undoubtedly the Peking duck - worth the high price for a nice mix of savory and sweet.

The downside to coming to a restaurant with dim sum carts is that they may run out of your chosen item before the dim sum ladies finish their rounds.  Exhibit B: my steamed char siu bao was the bun that got away.  Most staff speak at least some English, but don't be surprised if your request for water goes ignored by busboys.  You can pay with cash or card, but you'll need to flag down a waiter to get your bill totaled and processed.  Observation: the lady manning the register / cash box has been there for ages!

I'm not sure why my family has continued to visit New Asia for the past three decades even as quality has declined and value has decreased.  Old habits die hard I guess?
author: Greg T.

description:
I really want to like this place but I just can't.

This is one of the last big dim sum banquet restaurants left in Chinatown. It has been around for as long as I remember and I always loved looking inside when I walked by as a child. The interior has that 1970s-1980s disco feel and the stage in the middle makes for great parties, performances, gatherings,  and weddings. 

What killed it for me though was the food. The dim sum was just not up to par. As a chinese person that grew up eating at hole-in-the-wall places and don't exactly have the highest standards to begin with, even this was disappointing. The flavors and textures I've grown to love in dim sum was just lacking from the overall meal. They also kept pushing food that no body wants and was all getting cold. I don't want it to go out of business but I probably won't ever come here again unless I have some kinda event to attend there.
author: Lily F.

description:
The food was pretty good. A little on the oilier side, but very flavorful. If you decide to eat dim sum, try New Asia out. 
A little expensive, and a little noisy, but it's all worth it!
author: Anthony H.

description:
Wasn't the best dim sum I've had. I had a friend who hasn't been to a dim sum where they pushed the carts around so that's how we ended up here. With a party of 4 we got seated right away. As the carts came around we got:

Shumai - These were okay, pretty average
Chicken feet - Not great, it was super gamy and was orange! 
Fried Taro balls - Taste like any other crispy ball of oil
Shrimp rice cake with soy sauce - This was is always good no matter where I go
Pork soup dumplings - I've had better, these weren't filled with a lot of juice

One thing I liked was that when they gave us chrysanthemum tea. Other dim sums I've been to usually give me jasmine as a default. I think my experience here was a little less than below average. If I had a choice I probably would have just gone to the to-go dim sum places rather then this sit down restaurant. There was a bunch of other things I wanted to try when the carts came around like the tripe and intestine soup but my banana friends aren't really into those kind of things so maybe another time, if there is another time.
author: Andrew T.

description: Definitely a lively dim sum restaurant because it's in the heart of Chinatown San Francisco. I've gone on the weekend and weekday and still it's a bustling place. There are tons are workers who roll their carts around for dim sum. They have a good variety of dim sums as well. When I went they have some new stuff like the duck in a white bun. Food is quite good , not the most clean place. It's just so much happening. It's busy. The seating of tables are all round and are very close to other people's table. Often times just inches away.
author: Sally L.

description:
This is the last of the large wedding banquet-sized Cantonese restaurants in San Francisco Chinatown.  I used to know it as Asia Garden, then New Asia Garden, now New Asia.  Same two-story monolith that has easily served more than 10 million people in its lifetime (at least 30 years x 52 weeks x 7 days a week x 1,000 people a day).  Wow - a SF institution that is still going strong... observed at least from my Dim Sum visit on a Tuesday.  

The Dim Sum quality varies from plate to plate, some greasy, some pristine, some that have been on a cart too long, and others just right out of the kitchen.  Ladies push carts around and hawk plates of:
- Har Guow (hope you're not allergic to Shrimp), 
- Siu Mai, Pai Guet (Tasty Steamed Black Bean Garlic Pork Riblets),
- Char Siu Bau (Surprisingly good Baked Pork Bun), 
- Don Tot (I like Portuguese Egg Tarts more than these Egg Tarts), 
- Siu Long Bau (Stick to a Mandarin Restaurant to get these), 
- Fong Jow (Chicken Feet falls apart in your mouth like it should!),

While others carry around bigger and more expensive dishes of:
- Long Ha Geen Mein (Lobster Noodle was $20 and luke warm),
- Chow Mein,
- Sill Gee Yook (Roast Pork Belly),
- Ho Yo Gai Lan (Need Chinese Broccoli with Oyster Sauce to clear the palette)
  
The dishes are tasty, a bit expensive compared to other smaller Dim Sum joints in Chinatown.  They also charge for tea.  But hey, this place is like China or Hong Kong - lots and lots of middle to older age Chinese diners gossiping, meeting friends, reading the paper, sipping tea - thus gotta charge for tea as they're taking up a spot.  Also not one non-Chinese face in the crowd and I looked hard!

Do not expect cleanliness or cutting-edge dishes (i.e. Yank Sing),  Do expect to be out of your comfort zone if you're young or non-Chinese and have not been to Asia.
author: Scott L.

description:
I used to come here as a kid for the huge wedding banquets, but I'd never had the dim sum here. So I decided to try the dim sum for my lunch. The system is pretty good for waiting for a table. You just walk up to the host, and they give you a number. Once your number is called, an attendant walks you to your table. Luckily you don't have to wait too long, since this place is huge.

The dim sum is pretty good! They still come around with carts here, and if you don't see what you want, you can ask any worker for it, and they'll flag down the right cart for you. I like the roast pork, sticky rice, and the pork buns. Unfortunately I have a shellfish allergy, so I can't eat the traditional dim sum dishes because nearly all of them have shrimp. :(
author: Rachel H.

description: First time here was because I attended the Miss Vietnam SF Pageant 2017-2018 last year on November 11th. Generally, I would say that the food here is good. Some of the things I liked about the restaurant is that it is very big and spacious. There is an upstairs too. It's great for parties and events. I ate the fried rice, vegetable dish with black mushrooms, salmon with some sort of cream sauce, Chinese roasted chicken and some other entrees. Only issue is that I think some parts of the restaurant could of been renovated as it was a bit rusty.
author: Diana T.

description: Went here with my dad, husband, and baby boy. They had the coolest wooden high chair for him. Was here around 1:30 on a Friday was immediately seated. We ordered the usual rice rolls, shrimp dumpling, siu mai, and chicken feet. They were all good but I wanted to try something different or something new asia would be known for so I asked the waitress. She said roast duck and lobster lo mein. After some back and forth from my old school dad about how good could your roast duck be he obliged and let me order it. Both items were delicious! The roast duck was lean with a crispy skin...drooling! And the lobster lo mein was a huge portion with lots of vegetables. Try these non traditional items at new asia! You won't be disappointed!
author: Wendy L.

description:
Upon walking in, I felt at home. The large first floor filled with round tables reminded me of dim sum in Hong Kong. Waiters pushed trolleys around shouting out dishes in Cantonese. It's definitely helpful to understand Cantonese. 

We got the shrimp dumpling (ha Gao) and siu mai. Those pieces definitely stood out. I went with my mom so we stuck mostly with the core dim sum dishes and they did not disappoint. I also liked the cha siu bao (pork bun). 

They also are quick with service to the point where we had to tell the waiters that we couldn't eat any more. A local also recommended it to us.
author: Nathan C.

description: My family has been coming to this restaurant for well over 3 decades (before I was born) as a yearly tradition every Saturday after thanksgiving. You cannot beat the flavor and quality of the dim sum here. Awesome atmosphere and tons of carts always circling and coming by. Hint: if you're unfamiliar with dim sum yes its greasy but delicious. And in this restaurant dont hesitate to get vocal and wave a cart over if you see something you like, it's all about the experience!
author: Megan L.

description:
I attended a special event at this restaurant last week as it was packed upstairs as well as downstairs.
Parking is available at the Portsmouth Square Parking Garage. Walking distance to the restaurant is about 5 or 6 blocks to Pacific St.
Restaurant is located smack in the middle of Chinatown.
The food was decent and I have no complaints about that at all after all it was a sponsored event.
Restaurant itself is nice and fairly large enough to hold a main event.
Good Times.
author: jack d.

description:
Food wasn't terrible for once at the Family Association Dinner...the ceremony was, but that's not the restaurant's fault. By the time the first plate arrived (2 loooong hours after the start of the ceremony), the whole restaurant was literally famished...I've never heard a Chinese restaurant be quite so quiet - haha.

I digress, back to the food.

Appetizer - an assortment dish of steamed chicken, peking duck, bbq pork, jellyfish, and seaweed salad. It was a nice upgrade from the regular cold sliced meats, jellyfish, and random maraschino cherries.

Soup - water/cornstarch/white pepper thickened "broth" but was generously filled with crab claw meat, bay scallops, and fish maw. We pretty much just scooped out the contents.

Fried Fish Balls - juicy with a nice crunch. They were also pretty large, about the size of a child's fist. If you are not a fan of preserved fruit peels though, it does have a bit of that flavor which can be a little offputting. 

Fried Shrimp - probably my favorite dish of the night. The prawns were large and fully deveined (unheared of in a Chinese restaurant) then tossed in a delicious sesame/ginger/soy reduction.

Black Pepper Lamb Chops - the lamb was very fresh and tender. Didn't have much of a gamey taste (my table thought it was beef until I said otherwise). The steamed vegetables still had a good crunch to them which was impressive given the volume they had to cook.

Crispy Skin Chicken - chicken was done perfectly. Super juicy on the inside and a nice thin crispy skin on the outside. My grandmother did complain about the size (given the cost of the banquet dinner).

Goose Feet and Sea Cucumber over Napa - probably one of the least impressive dishes of the night. The goose feet weren't fried first so it had a really weird smooth texture that couldn't even hold onto the sauce. The sea cucumber was also overdone - mushy to the point of no return. The napa was decent, but you could tell they didn't really bother to pick out leaves that were aged (many pieces were covered in black dots or were bitter).

Sea Bass - usually the best dish every time this event rolls around, but it was overcooked this time. Luckily it's steamed so it doesn't dry out, but it's also not great when it's borderline mushy/soggy. 

Almond Cookies/Lotus Mochi with Coconut Flakes - the mochi was uneven. Some pieces were all pounded rice while others were way too heavy on lotus paste. But the almond cookies were good and chewy.

Given they had to accommodate over 75 tables with the same set meal, the quality was really impressive this time. That said, would I choose to come to New Asia more regularly now? Probably not. It's still not worth the parking ordeal or ambiance (chairs are old, clean dishware is often delivered greasy, restaurant has a tendency to be overly loud/echo-y, bathrooms not very clean)
author: Elaine Y.

description: Delicious dim sum. We got a ton of food, and everything was great (especially the chicken feet!). The atmosphere was very nice, too -- big space with lots of seating and pretty lights. Would highly recommend.
author: Kate J.

description:
My boyfriend and I were planning to eat at another restaurant, but we happened to find this place along the way. When we first sat down, the waitresses started to speak in Mandarin to us. Luckily, my boyfriend knew Mandarin. 

When we asked if the tea was free, they said that there is a charge for just sitting at the table and so we might as well get tea. We could choose several types of tea. I do not remember what the options were.

The table was not too clean. I noticed little black smudges on my tea cup and chopsticks.

My boyfriend said that it was interesting how  one waitress addressed us as "handsome young man" and "beautiful lady" in Mandarin.

I ended up ordering the Steamed Bean Curd with Oyster Sauce ($4.40) and Steamed Sticky Rice Wrapped in Lotus Leaf ($5.20). My boyfriend got the Steamed Spare Ribs in Black Bean Sauce ($4.40). 

The waitresses told me that the bean curd and sticky rice dish both had only chicken in it. For meat, I typically just stick with eating chicken. When I cut the sticky rice dish in half, I saw Chinese pork sausages in it. The bean curd also had pork along with a mixture of other ingredients inside. I feel like the waitresses had no clue what is in some of the dishes they were serving. This place is not great if you have dietary restrictions or if you are vegetarian. 

It took a long time to flag down the waitresses. When we were about to pay, one of them asked if we could pay with cash instead of credit card. She then said that we could give her a smaller tip if we pay by cash. It was really confusing. Our total meal added to $17.90 and at first we gave her a 20 dollar bill. She then quickly said we didn't have to pay her anymore and told us we could go and not to worry about it even though we ended up undertipping. 

$17.90 does seem like a lot for three small dishes and tea/"sitting down" fee. We didn't get a receipt, but I am assuming taxes helped bring the amount to $17.90.
author: Kristina M.

description: SO GOOD! I'd never had dim sum before going to New Asia but now I'm a huge fan. It was a wonderful and overwhelming experience. Some of the best dishes I tried: shumai (shrimp and pork dumplings), bok choy, some sort of fluffy steamed bun with barbecue-like beef in the middle (I think they're called char siu bao, maybe?), and turnip cakes. Will definitely come back here when I'm in the area!
author: Lena G.

description: One of the oldest dimsum place in Chinatown, we had been going there since I was a kid! We met friends and family there today at noon, we wait less than 10 minutes for the table, servers came by right the way and served us tea, carts rolled in with all type of dimsum and noodles, all the foods were delicious and we had a great time!!
author: Winnie T.

description:
No ridiculous long lines!!!
Food is excellent. All things authentic chinese Dim Sum. 
Service was friendly. 
HUGE RESTAURANT. 
Will come again whenever we can!
author: C C.

description: Don't go at 1:00 pm.  Most of their dim sum are gone.  No steam buns.  The stomach was good, $8.00.  Lau san bao got salted egg dripping out.  The tea is real, not tea bag. The chicken feet melt in your mouth, you just spit the bones out. Stomach lining is too salty.  The servers were very nice and helpful without attitude.  The favorite is still durian puff.  Greasy but good.  Lobster mein looked a little skimpy. We didn't get soft tofu.  Price is hidden in how much each dish cost.  I still like the push cart dim sum. Look before getting.
author: Helen L.

description: WORST CHINESE EVER. Sauces were very bland, consistency of the lemon chicken was not unlike that of a gummy bear. Everything in the restraint was slightly sticky: menus, tables, floors. Not coming here again any time soon.
author: Nick A.

description:
I grew up eating New Asia and I miss it everyday. This place is located just across from my grandmas house and when I used to live with her, it was the spot every Sunday...

I can't say that Chinatown is known for their cleanliness or service but what I could say is that the food down here is as authentic as it gets in the Bay Area. Dim Sum at New Asia is a must if you're visiting from out of town. There are a few other dim sum spots too that are great but this one just hits close to home. 

It's been 10+ years since I've eaten here and I feel like things haven't changed. The food was still bomb, the service was meh and it's not Chinatown without a dirty placemat right? 

I came here with my family for Saturday dim sum and since they open up at 9:30am and dim sum on Saturdays is crazy we decided to get here early. Of course we were seated right away considering we got here right when they opened. The cooks actually didn't even get in until 10am so some
Of the items on the menu weren't available yet. 

Overall, dim sum is good quality and service is pretty quick but I will say that one of the cart ladies ran into my brothers chair and all the dim sum fell on the floor...
author: Shelly W.

description: Food is pretty good. Service is ok. the chicken was very juicy and tender but lobster noodles's noodles was very soggy.  The combination plater was very tasty.
author: John Y.

description: Fucking ripped of Chinese place, as they always do. Half of duck and a rice for $19. Really? It freaky China town!
author: Xia V.

description:
I've actually been here many times before for dinner banquets, and I recently had to come back for another one. Although the service was decent and the waiters were good about getting me my hot water, the 1 star is really for the cleanliness and food safety. You can check for the specific violations this restaurant has had by clicking on the "Health Inspection" rating on the right side of its Yelp page.

-Waiters are quick to clear the table to make room for other dishes, but they kind of just charge in suddenly without a warning, so lean to the side quickly before anything drips on you
-Food was decent and flavorful, but sometimes oversauced and greasy, typical of many Chinese dishes though
-I saw platters of uncovered cold-cut meats stored out in the open with flies from the outside gaining access to these plates
-Restrooms (located on 2nd floor) are functional, but have poor ventilation
-Floors throughout the restaurant are sticky and actually soggy in some areas
-Utensils and tableware are sticky and my water cup had something stuck to the bottom of it
-Duck feet, sea cucumber, and lettuce dish was full of little worms, probably from the lettuce (Couldn't take a picture though because my phone camera wasn't able to focus in the dim lighting)

I can understand that this restaurant has been around for a really long time and can be difficult to revamp such a huge place, but the employees there should at least be refreshed on their food safety standards. I'm glad to see that they are correcting their violations and are improving on their health inspection rating though!
author: Winnie Y.

description: Turnip cake is very good and the staff are friendlier than the last time we were here
author: Jo E.

description: I would say this place is huge inside. Foods are ok, services are fast tho. But but the restroom is dirty, way too dirty. I saw a guy work in the kitchen came out from the restroom without cleaning his hands... The HELL" I told my wife ..ohhh hell no, no more here honey, I don't want look for restroom after eating for every hours and you know it's hard to find parking and restroom in San Franscico... you got my point. Yuk
author: Johnny T.

description: Was here for another banquet dinner. The servers/waiters are extremy rude and messy with no care for anything. The food was ok.
author: Conner B.

description:
This is a 4.75 star dim sum review but as I told my GF, even though this is a restaurant and the dim sum is authentic and delicious, it will be rough"

Truly accurate experience! Lol dim sum quality outstanding but service is traditional Chinese so definitely not for the feint of heart!
author: P C.

description:
Average dim sum. LA has way better. 

Good: 
- crispy crab ball
- egg tart

Ok: siu mai, har gao, shanghai xiao long bao, shrimp rice roll

Forget it: spring roll, baked char siew bao, char siew shou
author: Samuel A.

description: From the couple of dim sun places we tried going on a Sunday morning this was the only one with no wait lines. The space inside is huge and you have to be ready to immediately start ordering. Most of the waitresses don't speak English but when we had trouble ordering we asked the girl at the cashier's desk to help us and she was so nice to let us know which dish was what. Came out stuffed and happy.
author: Jo S.

description:
Overall ratings:

- Food 7.5/10
- Customer service 6/10
- Cleaniess 5.5/10
- Cost 6/10 

The food was okay. It wasn't the greatest and it wasn't the worst. It could be better though with more selections and without the need of convincing a person to get a dish of food that they don't want. The customer service was kind of bad because they have a hard time hearing us speak when the noise level is too high. The cleaniess of the restaurant is not satisfactory to me. The stairways are wet and you can easily slip and fall. Oh by the way, the floors are kind of sticky also. 
The cost of the food was a D letter grade. This restaurant is just like any other restaurants. The food taste the same and the quality of it is nothing special in my opinion so I believe that the price of the food is just not worth the double price vs the other restaurants where you can get it for cheaper.
author: Jonathan Z.

description: How the hell does clean their restrooms? It's a hazard to have oily floors especially in the bathroom. Do they cook in the restroom too!
author: Jason H.

description: My mom ordered a take out chow mein with some shrimps for my dinner yesterday. I have a very bad stomachache, throw up, and diarrhea for about 15 minutes. For right now, the second day, I still have a stomachache and want to throw up. I know this restaurant's health score was 64 out of 100 for the last year. I hate this restaurant.
author: Min S.

description:
I wanted to give this place a chance when I was in Chinatown despite the ratings since usually low ratings at Chinese restaurants are due to service. But the food was DISAPPOINTING!  

Decor/ Atmosphere:
Very nice, clean, spacious, and bright compared to other restaurants in Chinatown. There wasn't much of a wait because we came around closing time. 

Service: 
Attentive
Made mistakes with the tab and charged an extra XL har gow 
Fairly quick with bringing out dishes

Food: 
Under-seasoned food
Served a RAW pork Siu Mai

After biting into a siu mai that turns out to be raw inside! About 1/3 of it was RAW! I immediately turned to my dad and asked him if it was and he said yes. When I showed it to the waiter he immediately took the plates away and said it was straight up raw no doubt and then cancelled it on the tab and apologized. Thankfully, we didn't eat the whole thing or else.. Then we just kept eating the rest of the other dishes. The food was just okay some was under-seasoned. I would have been okay with coming again but because I got served something that was raw, I was very displeased. It could have been that we came around closing time but still does not justify this. I will only come here again if I really have to and prob skip the dim sum and just get noodles.
author: Jeanette Q.

description:
Extremely Horrible restaurant!!!

 Last Friday, I went here with my friend and her daughter. And it will definitely be my last. This was probably one of the worst, if not the worst experience I've had at a restaurant. The food might be barely acceptable, but the service and attitude of the staff was horrid. Usually, when a customer finds an insect in there food or beverage the staff should be cordial and respectful as possible, while they remedy the situation. But instead of this approach, the manager was abrasive and blunt and kept on asking in Chinese "Well what do you want to do about it?", putting aside the fact that after I discovered the cockroach in my tea and had already vomited twice, his tone disgusted me enough to want to vomit a third time. His attitude made it seem like the patron was wrong for finding the cockroach! And that I should have just swallowed it and accepted the gift. In the end they very reluctantly offered to cover the expenses of the meal, but my friend and I turned them down and  paid anyways because my friend and I couldn't stomach their generosity. If possible I'd give this place a negative score, but sadly the system won't let me.
author: Kay J.

description:
I was brought to New Asia by family friends (who are locals) so I didn't have a chance to check this place on yelp before arriving. 

We had shumai, shrimp rice rolls, portuguese egg tarts, soup dumplings, chicken feet, and rice rolls with spare ribs. Everything tasted very fresh and very good. I don't understand why there are so many negative reviews of this restaurant.
author: Margery W.

description:
This place goes down hill in a steep slope as the years go by. I only come here when I visit my grandparents in Chinatown and because it is the most spacious restaurant in the area for easy access for my grandparents and avoiding long wait times.

The food is just ok. The traditional ha gow and sui mais are alright. They serve all the usual dimsums but you won't find any specialty dimsums. They even have lobster noodle in their dimsum carts to lure you in eating their expensive dishes.

My most recent visit was quite an experience. My cup looked clean but tasted salty when I tried to drink my tea so I had to ask the waiter for a new one. The dimsum ladies pushing the carts were having an argument in front of our table. It was 2 vs 1. One of them wanted us to be in her team and said to me:  "Am i right for arguing with her?" in Chinese and I ignored her. The best dish we had was the Cha Siew Chow Mein that my gradnpa had requested.
author: Allie Y.

description: Incredible dim sum. It's a solid choice to visit regularly or bring family and friends visiting. Go early in the day for the best selections.
author: Amy H.

description:
Chopsticks - sticky.
Sui mai - lukewarm. 
Hostess - ear rape.
dim sum - lackluster.

This is the old style, push carts only, without the pencil and menu order.

Jammed packed with OGs
author: Hui L.

description: Just had lunch and it was delicious. We were walking around Chinatown and came across this restaurant. You choose from carts that are being pushed around by staff. A must try.
author: Tara M.

description: This is our go to dim sum place in town (we come here almost every weekend). As dim sum fanatics, we've tried almost all places in SF that serve dim sum. And this is it! This is the place to be! Don't turn away from the gaudy decor of the venue, the food is magnificent. Our favorites: chicken feet, pork short ribs, durian pastry, shrimp dumplings with chive, congee, BBQ pork bun, roasted duck, and egg tarts.
author: Lu L.

description: Went for my first dim sum lunch but was kinda disappointed. The food was just not my taste i guess. I tasted some sesame jelly roll, a deep fried taroball, and a series of dumplings and shumai that i didnt really enjoy due to their greasiness and odd flavors/textures and this review is coming from a korean girl, which is saying a lot
author: Song K.

description:
I've come here twice, and I usually don't stop at chinatown to eat, however this place is pretty decent.  I wouldn't say it's close to some of the great dim sum spots that we have in sf however it's not bad.

We had the Shanghai style dumplings and they were just ok, we also had the spare ribs, shrimp crepe, lao ba ko,the fried tofu with veggie filling and the lao Sao bao.  The lao Sao bao was runny and the best thing I had here, everything else was just not bad.

If I'm in chinatown again and in dying need of dim sum I'd come back, however nothing compares to some of the dim sum spots we have in the Richmond district.  All in all its not bad, especially if you're just visiting and don't want to leave downtown to go to some of the outer districts in sf.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
Zero Stars

A legacy location.  Built by the legendary Robert Yick, this was once the infamous Asia Garden.  Two levels of banquet space.  Premier cuisine for the most discriminating palate.  Truly, a palace for a royal feast.  Once designed to compete for Wedding Banquets where no cost was spared.  Chinatown was once the hub of the Chinese community banquet business, where extended family and friends number into the hundreds.  

Dim sum carts are still being used.  Food kept hot on carts equipped with burners, steamers, and miniature griddles to fry & crisp dishes at tableside.  You don't have to speak the language, or even know what you're getting.  If it looks good, accept it.  One could easily communicate with motions and gestures.  

Dim sum cart service is becoming a thing of the past.  Dim sum carts require the kitchen to make food before it's even ordered.  Then the food is presented, in hopes that it will sell.  The restaurant has to have good food, in order to keep a steady stream of customers coming in, to consume the product, and keep everything fresh.  You also need space for these carts to turn and move.  By eliminating the carts, you get more seating in your dining room, food is made to order and waste is minimized.    

Today, it's faded grandeur.  Badly in need of everything.

The food is bad.  Everywhere you look in Chinatown, there are take-out dim sum joints for the same steamed dumplings and buns.  All are lackluster at best.  In order to get good dim sum, you have to leave Chinatown.  Sad.  

Instead of stepping up their game, and serving food that is fresh, they ave stooped to cost cutting measures in order to compete with the discount market.  Yank Sing has nothing to worry about.

Apparently, even the banquet business has taken a downturn.  To make up for the loss, evenings are now a ballroom dance session for seniors.  

Did I mention how bad the food was? Xiao Long Bao in a tin foil cup was obviously frozen from a supplier; wrapper was hardened, appearance was deflated, wrappers stuck to tin foil, and stuffing was greasy and devoid of broth and flavor.  Har gow wrappers were mushy, stuck to each other, stuck to wax paper liner in basket, fell apart as I tried to pick it up with chopsticks, and the stuffing had fishy odor of bad seafood.  Siu mai had the look, texture, and taste of something from a freezer bag.  

The service is even worse than the food.  Dim sum cart pushers wander by, gazing into space, mumbling, and completely ignore the guest seated at the tables.  You have to waive, yell, and flag them down to get one to stop to serve you.  Sesame rolls were stacked sideways on a cart to minimize space, with plates wrapped in cling plastic, and the server simply put the plate on our table and walked off without removing the plastic film.  What kind of restaurant serves food in Saran Wrap?  Nobody checks on the tables.  Dirty dishes are not bussed, tea is not refilled, water is not offered, and they will not give you extra napkins or clean plates.  

The floor in the entire restaurant is covered in a film of grease.  I'm wearing rubber soled shoes, and slipping.  Is it better to have a greasy floor, as opposed to a sticky floor?  Why not clean the floors?  Especially the stairs that you have to go up & down to get to the 2nd floor bathrooms.  The bathrooms stink.  As I was using the urinal, a woman came in with a household broom, which she used to push around a was of dirty paper towel sheets, and actually hit my foot with it as I was peeing.  Where did she get those from?  Since paper towels are not offered in the bathroom for the customers.  

Never mind that if you don't speak Chinese here, you are out of luck.  Knowing the local dialect doesn't help.  Forget that the wallpaper is peeling, and a quick look into the prep area and kitchen as you're going to the bathroom reveals that cleanliness, health, and food safety are not a priority.  So what, if nobody cares about the customers because their personal conversations trump the scope of their job duties?  

Ask for the check.  The person bringing to you will tell you that you have to tip.  Different person picks up the check, looks at the check, looks at the currency, then tells you that you have to tip.  Another person brings your change, and reiterates that they want you to tip.

What the F*ck is that?  I have never been anywhere that the workers tell you to tip.  What the Fuc* am I tipping for?  The bad service?  No.  There was no service.  Am I tipping because they are rude enough to demand a tip?  F*ck You!  Go up to the front. The old lady at the cashier station who collects all the money, suddenly doesn't speak English.

A tip is optional.  Tipping is for good service.  I tip very generously where the service is good.  Funny, in a good establishment, the servers never have to tell anyone to tip.  Tipping is not required by law.  

Did I mention that Yank Sing has nothing to worry about here?
author: Barry M.

description:
I went here at 2.30 p.m. and it's closing in 30 mins. However, I still got in and ate.
My friend and I were so hungry! We ordered ha kao, siu may, shrimp rice noodle, deep fried shrimp balls, and something like wonton I forgot!
We didnt get full but all of them are great!
author: Candice L.

description:
General rule of thumb: long line of people at a restaurant means they have good food...in this case, it's a fact. I'm Chinese so I think I know a thing or two about dimsum and Chinese cuisine.

New Asia has awesome dimsum! This is my favorite dimsum restaurant in San Francisco. The best part of the dining experience is that they have push cart dimsum service (side note: a lot of places in SF doesn't have push cart service). Not only do they have dimsum from their push carts, you can order specialty dishes like fried noodles, fried rice, roast duck, etc. from any of the servers. The staff here speaks Chinese so you can order in Chinese which is great but for those who don't speak Chinese, they speak English as well. Everyone here is quick and operate as a very efficient team. 

When you first enter the restaurant, you'll notice that they have two floors and that all the tables are full. Immediately to your side is a large waiting area with chairs. Make sure to get a number before waiting for a table! Once you have it, you'll be sitting among others anxiously waiting to be called. Great time to think about all the wonderful dishes you're about to devour. If you look to the side, you'll notice they have roast duck, char siu and other meats hanging. Behind that is a butcher working hard to fill the specialty meat orders. Try their roast duck if you have a chance, it's very good. 

This is a great spot for breakfast, brunch, lunch or dinner. I enjoy coming here and actually crave their dimsum every time I'm in Chinatown SF. You will need to find street parking or you can garage park around the area. Make sure to read all the street signs before parking! Some signs are very confusing. Ask if you are uncertain! Better safe than sorry. If you go up Pacific, you can park in a garage on the right just before the restaurant. Overall, this is the spot to check out if you want Chinese food in Chinatown SF!
author: Daniel C.

description: Went to CREA event and have attended several others. Very good food service fast and food served hot. Recommend
author: Steven M.

description: Terrible experience here. Took over half an hour for them to serve me, food was subpar, and the workers forced me to tip more than I already tipped. I feel so scammed, PLEASE DO NOT COME HERE!
author: Latrell J.

description:
Ok in a pinch but you could find better in Chinatown.

Food was mediocre and often cold. The service was also slow at times and we had to ask for the status of a menu order multiple times.

It is a fun experience if you're visiting from out of town and want the dim sum cart experience but you can find better if you're willing to venture a bit farther.
author: Kelly W.

description:
DONT COME HERE! For your health, be aware!!! Unless you want to get sick.

We were here at the restaurant for wedding. Food was bad quality, tasteless. Service was horrible. Tried to tell them we found a cockroach looking bug in our food, the servers ignored us entirely. I broke out in rash the next day because the seafood wasn't fresh. NOT COMING HERE EVER AGAIN.
author: Ann H.

description: I went here a long time ago when I was 13 and I loved it, decided to go here again when I have limited time in SF. Worst decision. my friend and I were only obvious non-asians there and we got the worst service. Food was always cold including the hot dishes. 40 minutes after our table was cleared did we actually get our check even though we kept asking. Finally we just decided to get up and go to the host lady in front, I left a tip on the table even though it was not deserved. And the rudest woman yelled at me for leaving it at the table. Then she rounded up our total bill just because? THE FOOD HERE IS NOT WORTH THE RUDENESS OF THESE PEOPLE
author: Alexandria T.

description:
One star for being seated immediately and one star for fresh egg tarts... other than that, get me out of here!

First of all, if I had seen the poor health score on Yelp, I wouldn't have dared step foot in New Asia. My boyfriend was convinced that when he came here years ago, it would be just as good as he remembered. However, it looks run down and dirty inside with uneven floors and tables crammed closely together. 

We only ordered a pork dish, lobster noodles, and egg tarts before I just really wanted to leave lol! The pork was super greasy and not very flavorful, the lobster didn't taste fresh, and the egg tarts were standard. 

Unfortunately, I won't be coming back unless the health score changes.
author: Melanie W.

description: Found 2 big insects in our food. Food was satisfactory. Most were cold. Not really a good place to go during lunch time
author: Envy K.

description:
It's rare that I feel this strongly about a dim sum restaurant, but man do I love New Asia. My parents (the OG dim sum eaters) told me to give this place a try, and wow I wasn't disappointed. It has taken me a lot longer than it should to get into New Asia though -- I've tried on countless random nights to eat there, only to be detained by the fact that the entire restaurant was booked out, or I came too late, etc. But the SO and I finally made it in around 1pm this past Saturday.

First thing you notice -- this restaurant is HUGE relative to most places in Chinatown. It might be as large as some of the major establishments, but it's laid out almost as a giant rectangle, so the largeness of the place is super evident. Anyways, we were seated pretty much instantly, which I love because a) I hate waiting in dim sum lines and b) it is literally impossible to get good dim sum in this city during prime lunch time without a line. So that was one major surprise for me.

Second thing, New Asia does dim sum the in my opinion, right way -- with the carts! A lot of Chinatown dim sum eateries also make you do the checking off a menu thing (presumably for space restrictions), but it's just so much more satisfying to see your food roll by rather than just checking it off a piece of paper and not realizing what you want until you see it. Once you get seated, it doesn't take more than a minute for a cart with some yummy dim sum to roll by.

Food wise, there were definitely some hit and miss dishes in the typical dim sum cannon. 
Hits: 
Pi dan sou rou zhou (my pin ying is not great, but hopefully this makes sense) aka preserved egg and meat congee -- like WOW. This is some of the best form of this congee I've had in the city. Honestly I'd come back just for this because it's a pretty staple dish for me in dim sum
Siu mai -- how can you not get this? Large and tasty.

Misses:
Spare ribs in black bean sauce -- sad. This is a pretty classic dish, and this just didn't taste very good at all. It lacked flavor.
Beef noodle rolls - meh, I didn't love these. Will try out the shrimp ones next time I'm back. 

The place is definitely pricey, but it's SF so I guess it's normal. Each dish we got was about $5, but given the quality, I was pretty happy. Plus, "pricey" in Chinatown standards is still a $30 lunch for 2 which is great by SF standards. 

tldr; probably one of my top dim sum places in Chinatown... would def get the preserved egg and pork congee
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Totally editing my old Review b/c I realized I was a little harsh & my palette has changed a little. 

I mainly come here for Yum Cha (Chinese version of Brunch), so I'm not sure about their dinner experience. First thing to do is grab a number when you walk in b/c 98% of the time there will be a queue (unless you come right when they open). 

~~Parking: Street parking, but i'm sure you've already parked elsewhere and are just looking for a place to eat. 
~~Service: Servers come around with carts full off food and you can ask them what they have and choose what you would like to eat. If you want a big main platter dish like noodles and such you'd have to order it with a manager.
~~Other Notes: Bathrooms are up stairs & entrance to the stairs are near the stage. Have the person that has the ticket number waiting inside so you don't miss your call. 
~~Tips: Would def recommend getting the Feng Zhao (chicken feet) to try at least once b/c it's mainly what people get for dim sum. 
~~Return: Yes, it's one of the few good yum cha places in Chinatown. If you have a go to spot, please PM me and share the place!!
author: Jean T.

description:
This place is super pack full of Asian every time I come here. So I thought to myself this place must be good. I have decided to come here for lunch. Had lunch here and I was surprised. It's like eating in Vancouver Bc. Well close enough . Good Asian food outside of Asia. 

I did notice the health concern posted on Yelp after finished eating so luckily nothing bad happen. 

Service is a bit slow here that's for sure. Asked for glass of water and the server forgot about it. Made me wait until i was tire of asking over and over again so I kind of got a bit angry. After that it came right away. As we, after we paid and was still sitting at the table they started cleaning right away and laying new place mats. We have not left yet what's with the rush. Service not that great that's for sure.

Decor is nice with nice chandlers.  The place is pretty big being he fact it's in San Francisco Chinatown. Parking is horrible! It's super hard to find a parking space. Even meter parking is difficult to find. City is too dense and it's annoying.

Ok now back to food. All dim sum are fresh and taste great.

I highly recommend this place base on food but not service. Oh yeah this place is quite pricy compared to LA dim sum
author: Denise W.

description:
This is probably the most disappointing dim sum place that I have ever been to.

The service was either super slow or the ladies were very aggressive in serving the food. We waited so long for some orders that we ordered in the kitchen. After 25 minutes of waiting for a Chang fen, we decided to just leave without getting it, but they delivered it when I asked for the check. Then the waiter yelled at me for asking for a check before a food was delivered.

Regarding the food, it was very mediocre and there are many other dim sum places that I have been to that are much better than this one.

Overall, just do down the street to the other dim sum place that probably has better service and food. Unfortunately, it was closed when we tried to go today.
author: Samantha S.

description:
This was the third year my family has held my grandpa's birthday dinner here and it was a sure hit! 
Each summer, we have reserved the second floor for a huge family dinner at this restaurant since we are all fans of this place! We usually take four to five tables on the top, while there are wedding receptions taking place on the bottom floor during dinner time.
The total cost for a 5-6 course meal came to roughly $800 for four tables of ten. A decent cost for the delicious food served that night.
The food came out fast and fresh with attentive service and happy tummies.
As always, I will definitely come back here for another birthday dinner!

Pros:
-Delicious, big serving dishes
-Helpful and attentive waiters
-Comfortable seating area
-Family and kid friendly
-Waiters help box all leftovers up for each guest
-Helped us cut the cake and serve it

Cons:
-Lobster noodles tasted bland with less seasoning
-Restroom is filthy (Second floor, cut through the kitchen, follow signs)

Tips:
-Parking is easy to find on the street (for dinner) since meters stop after 6PM
-Speaking Chinese here will help
author: Lianne W.

description: New Asia is the definition of a gaudy Chinese restaurant. Visiting SF from DC, we were really excited to be walking around a real Chinatown. For those who don't know, DC's Chinatown is completely westernized with maybe ONE half decent Chinese restaurant. SF's Chinatown was a blast for us craving some authentic sights and smells. We wandered the streets for a bit and checked out a few other restaurants and bakeries, but eventually we were suckered by the crowd and overall vibe of New Asia. When we showed up, the hostess was handing out numbers to people in line and aggressively yelling in a microphone. The crowd was primarily Chinese people, and the general vibe made me nostalgic of the time I've spent in China/HK. We were seated pretty quickly for noon on a Saturday. Ladies came around in carts and were surprisingly polite was we chose our food. Maybe it was because we spoke mandarin to them. All in all, the restaurant was relatively dirty, the food was average, but the experience was a blast. Pricing wasn't bad either, less than $40 for two of us to stuff our face.
author: Eric H.

description:
The first restaurant we went to there was an hour wait at 1PM and since we didn't want to stand outside in the sun for an hour, we went on the hunt for another dim sum place.

We came upon New Asia.  The last time I ate there was 8 years ago so I didn't remember much about the experience except we went with a local and he said it was a good restaurant to have dim sum at.  From the entrance, we could see a few available tables so we made our way in.

It was a hot day and like most places, there's no AC but a few big fans blowing.  I felt bad for the staff running around sweating.  The food on carts came around pretty frequently.  But after a few rounds, it's the same stuff circulating around.  We ordered a few favourites shortly after seated such as har gow and rice roll with beef.  The har gow was good with lots of plump shrimp in it but the other food wasn't as impressive.

Although the staff are running around, they aren't consistent with the service as we asked for water and needed refills and we could barely get anyone to stop at our table.  For 4 people, our bill was just over $50 but there were no prices on the card they stamp. 

The washroom looked like it hadn't been serviced since my last visit 8 years ago.  They are upstairs but there's one wheelchair accessible one downstairs (the door was so dirty and black, I wouldn't want to see the inside).  Upstairs washroom was dirty, small, and barely any soap.  

Definitely needs an update, maybe when I return in 8 years, it might look better.  Then again, maybe not.
author: Violet P.

description:
What a disappointment, it's taken off from a must visit list next time we go to the Bay Area.  The bad service remains but the quality of the food has gone down.  The lobster emein no longer good from what we remembered.  The noodles doesn't absorb any of the lobster flavor.

Proof of this is when leaving during prime lunch time, there is no longer a crazy crowd waiting for tables.

For a good dim sum place without the parking hassle, check out Grand Palace in Downtown South San Francisco.
author: Addie L.

description:
I've been to San Fran 3 times now and always end up here for dim sum. I have no idea how it compares to some of the other authentic places in the city but to me it's always delicious. 

I never expect good service because I am clearly the minority so it doesn't bother me that no one asks me what I want to drink. Plus I like the green tea! 

You order things as they are flying off of the dozens of carts throughout the restaurant. This time they had a menu on the table and we were able to point to specific items we were looking for and although they didn't confirm understanding a few minutes later the dishes would arrive straight from the kitchen! 

You have to be adventurous and willing to try different dishes to truly enjoy this spot. We ate what felt like a millions dishes between us three girls and still spent under $50! 

The bill will not be in English, there's not any pricing so just trust in them and relax! 

Are there better places in San Fran? Probably. But I like coming here!
author: Tara P.

description:
I came here with cousins this past Saturday. Even though there was a crowd waiting to be seated, when I went up to the hostess and told her, "Party of 6, please," I was immediately told that a table for 6 had just opened up, and was guided straight to the table. My cousins were parking, and they were so shocked that I had gotten a table that quickly.

Food was DELICIOUS. This place is spacious and packed like crazy (as to be expected of a dim sum establishment), and there's always servers walking around pushing their carts of food. Even though the staff seems to mainly speak Cantonese, you should be able to communicate if you speak Mandarin, and their English was decent. Bathrooms were also cleaner than I expected.

Everything we had tasted wonderfully--not a single bad dish! It was just a shame that they didn't have Xiao Long Bao (Chinese soup dumpling). The Portuguese tarts and the Sesame Balls are Heavenly desserts!
author: Jo W.

description: Typical dim sum place. Just like New York. Large and busy, filled with Chinese, which means the food is OK. The place itself is dumpy and dirty like most city Chinese restaurants. We had some dim sum on this day. I found the food to be very good.
author: Kai L.

description:
Decent dim sum at the edge of Chinatown. The place is huge with wall to wall tables in the main dining room and plenty of tables upstairs as well. We arrived around 11am on a Sunday and were seated right away for our party of 5 upstairs. First impression is your typical dim sum joint in SF Chinatown. Loud, busy as hell and could use a little bit... well, actually a whole lot of cleaning. 

The har gow was ok but it was sticking to the paper in the bamboo container. That tells me that the dumpling encasing it was undercooked. Not cool. The siu mai was good. I liked it. The taro cake was good. The short ribs in black bean sauce was good. The lobster chow mein was good but really rich. The char siu bao was good. I was bummed I didnt see any bbq pork buns, foil-wrapped chicken and crab claws. There were other things on carts we passed on like the jook and egg rolls.

Service wasnt bad. It was hurried but that's normal. They need to clean the place up. That is why I never opt for dim sum in Chintaown but it was within a good walking distance from our hotel. Would I come back? Probably not. There are many more places that are of better quality & atmosphere throughout the city.
author: Chuck D.

description:
As terrible as the reviews imply.

I've been to dim sum probably 100 times in my life, and this is probably the second to worst dim sum experience I've had.

Reasons this place terrible:
- Food is starchy, undercooked or overcooked, and basically tastes like frozen stuff defrosted and then nuked
- Service is non-existent
- You won't get all the dim sum staples you've come to expect, because the service is non existent and not all the carts come to you

The only redeeming qualities:
- It is cheap
- The tea is okay

Just...don't.
author: Lilly D.

description: During a banquet, I asked for ice & the waiter looked at me, made a look like "wtf that's not my job" & walked away. Twice. Food is not great either.
author: Alicia W.

description:
I'll have to give this place a minus five stars . They put a noodle dish on our table that we did not order . 
Also charged a dim sum fee of $7 per person . Not sure what that was about but the bill came out to $83 for four people . The most expensive item was a lobster noodle dish that the non English speaking cart person put on our table without any of us ordering . Very suspicious . Use caution , and don't be like us and try not to ruffle feathers if you think something suspicious is going on .  I should have challenged the dim sum fee at least , but I felt like communication is impossible .
author: Dan F.

description: Good dim sum. Came to SF and checked out yelp for reviews. Walked around Chinatown and realized the best places probably aren't on yelp because people that go there don't use the internet like I do. Nice, big spot with traditional push cart food at a reasonable price. Give it a shot!
author: Christina W.

description:
40 years ago this was a nice Chinatown restaurant named Asia Garden that was popular for wedding banquets.

Now, it is aptly named New Asia.  There were probably 200 customers and maybe all but a dozen were born in Asia.  It looks like a restaurant in China.  I wonder if the fire marshal and health department have inspected recently.  We expected authentic Chinese dim sum.  

Portions are very generous, but flavor is barely OK.  Many of us were nauseated a after eating there.  Don't know if the stuffiness of the restaurant contributed to our malaise or if it was the food.  The management hung multiple fans along the rear wall with exposed electrical cords attached to the walls.

Six of us had dim sum for $80 including tax and tip but we did not eat a lot.  I had little appetite for the food

The restaurant is packed with people and very noisy.  
Servers kept pushing us to order more.  When we said we were full, three different ones tried to push us to get food to go.

It's really packed with Chinese speaking customers, so I think many people like their food.  

If you want to experience China without the hassles of international travel, this might be a good choice.  The streets outside are packed with people, including many smokers.  The one big difference is the air does not have the damp musty smell of Asia.
author: Joanna S.

description:
2.5 stars

Our family has been coming to New Asia for a very long time. Literally decades. Had many weddings and family association dinners here over the years.  Though, it's been awhile until recently. Came to a family association dinner and my experience with the food was ok. The Chinese Banquet dishes came as expected and everything tasted fine. It was the restaurant putting its best foot forward. 

So why the Meh? I gotta say, rather than my experience with the food it was restaurant itself. Right when I stepped in every step was slightly sticky. Getting to the table growing up we've become accustomed to wiping the dinnerware down but honestly it's more of a formality...this time there was a thin layer of grease. Yeah...time to step it up New Asia.
author: Desmond F.

description: Came into the restaurant very cramped. There was no space to move around. The utensils and the floor were both very sticky. The service was pretty terrible also, with 2 waiters dropping some of our food while another had ignored us entirely when called upon. Would not come here again.
author: Melody T.

description: Nice service - food is good. Lots of space. Seems clean. Sesame balls are really good. Liked the duck. We came at the end of the lunch period so the selection was a little limited. Would definitely come back.
author: Sean F.

description:
Came last Sunday for dim sum.  We had 3 tables among us and the total bill came out to be around $360 plus tip.  

The food doesn't taste as good as many years ago.  The dim sum are average and overpriced.  The only good thing is that they still have people pushing dim sum carts around and the place is packed with diners so it was a livelier place to eat.  

Also ordered the Chicken Fried Rice and it was not good.  I think my husband makes better fried rice.   

The bathroom areas are dirty, sticky and slippery.
author: J W.

description: Cantonese dim sum restuarant with an authentic taste. A must try for push-cart dim sum breakfast/brunch! Someone told me that, "I'm glad you speak cantonese, I just want the food which I do not know how to order". You have got to try the BBQ pork and Roast Pork. Duck buns are light and fresh. Har kao is extremely fresh. A friend told me that she saw chinese restaurant owners from Sonoma County eating here.
author: William L.

description:
The food is fantastic here. I got lobster noodle, roasted duck, and other dim sums. They were cooked perfectly and not under- or over-cooked. 

Ignore the bad review and try the food out yourself.
author: Pim H.

description: They blast chinese music here. Bad food and bad service 10/10 WOULD NOT RECOMEND. Overprice food and takes a long time to come to you. If it werent for the nearly 100 elderly chinese people at this restraunt, this place would be out of business. The singing here will give you headaches. This restruant is the reason why taxes should be raised. Then, this restruant will be replaced by a McDonalds, which people would prefer over this place. All the meat here is frozen and covered in salt. Only come here if youre an elderly chinese citizen
author: Viet L.

description: Average dim sum. Rude staff. Charges for tea even if you don't order tea. When we asked for a different type of tea since they said they had to charge us for it, they audibly complained and said in Chinese how annoying we were for asking for a tea. There are plenty of better places within a blocks walk of here. Try one of those places instead.
author: Katherine F.

description: Many different types of dim sum. It seemed very good however I got pretty sick afterwards. My non macho tummy can't handle the cleanliness short cuts taken at this establishment.
author: E. R.

description:
Im used to Chinese restaurants having bad service, so i wont factor that into this review, but this place isnt even that great for food.

I came for dim sum. They really lacked variety, and the chef wasnt even in the building so they couldnt make food from the menu. I feel like the same 2 carts passed by, and they didnt have a lot of my favorites like the sticky rice in banana leaves or shrimp puffs with sugar cane.

The congee was really good though.
author: Justin K.

description: This place used to be my go-to Dim Sum place in Chinatown. I liked the quality/size/price of the dumplings. I came to visit on a Saturday afternoon, and I was immediately sat. There were a lot of people in the restaurant, but we were able to be served right away. Right as we got sat, we were able to get our favorites (Siu Mai, Har Gow, Taro, Chinese Broccoli, etc). Service wise, they did a great job. Food quality wise.. not so much! The dumplings weren't steaming fresh and the fried food seemed stale/not fresh. I understand it's been sitting out for a bit, but they should at least rotate it so the dumplings are fresh and hot!
author: Katy D.

description: The absolute WORST place ever....I'd rather eat dirt... if I was able to give it negative 5 stars I would
author: Mike R.

description:
I don't know if I should writing for a review for this spot... especially when I came here for a funeral dinner. 

Businesses in dtsf is my worst nightmare in terms of parking and parking on hills. Parking in sf is already a nightmare, now think of adding parking limits, construction, hills, and a**holes that can't drive or park. 

Food is extremely subpar. Don't expect any fine dining. I can't think of any dish that is memorable, other than the desserts at the end. The redbean mochi is quite delicious.
author: Phuong V.

description:
Top go for Chinese dim sum in a palace-like hall.

Carts come around with selections of Chinese food and when you choose, the attendant stamps a sheet. Your total will be based on the number of items you eat.

The eatery itself is quite disorganized but there is quick service but long waiting times. Perfect for wedding celebrations.

Parking can be a nightmare as it is in San Francisco and Chinatown especially is notorious for parking spaces.

Save yourself some time by parking at the Portsmouth Square Garage on Kearny Street. Rates are cheap and the garage is city-operated.
author: Junming G.

description:
If I could leave only zero stars I would !!!! 
    My husband and I came to lunch at this restaurant today in San Francisco. We were quickly sat down and began to order everything was fine until it came time to pay. They produce the check and we gave them our visa they quickly came back with two or three people I can't remember telling us that their visa machine was down, we had no idea what to do or what they wanted from us. None of them had a very qualified English speaking skills but they continuously directed us to the ATM outside telling us cash only cash only. No one had mentioned this was a cash only business when we got there or else we would've made sure to have grab cash first. I went up to the front desk to see if I could talk to someone who is reasonable because the three at the table seem confused and unclear as how to handle a situation as well. I went up to the front desk to be greeted by an equally as grumpy and equally poor English skills and all she could manage to say to us was just repeating over and over cash ATM outside visa is not working. At the time there was over 150 people in the restaurant and I could not understand how they expected everyone in there to have only cash on them, ( was it only us?) ( we were the only Caucasian people in there) (racism??)it did not make sense to me and things started to feel wrong with the whole situation. My husband and I started to walk towards the door to go to the ATM to get them their money as we had repeatedly told them OK OK we will go get money from ATM like they continued to tell us and point to the door ,as soon as we started to walk towards the door a giant man stood in front of my husband attempting to block him from leaving, because apparently they had had some idea that they were going to hold one of us hostage while the other person was sent to the ATM again this all felt very staged and planned. We were in this establishment for length of at least 45 minutes to an hour and we did not see one person escorted out of the restaurant to get cash for this business ( racism??) who is claiming that their visa machine had suddenly "broke down" then as attitudes began to escalate very quickly because we have never been treated in such away by strangers let alone upper management of a highly populated tourism spot in Chinatown. This giant Asian man proceeded to follow us all the way to our ATM walking through Chinatown yelling And cursing at us in his language while he was followed around by another short little Asian man wearing a long black trenchcoat he was a very frightening person as well (mafia??$) as the tall Asian gentleman followed us through Chinatown arguing with us he had told us that this just happened the moment he went to use our card, but then a few minutes later during argument told us that he had been following people to the ATM all day to get their money from them (??? So which one was it ???) ( SCAM )( SCAMMING THE GOVERNMENT??) ( TAX EVASION??) I have contacted Better Business Bureau, I have contacted the police, I have contacted the mayors office and the San Francisco public tourism headquarters and I will continue to reach out and contact every possible legal Avenue untill I am completely satisfied with the consequences that these restauranteurs should have to face. I have never been so humiliated embarrassed or frightened in a public place let alone a restaurant ever in my life! 

Sent from my iPhone
author: Allison J.

description:
Apparently after Christmas, everyone is still hungry. Came on a Thursday afternoon for dim sum and still had to wait a good 25 minutes. It's cool... Gives me time to look at whats in the carts and figure out what I want. Everything we got was huge portioned, steaming hot, and delicious. I recommend the sui mai, ha gow, turnip cakes, and chicken feet. Very well made and flavorful. 

Tip: eat everything with the hot sauce!!
author: Stella Y.

description: The floors are dirty and slippery. Almost slipped going into the bathroom. The food is too salty and not worth the price. The service is also horrible. They took away my soup when there is still a lot of soup left.
author: Kevin L.

description: Sitting among other sub par places to eat at, is this gem.  Suggested by a friend they were right on. Great for Dim Sum. Loved it to start our San Fran trip off.
author: shane a.

description: This great place is closing so go soon and don't miss out.  Traditional and fantastic dim sum and dim sum on carts atmosphere! Especially good were the shrimp noodle, duck and custard pies. Run there; don't walk!
author: Vyvyan B.

description: No wait, huge place a lot of tables, love the dimsum selection. Food taste great. Even with a lot of people, you dont feel compacted. We love going here every time we visit china town.
author: Don D.

description:
There are times in life where you just give in to anything and this is one of them. 

After a long afternoon of running around circles in Fisherman's Wharf to rolling down Lombard Street, we finally reached Chinatown. Of course we were excited to be in Chinatown but our stomachs weren't, so we threw our hands up in the air like we didn't care and went to the next place we could get dim sum. This place is hugeeeee. Like, I bet people throw parties and banquets here all the time and I bet whenever someone famous from China/Hong Kong/Taiwan comes to town, they hold a meeting here and this place secretly turns into a huge nightclub once 9 p.m. hits. SO BIG, there are 2 floors. 

Seating is a little congested but I don't think people share tables here...or do they...
Didn't want to get a little uncontrollable, given the way we are when we're getting dim sum so we just stuck with the basics and got Fried Turnip Cake and the Lobster E-Fu Noodles were calling us. The turnip cakes were standard but the noodles really hit the spot; there wasn't a lot of lobster meat but the flavoring was delicious and the noodles were consistent. $17 for the noodles was definitely a little pricey but every dollar was worth it and we were really hungry so there wasn't much left. 

I wouldn't call this restaurant a "must" but the lobster noodles are a must. Glad I came here, though it was the only dim sum experience during my trip but I know there are other  great options in San Francisco.
author: Sharon T.

description:
It was about 1 pm on Sunday when we arrived and surprisingly we got a table for 4 right away although it is a large restaurant.  We were asked what kind of tea we wanted and we also requested ice cold water which took a while to arrive.  The carts full of dim sum came around quickly with the usual items, we didn't see anything different here in San Francisco.  The food tasted just okay.

Most of the staff doesn't seem to speak much English so that could be a problem when asking what the items are or when requesting a certain item.  The washrooms could use some attention as there were not enough stalls for the size of the restaurant, one stall was out of order and really no place to line up to get in.
author: Lisa C.

description: Do not go here. Dirty and the food quality is horrible. They will rip you off too. Trust me, never again!
author: Khanh N.

description: Worst dim sum I ever had. Chrysanthemum tea was like water, service was terrible. Food had no taste
author: Jj H.

description:
Went for dinner
Didn't know they don't have dim sum for dinner:( 
The service was slow and we waited a while for our food. The guy who served  us didn't understand much English. It was hard to communicate. 
The food taste decent
We got Mongolian beef, noodles, and duck
The duck took 45mins to get to the table! Ridiculous wait. 
Find another place if you're in china town. It's not worth the wait and taste.
author: Cee T.

description:
Good, not great. Service could be dicey if the place is crowded, and it pretty much always is. My favorite thing about New Asia is, unlike other popular dim sum restaurants, inventory of the more popular dishes are always available - from shu mai to hai gow, they kept it coming!

Note: From my observations I conclude that the madame in charge of restaurant's cash register likes to get loose. I've been here twice, saw her sippin' on liquor both times.
author: Dave K.

description:
Went in here based on the volume of people eating that were obviously locals. 

This was a fun experience as the servers wheel carts around the floor with various items to select. You can prefer from a menu, but why you would want too is beyond me.  

The duck was cooked perfectly.  The pork was super delicious too.

We thought the bill would be more than $90, but end up at $65. And we were stuffed!  

I recommend this as a great local place to get Dim Sum.
author: Mark P.

description:
I came here for a family gathering and as soon as we sat down, we noticed that someone had drank the soda from our table. We deducted this from seeing our empty table with a opened bottle of soda and a used glass. We asked the waiters if they could switch out the bottle and give us a new glass but they said that it wasn't their problem. They made up an excuse that someone from our party had sat and drank from it so they weren't going to switch it out. After a few minutes of arguing they decided to give us a new bottle.

What enraged me wasn't that we couldn't get a replacement bottle of soda. It was the fact that they made up a story and decided to just continue to comfortably sit down while getting paid without trying to be empathetic and seeing our side of the story.
