They had very poor customer care and along with the bloody raw chicken they served, I would not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Frank C.

description:
If you need a spot for Dim Sum this is the new place to close. Once they closed Golden Dragon, this is the new go to spot for dim sum for the locals. Hey it's crowded and loud, but that's what you expect at Chinatown dim sum. They come around with the carts here so just point and get stuff put on your table. The flavor of the standards like , Sui mai, har gow, chicken feet, pork spareribs are good.  The captains( head waiters) are a little hard to find to place extra orders and get the check but other than that, pretty standard dim sum in Chinatown. 

Good food, standard Chinese "Chinatown" Service. 

Come on the weekend for the real Chinatown dim sum experience.
author: Vincent W.

description:
The food is average for the price. It is more than some dim sum
houses. The service is poor. The waiters run around but not look to service the customers. It is pretty much self-served by picking the dishes from the dim sum carts as they come around.
author: Fred T.

description: This place is a solid 3. Came here since I was a kid. Consistent quality. Fast service. Can't complain. The portions have gotten a lot bigger. I would recommend coming here with at least 4 people since  most of the dim sum items come in 4 pieces.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Let me start by saying that I used to come here a lot in the 90's for dinner or dim sum when I was younger. I haven't been here in over 10 years and thought I would give it a try again. I should have just left this restaurant in my memories because now I will forever have a bad taste in my month both literally and figuratively.

Service: I am used to the stereotypical Chinese restaurant service, but everyone here was rude. They slammed the dishes onto your table and had a mean tone asking what you wanted. In Chinese they would complain about their boss on the floor and how he does nothing. They seemed to stamp anywhere they wanted so you don't even know what you are paying for. The service was terrible, but not as bad as their food.

Food: Terrible! Haw gow was bland and all of their shrimp dim sum was tasteless. The Cha Siu bao was cold and they might as well just call it bao because you could barely find the cha siu. Anyone that said they had a good dim sum dish must not have be paying any attention to what they are eating, because everything had no flavor, cold, or MSG filled. The best thing might have been their $1.25 per person tea. (oh..BTW, water is $1.25 per person too!)

On top of all this, when I got home to review this place on Yelp, a "Consumer Alert: Poor Food Safety score" notification popped up. Yeah! I can easy say I will not be going back to this place in a long, long, long time. Someone better be forcing me to go, because I don't want to step foot into this place again.
author: Cal K.

description:
2 stars for chicken feet:  could be less soggy, flavor was below par
2 stars for roasted pork belly - fresh 
3 stars bbq pecking duck- fresh but cold
2 stars pork soup dumplings -had juice inside the dumpling but lack pork flavor
3 stars jok (porage) - good 
3 stars durian pastry - fresh but really oily
4 stars Chinese broccoli - fresh and the amount was huge
5 fried shrimp balls- crispy and served warm and fresh
author: Roul L.

description: around for decades (asia garden), and hasn't changed since childhood memories.  even the clientele, noise, carts, pushy servers, dirtiness, popularity, same.  wrappers drier, some overly sweet, greasy, a bit inconsistent. fatty tasty cha siu.  but they also have their unique pink cheung fun with fried shrimp inside.  can check out lai hong lounge
author: Rob C.

description:
I swore two years ago that I would never go to New Asia again. When I went a few years ago for dim sum, I got the bill and paid cash (cash only). Anyways, I picked up the change and I was getting ready to put a tip down and before I could put any money down the waitress yelled at me for taking money off the table. Wow. So I put a ten percent tip down cause they really didn't do anything. It's all push carts. When I put ten percent down she yelled at me again and told me how much more of a tip to put down. Because of this I swore I would never come here again. Don't like it when people yell at me for tips. Not cool at all. 

Anyways, I had to come here again for my father-in-laws 90's birthday. Four tables on a Saturday night. They had a wedding banquet and another party at the same time. Food was at best the worst Chinese food I've ever ate in SF Chinatown. I'm thinking the Panda Express is better. Soup was terrible. Not sure what kind but my wife didn't even eat it. This was a first for her. Also, scallops were sour which means they were spoiled and the lobster wasn't firm which meant it was under cooked. Even with a banquet with four tables, they required cash only. Terrible. 

I really don't like this place. Food wasn't very good. Service wasn't good. Someone told me the Chinese waiters were cussing at each other while serving the food (I don't speak Chinese so i don't know). Cash only. I will never go back unless forced again. There is too many good places to eat so no more chances for this place. Good luck if you go here.
author: Doug T.

description:
If you're not asian and you walk into this place for the first time, the thing you have to realize is that you're probably going to be in the minority. And this is a HUGE restaurant. But if you want an authentic dim sum experience, this is a great option. 

I'm giving this place 4 stars but here are some of the pitfalls:

- Always crowded but we got seated within 10 min; the lady at the front desk calls out your number into a microphone like it's bingo night.
- As with many (and most) real Asian establishments, don't expect the friendliest service. Just keep your head down, point to what you want, and eat. For you picky, special needs eaters, you won't last 5 min here so don't even think about it.
- Chicken feet. Enough said.

If you want a cleaner, more American establishment, you could go to Yank Sing (which I love also), but you'll probably pay twice as much. This place is very reasonable.
author: Jules L.

description:
Went here today because Uber hosted a Chinese New Year free lunch for some of their drivers.  I was disappointed to see the food safety warning on Yelp that this place scored in the bottom 5% of San Francisco restaurants (and Uber loves to brag about how well they take care of their drivers) but I'm a sucker for a good deal and free is free.  Yelp said vegetarian options were available so I figured with Chinese food a vegan like me would be able to make do. Unfortunately they had a set menu with nothing vegan, or vegetarian on it.  So when the food started coming out I asked a server if there was anything vegan/vegetarian and I could tell he didn't really understand but he indicated that he would ask someone else. A few minutes later I saw him motion towards me to another server who looked but then just carried on with what she was doing. Several minutes later I was able to get her attention as she was walking by and asked her the same question, she seemed to understand after a couple rounds and headed back towards the kitchen.  After about 20 to 30 more minutes watching them carry plates of food to all the other tables I got up and asked her again and she waved me off and walked away a few feet and made some sort of indication that made it seem like I should talk to this other guy next to her, who told me no and all that was available was what was on the set menu. I was pretty upset at this point and as she tried to avoid listening to me I complained I had been waiting for half an hour and she could have just told me no in the first place. The other guy could understand why I was upset and ready to leave and tried to assure me that they had plenty of vegetarian menu items but after he talked to the manager it was again a NO but finally at least with an apology. 
Sad. 
With their health department record though, perhaps I lucked out.
author: Paul P.

description:
Ate here once and this dim sum spot is definitely where all the local Chinese people go and it's not touristy at all. Like a typical popular local favorite dim sum spot, there's a long time wait time for a table during lunch time.

My coworker held her wedding banquet here and it was beautiful! Congratulations Anny and Sam!
author: Alice X.

description:
While in the city for the day and hanging out in Chinatown my friend had never had dim sum before so I thought we better get some and let her experience it.  Walking around all day we wanted a place to sit down and eat and a lot of the dim sum places are just takeout kind places with huge lines (must be good food) But this was the first one with good reviews that we came across that was sit down style. The food was OK but I have certainly had better.  The service was mediocre at best and they skipped us several times when going by with the carts. Lost a few stars for this. When I received the bill I was shocked to find it was over $55. especially for lunch for 2 people and the amount of food we received did not correlate with this price.  I feel they overcharged for the plates, we had a total of 7 and barely had a little box of left overs. 
6 pot stickers
4 eggrolls
6 dumpling things 
Chow mien
3 mini egg custard tarts
Duck
Pork

They brought hot tea without asking and then charged for it, not cool. Also it took forever and asking two times for water and 3 times for hot mustard the egg rolls were cold by the time we got that. I would go here again just because of the cost I have had much better food and larger quantity dim sum in other cities for less money.
author: Heidi H.

description:
I didn't know a lot of dimsum places in Chinatown SF are to-go only.  Places that had high Yelp rating did not offer dine-in so next best thing was New Asia Chinese Restaurant.  It was hugh and packed so we thought it would be worth trying.  

The wait was not too long, but it was a bit funny and annoying too listening to the lady in the front calling out numbers to the awaiting customers.  She looked and sounded very unhappy and upset.  

Food was good, but nothing I'd dream about having.  Cart ladies were pretty friendly, though the same couldn't be said about other wait staff.  Also, we had to ask for ice water about 7 times before they brought us any.
author: Angela W.

description:
Wow! This is such a "80's throwback to Hong Kong" kind of a restaurant. Instead of dim sum, I came to New Asia Chinese Restaurant for a dinner banquet that had folks like Mayor Ed Lee, city councilmen, Miss Chinatown 2012, Miss Chinatown 2012 runner-up, Miss Chinatown 2nd runner... you get the drill. It was that kind of time warp that made it awesome at the same time. 

It's amazing how many tables they can squeeze in here. We barely had room to maneuver much less the servers. Oh well they weren't really serving - efficiency is key here. Their goal is to serve you food quickly. No "Hi, my name is _____  and I'll be your server today." Napkins and cutlery were dumped onto the table and nary a smile to be seen. Yet it all made sense somehow. 

Food was mediocre. How 80's Chinese wedding banquet is shrimp and melon doused in mayo? There were other fried dishes, soup, and noodles served that were so-so as well. I must say though that they roast their meats (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hPdebXu_37ELCtoDaVuU8g?select=0GwxcVi0BBqcQtUJIR7ijA#vhKrTESZXrthNfZ6Ynt7YQ) really well and I liked the chinese veggies with mushrooms here. 

New Asia Chinese Restaurant is worth a visit just for the step back in time... just don't come here for the food exclusively. Perhaps weekend dim sum is a good time to plan that return visit.
author: Jon L.

description:
We come here every year for our association's banquet. I am so disturbed that I am typing this before dinner is even over. It's not about the food, it's the service.
  
Why is there a separate party with competing karaoke?  I can barely hear what's going on in my banquet and the clashing audio is making my ears bleed. Also, why are the waiters clanging our plates? They also muscle their way to plate the food. And they act like you don't exist.  

Y'all need to fix this restaurant because you make Chinese restaurant's look bad. Epitome of crappy service and I would never come here on my own
author: Lisa X.

description:
This is where the Chinese locals go for weekend brunch, so you know it's solid. It's one of the few places in the city that not only still has carts but also has abundant seating. If you're looking for attentive service, go to somewhere like Yank Sing because you will not have a good time here. 

Carts are for people who want instant gratification, whereas made-to-order places are for those that want fresh & hot foods. I personally choose the former every time. Even though I could tell the food had been out on the carts for a while, being able to eat upon sitting down made it worth it. 

Recommend: shumai, hargow, changfun, xiaolongbao, taro dumplings, chive dumplings, steamed spare ribs, custard buns.

Will be back!
author: Lucy N.

description:
Not my cup of tea for dim sum. But it is decent when other options aren't available. They come around in carts with your typical dim sum dishes but they also have a menu you can order from. Food is mediocre at it's best, it sad but I think there are fast food dim sum places that do a better job than New Asia...and cheaper. 

Layout is like a typical Chinese banquet type restaurant. Pretty sure I've been here for a wedding or Chinese dinner for an event but don't seem to remember at the moment.

Parking is horrible. Just bus it. Or taxi. Or lfyt. Or bike. Whatever suits you.
author: Tommy L.

description:
YELPERS - pay attention to the dangerously low Health Score: 64! Up from 57. 

Is you look this up on the SF Dept of Pub Hlth website, you'll see that among the high violations is "vermin infestation." Is that what you want with your dim sum?
author: R. P.

description: Chow mein and chow fun is good, but greasy. As most Chinese food is. Vegetables are good. The steamed buns are amazing
author: Emily X.

description: Don't go here. Food is below average and they over charge. We only had 11 items, but they charged us 12. We told the manager and he started yelling. They charged $1.25 per person for tea, even for an infant that doesn't drink tea. Bad bad bad place!!!!!
author: Tracey N.

description:
We went to New Asia in hopes of finding authentic dim sum because where else better than Chinatown? Some reviews say that New Asia is the BEST in terms of dim sum in this neighborhood. BUT they also fail to mention that most of the near by restaurants have been closed down for business. New Asia is probably the ONLY big restaurant that's still open. So if BEST is equivalent to ONLY or best out of a very limited list, then I guess. 

I'll commend New Asia for still serving their dim sum by ladies pushing carts, they're one of the very few restaurants who still employ this old fashion method. With that said, in order for this method to be efficient, dim sum has to circulate around the WHOLE restaurant, not just around the entrance of the kitchen or down the center aisle.

This is where New Asia completely failed. My family was UNFORTUNATE enough to be seated along the side of the wall. For 25 minutes, the same ladies pushing the cart of buns walked past us at least 5 times while everything else that came out of the kitchen never even went by us. When we requested for specific dishes, we were just told  that they would be out shortly. The problem was that when it came out, it was served directly to the tables sitting by the entrance of the kitchen. So while all the center tables had tons of dishes, the other side of the restaurant either had none or sparse dishes. 

Fast forward to after we voice our complaints to several bus boys and waiters, they start having ONE person serve from our side of the restaurant rather than just the center. Since all the tables around us were pretty much neglected, EVERYONE called dibs on everything and anything in that one cart. It's a rather peculiar (humorous)  feeling to witness all these grown adults yelling at the dim sum lady to ensure they get food...

Some of the dishes were cold (I think STEAMED anything should be at LEAST warm), service was very lacking to say the least, dishes & overall cleanliness of the place was very questionable, inefficient dissemination of food, extremely pricey for the quality of food, the list can go on.

In summary, this place was a total waste of time & money.
author: Ada C.

description: Food was decent, but this is the most expensive dim sum I've ever had. I paid almost $8 each for a normal dim sum plate that normally costs me $2-$3 at any other place. The food is not worth its price. As expected, since it is chinatown, cleanliness is 4/10 and authenticity of the food 8/10. Service is 3/10 as they all speak Chinese, which makes communication extremely difficult, especially if you feel you got overcharged as I am pretty sure I did.
author: Sydney ..

description: Not as much food to choose from before one hour it will close. The dim sum,they just walk through and don't say what they have.
author: Victor C.

description:
cockroaches and cockroaches !! 

I came here few weeks ago with my husband and friend couple.  The dim sums were ok , nothing extraordinary. But , we saw the roaches really close to our table and had to leave before they came close to me and my table. It was absolutely disgusting. 

 
If you can easily see cockroaches where you eat, it's not hard to imagine how poorly the restaurant keep their hygiene in the areas where the customers can't see.
author: grace k.

description: New Asia has been in China Town forever. The dim sum is pretty good and the daily night live band along with dinner is so cheap. Dancing & Eating with the great live singing & band performance of oldie Chinese Songs is nowadays a rare experience in the US.  The downside of New Asia is the place is old & messy.  The bathrooms are not clean to the standard but its an old restaurant so not much can be done unless the complete renovation will take place and follow with a significant price increase :)
author: Jason C.

description:
Welcome to China!
The closest I've seen to "the real thing" in this country.
So the health department doesn't like it?  Welcome to China!
The place is dirty, the staff is rude, the tables are crowded, and the line to the ladies room is excruciatingly long.  Never mind!
Some of the dishes are excellent, others taste like they were re-heated from yesterday.  Never mind!
For sheer cultural experience and entertainment, this is the place to go in Chinatown.
author: Melissa K.

description:
I came here for Dimsum with family members. Now coming from NY, Dimsum here is like heaven. Their dimsums are a 10 out of 10 in flavor and presentation. Its like art work served on a plate. This makes NYC's Dimsum look like ..turd... sadly. Each bite was so wonderful that i couldn't help but to order one of everything. Service is just like every chinese place. Just order, hush and eat. I think thats the only thing that doesnt change. 

The food can be a bit pricey compared to NYC's Yumcha places but its worth it as many of their chefs are trained to make hong kong cuisines. some of the things that are found there that maybe impossible here is fresh purple taro buns, stuffed durian puffs and pumpkin and coconut cream mochi dumplings. Getting a table can be tough since its a full house. My aunt had to wait since 10am for 2 tables for 12 people and we sat down at about 11 am.

Now that i am back in NYC writing this review, i am drooling and missing their dimsum.  I do wish i did take pictures but i was too busy eating that i remembered after the meal.
author: Bei T.

description:
This is the only place in chinatown our family goes to for dim sum. They are a tad pricier for chinatown but their food is tasty and consistent week after week. They still have the cart ladies circling around with all the dim sum which probably contributes to their poor food safety score. I sometimes wonder how long a dish had been circling for, especially the lobster noodles. 

Come early to grab a number in line, there is usually about a 30 minute wait on weekends and holidays.
author: Simon L.

description: It was a surprise find when we couldn't find a targeted restaurant for dim sum.   It was packed with local Chinese peeps that assured me no disappointment.   Good selections of dim sum tables came around and we enjoyed everything including my favorite Chinese broccoli!   One lady pushing the table was very friendly and courteous as well.
author: Toni P.

description: Really expensive noodles. They also charge for water and tea and add a 25% service charge. Not vegetarian friendly. Definitely not coming back.
author: Priya S.

description: Came here for yum cha on New Years Eve 2013 with my family and to enjoy the very last day of December 31st 2013 before saying hi to the 1st day of the New Year of January 2014!!! It has been a very long time since 2008 and that would be the very last time... I came for here for yum cha!!! Until yesterday and it was packed with lots and lots of people!!!  But we were really really lucky that the hostess called out our number really fast!!! And our wait didn't really take us that long for us to get seated to our table!!! New Asia isn't really that bad the only good thing was all the dim sum items that we wanted to eat came right to us!!!
author: William B.

description:
It was okay, not a placeI recommend a friend. 

The experience-

The customer service was pretty bad. The waiters and waitresses seemed like they were ignoring my group even though I was speaking Chinese to them. We were waiting a while just for our waters to be refilled even after asking several times.  

The food was mediocre, there was nothing special about it. The Xiao Long bao was disappointing, I have had a lot better. Unfortunately, it was my friend's first time having Xiao Long Bao so they were scarred; they took a bite and never finished it. 

Hope they really improve and the next time I go to try it again I will be blown away!
author: Marvin L.

description:
All hail the cockroach hotel of cold food, shitty service and a cashier that thinks my credit card belongs to her more than myself....

Not a joke! We arrived and got 10 plates of food to share some of which were cold and if they weren't cold they didn't taste at all as they should have. While eating what we could of this cold food we saw a cockroach non one foot away from our table on the wall so we decided to leave.

When we went to the casheir she snached my card out of my hand and ran it before we had a chance to tell her how we wanted to pay, when it was declined for the full amount as I knew it would be she refused to let it be ran again for the smaller amount of my portion of the meal since it had been declined causeing my friend to pay for me. 

That's not even all she then demanded my friend who had already left a decent tip to leave more before we could leave the restaurant.

Unless you enjoy shareing a cold disgusting meal with cockroaches and having to pay whatever the clown makeuped woman at the cashier deams appropriate, I would go anywhere else.

Having lunch in a soup kitchen would probably be cleaner, more appetizing and have better service than this place.
author: Jessica W.

description:
New Asia and it's predecessor (Asia Gardens?thanx carol!) has been around for decades, maybe an half a century.  been to their banquets, dim sum, regular eats,  and weddingss, even made deliveries here (long ago).

don't remember the food so it's probably not that bad and also not memorable.
so i probably won't be returning here.

they have a lot of banquets, weddings here. that's why they're here after all these years. (weddings more profitable than dim sum.
author: Victor G.

description: DON'T GO HERE!!! Probably the worst customer service experience I have ever had. The food was bad and the place was dirty. They would not unlock the restrooms and told me they would be open later. On top of that they charged us for tea which we had not ordered, and when we asked about it they told us it was for the water. We paid in cash and as we were getting up to leave one of the food cart ladies started yelling at us accusing us that we had not paid. Many other workers came over and started talking to one another and soon the whole place was looking at us. Finally the worker who took care of our transaction came over and we were able to go. This place is a tourist trap!! Don't go here!!!
author: Sophia H.

description:
There is one main reason this dim sum restaurant is getting 5 stars from me. They have the MOST amazing Chinese donuts. Have you heard of Cronuts in Soho NY? Where people line up at 6 am for a chance to buy Cronuts? Not me. I would never wake up that early to wait on line for food. So I may never get to taste a Cronut. But here, in a regular dim sum restaurant, you will taste the best Chinese donuts ever. Light, flaky and just right. Not doughy, not too soft. Just perfect. I might even be willing to wait on line for them if I had to. 

By the way, their other dim sum dishes were pretty good too!
author: Susanna C.

description:
Came here with my mom, auntie and grandparents for yum cha (Chinese version of tea) We got our number and was quickly seated since it was still early. 

The place was already crowded and the employees working there was rushing left to right. There was only three waiters,  all men rushing everywhere. 

When ask to order a take out, it came out quickly to us but when it came time to ask to refill our tea pot, every one was ignoring us. The food was decent but not a lot of variety. The bathroom upstairs was dirty. I didn't go but I heard the lady inside said the floor was wet and the toilet was dirty.

I only would come here because my grandparents wanted to come here, otherwise I wouldn't even come here. I would suggest go somewhere with better service.
author: Jen M.

description: Had dinner there with 600 relatives. The food was quite good. The place is old and grungy though. It's been here for over 40 years though.
author: Vince L.

description:
There's a pretty good reason why I give this place 5 stars.  Although I may not have consumed dim sum as others out there, I have to say that this place gets a huge high five from me.

My friend was showing me around SF Chinatown and we were actually looking for those mom 'n' pop shops, but we came to this restaurant b/c really, it's got it all.  Large eating area with carts that come up to you without waiting a second or two of what you want to choose and eat.  We got into the restaurant at noon, got seated right  away, and the waitress came within minutes to drop off our stamp card.  What's so awesome is that the carts pass by every 30 seconds you never stay empty.  I think we were in there for a total of half hour, and ate a lot.  Unfortunately, we couldn't finish everything we ordered, however, the total of probably 6 or 7 dishes came out to $28 including tax, which is a total steal!

What I found interesting about this restaurant is that most of the customers are Chinese, with a few non-Chinese, which I presume are tourists if any.

The question is, would I return back to this restaurant in the future?  By all means, a big yes~!

Overall grade: A
author: Bobby K.

description: Dim sum is not very good and I'm not even that picky of a dim sum guy. Place is also rather dirty feeling/looking.
author: Tinou B.

description: Would never come back here. They served us leftovers and charged us something didn't order. We just started eating and they asked us to pay so we did so they can close out register but they kept harassing us for tips when we were still eating. Horrible food and worse service!
author: tuan d.

description:
Another wonderful trip to New Asia. This time we brought 19 family members who were new to Dim Sum.  Our serving staff did their best to meet our needs. Everything was fresh and wonderful.  
Yes, we will come back every time we go to San Francisco.
author: greg c.

description:
My God! The Dim Sum craving is so unbearable! You would think that by being in San Fran's Chinatown you'd have a million and one dim sum places to choose from right? But NOPE! Everyone was either filled to the brim with customers or not a sit down place to eat. I wanted the whole experience. The carts, the tea, the hot Asian waiter who wants to personally feed me some Xiao Long Bao...

Finally, almost about to give up, we found "New Asia Chinese Restaurant." I was dazzled by the ceiling chandlers, so my family and I got our number (71) and played the waiting game. The lady told us "20 minutes" but we only waited for 10 at most~it was very busy, which I assume is normal for them. 

We were sat in the far back by two very kind, very loud, very annoying families. There is no leg room here for sure, they certainly tried to utilize EVERY inch of this place. What's funny is that there is a whole second floor that they don't use~they have tables up there and everything. I guess they just never thought of a good way to get carts up and down their stairs?  

Food: Their Xiao Long Bao (or soup dumplings) were meh. I personally feel that their dough was too thin because the soup kept spilling out when you picked it up. Even when I picked it up all Asian like (by pulling it by the tip and catching it with the spoon). Every other dish was pretty meh also. Some things (like their shrimp balls) tasted like they came out of a box~which they probably did. 

Service: I didn't get the hot waiter who wanted to feed me, but we did get an attitudinal Asian guy who couldn't wait to throw us in the corner and leave. What really bugs me about dim sum places are that they charge you for tea. Back in China, dim sum places are sometimes called "tea houses" where you go to drink really nice tea and eat small dishes (like dim sum). Here in the states they charge you for a 6 dollar box of tea that they got from the shop down the street from them because they can market off the tourists/off the fact that this isn't China. 

This is honestly as good as it gets in SF Chinatown. 

Our family of 6 spent 72 dollars after tax.
author: Cindy M.

description:
This dim sum is ruh-di-cu-lous.

In the heart of San Francisco's Chinatown you can walk through the gates to get to this amazing lunch spot. You may have a wait, but don't give up your meal will be worth it and the staff moves quickly. They are a well oiled machine. The dining room reminded me of my elementary school lunchroom times 5.

Seated in a giant open hall with at least 50 round tables of diners you'll need to keep your eyes peeled so that your favorite dish doesn't pass you by. 

Try everything and come hungry!
author: Sarah Rachael W.

description:
This was a place that I knew well, many many years ago. My sister had her wedding banquet her way back... and we used to go here for dim sum twice a month growing up.Twenty years or so later, my family and I were in SF and decided to do a little dim sum and decided to come here. 

Unlike many of the dim sum restaurants which now have an ordering sheet at the table (you pick out what you want and they bring it to you), New Asia is more traditional. They have dim sum in carts that come around, and you pick out what you want, and then they stamp the little piece of paper on your table. Depending on the size of the dish you ordered, as well as the price of the item, the stamp goes on a different place on the sheet. For example, there is a section for small dishes, medium size dishes, large dishes, specialty dishes, etc. Then when they ring you up, they count the number of stamps on each section to get to the final bill.

A note about this place - if you want the check - you need to flag down one of the guys in black vests. They will not always know that you want the bill, so it is better to be proactive and flag them down. If you are not Chinese, this may be considered rude behavior, but this is par for the course in a Chinese restaurant.

A second tip - if you need more water for your tea, simple open the lid of the tea pot. Someone will see that and they will come by and grab your teapot and bring it back refilled with water. This is just standard practice in a large dim sum place where they are so busy running around it might be hard to flag them down all the time.

This place is huge, and packed. Best bets if you don't want to wait in line is to go closer to 1 pm. If you go between 11:30 and 1, it's going to be crowded and you may have to wait in line.

Overall, the dim sum as you expected - some were fantastic.. others were a little greasy, but overall tasty and fresh. the steamed items were our favorites (like har gow, siu mai, flat noodles, etc.). The fried items weren't as greasy as I had expected, and were quite tasty. The BBQ pork buns can be hit or miss, and it really depends on how long they have been sitting there. In general, you can't really screw it up.

In addition to the usual dim sum items, there are a couple of carts of stuff you don't always see - one is a cart of noodles (lobster lo mein, and other fried noodles). These are more specialty dishes and are more expensive. You could probably feed 4 to 5 off one of these dishes. A second item is a porridge on a cart that comes around. Recommended if you like rice soup.

A word about service - this is a large tea house. So you can't expect top notch attentive service. If you want service, you need to flag down the carts (especially if they are going to skip your table), or the guys in the black vests for things like water, tea, your bill, etc. As long as you know to do that, service is ok.

Someone else mentioned bathrooms - first - restrooms in Chinese restaurants are usually dirty. If the restaurant is any good, they're too busy cooking and not enough time cleaning bathrooms. There is a large bathroom upstairs at the top of the stairs  for men and women. It's relatively clean by Chinese restaurant standards. There is a second uni-sex bathroom on the first floor as well, ideal for people who have trouble climbing stairs. This is a smaller one and you may have to wait to use it.

While I am at - might as well say something about parking.. first, there are a couple of garages I would park at - the Portsmouth Square garage on Kearney (between Clay and Washington) is a good choice and usually you can get a spot. The other garage I would recommend is the St Mary's Garage (on California between Kearney and Grant). There are two closer garages (the one on Pacific/Broadway between Grant and Stockton), and the one by the police station on Vallejo Street (between Mason and Stockton). I generally do not recommend because based on experience, those are usually filled up very quickly.
author: Benson C.

description: This restaurant is exactly what you would expect if you wanted to go to a traditional dim sum restaurant: Cantonese speaking, food on carts, fresh dim sum staple foods, food available to order, loud tables, banquet area. I had the duck buns, taro root cake, deep fried taro root pastry, shrimp dumplings, shu mai, Chinese broccoli, and deep fried durian pastry. All around delicious and would definitely recommend if looking for a traditional dim sum restaurant. Restrooms were decently clean and the main waiters spoke enough English to serve us.
author: Christine L.

description: We took over the entire restaurant for our wedding banquet years ago but it has since changed ownership and then GMs.  With that said, the food had gone downhill since where my dad's family association banquets have found other alternatives the past few years.  This year was the first year in quite some time that they decided to give them another chance and maybe it was because our expectations weren't all that high, but we were pleasantly surprised that the food variety seemed to have improved.  Do keep in mind though that they probably have different banquet menus to choose from.
author: Joyce Z.

description:
New Asia is by far, hands-down, the BEST dim sum restaurant in SF Chinatown. I have been frequenting this place for the past 2 decades, and am still delighted with their menu selection. Over the last couple of years, New Asia have had added a contemporary twist to their dim sum offerings, like durian pastry puffs, baked taro buns, and deep-fried lobster noodles. 

How do you tell when a dim sum joint is good? I do so by judging the patrons. If there are oodles of elder Chinese grandmas and grandpas at the dim sum joint, then the food must be good. Yes, the ones who push and yell loudly at the youngsters on the MUNI and on the street. But the reality is, they are the most picky and hard to please people in the world. They are almost never satisfied! And if Obama gets groped by a senile elder woman in a certain dim sum joint that is not New Asia, it does not mean it is good! Obama is not the taste test standard. Moreover, if the dim sum joint is filled with clueless tourists and is featured on a 7x7 article, then it may not be actually good. I hope you get my drift, because I am trying to be demure.   

Here, New Asia is filled with the rude elder Chinese grandmas and grandpas. So, by some crazy transitive property, New Asia is the best dim sum restaurant in SF Chinatown. Since all of their food is amazing, I highly recommend the whole lobster with ee mein noodles (aka first deep-fried, then pan-fried noodles in sauce) for $16. And then devouring the durian pastry puffs, taro puffs, shrimp puffs, beef balls, and pan-fried daikon cakes. 

My only complaint is that their building has aged throughout the years and that they are due to be remodeled. Oh, and last, but not least, don't expect to find any teeny-bopper dim sum girls at this place. See youtube. This place has dim sum ladies filled with sass towards their own kind, but super nice to the occasional tourists.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
This is now my favorite Dim Sum place in the city. I can't say I've explored many places, but why continue the search when I'm happy coming here? 

Highlights:
Shu mai (pork dumpling) - plump, flavorful, and includes a whole shrimp in each dumpling!
har gow (shrimp dumpling) - gigantic and includes multiple whole pieces of shrimp. Not the mashed up shrimp ball that some other places serve. 
shrimp rice flour roll - good texture with the roll, but I was never a fan of the sauce it comes in. 
steamed pork buns - ehh...I've had way better. 
stewed pork riblets - tasty! 
chinese broccoli - pretty good, but I wish they cut these up so I don't gnaw on them for hours. 
chicken feet - I can't speak from experience, but my friend says these are the best she's ever had. I don't dare go near them.

Service isn't very good, but I don't expect much. Downside would be the fact that their restrooms are upstairs. I'm just imagining how difficult it would've been for my grandma to make it up the stairs to go to the bathroom. This place is gaudy, but leaning on a tacky side. Their constant advertisements for special event booking at the restaurant on the TVs aren't very convincing. But to each their own! The place is huge though and can accommodate a lot of people.
author: Kathy T.

description: Food was ok, but I am pretty sure New Asia was the cause of severe food poisoning.  Heed the city food inspection warning.
author: S J.

description:
We came here on Sunday to have dim sum.  The place is huge and very packed.  A few items were very tasty.

siu mai - pretty good.  My husband and I usually like China Garden (Irvine) the best but their were less fatty and pretty good.

har gow - We usually don't like it cuz the skin is pretty thick but theirs were very thin and shrimp is very tasty.

chicken feet - very well braised and very tasty.  I thought it was tastier than China Garden.

Watch out for some of the waiter.  We were still waiting for a few relatives to show up but this particular waiter came by with a plate of roast spare ribs and just put it down and said it's good try it, stamped it and left.  We were like urgh, WTF just happened??  That dish was dried but has nice flavor.  We should have asked for refund.
author: Abbe W.

description: THIS PLACE SCAMS PEOPLE! we walked in and go to a table and right when we got seated we were given a pot of tea. The guy didn't say it cost anything he just put it there. So we thought like any other restaurant that it would be free BUT BOY WERE WE WRONG. The tea costs freaking $5.50!!!!!!! So we decided to finish the tea BUT THE TES WASNT EVEN GOOD!!!!!! DEFINITELY NOT COMING BACK!!!!
author: Laura K.

description:
Came here for dimsum on Sunday afternoon, the place was packed, even for 1:30....after spending over 45 minutes in traffics due to fleet week, we were famished....

My friends already had a table set up so all we had to do was order off the carts...we ordered almost everything that came by...this time I didn't do the durian puffs because I had enuf of durian mooncakes last month...

Great bbq dishes, much more expensive than other restaurants but that is because the Hong Kong chef they have in the bbq section knows exactly what he is doing.....
author: Leslie Y.

description:
If you know me, you know I dread eating at Chinese restaurants. That being said, I would actually come back here to get some Chinese grub.

I was a little frustrated going in on a Monday afternoon to find it packed despite this restaurant being huge and having many tables. We had to get a number and wait to be called. Fortunately, people waiting were called in fast and we didn't have to wait long to be seated. This place is so packed that everything can seem disorderly and rushed. We even asked for a fork during our meal and the waiter must have forgotten to get back to us in all the semi-chaos. This place is pretty loud and since it is crowded you might be sitting in the midst (warning to any claustrophobic people) of many Asians chattering about loudly. And we never got our fork(s). Oh well.

Anyways, I do love me some dim sum, and boy, this is the place for dim sum. I really like the style of this restaurant, everything is brought around in carts and you can choose what you want rather than ordering off a menu (or the mix of both ordering from a menu and a dim sum cart going around). I'm a little iffy when it comes to steamed/sauteed Chinese broccoli since most Chinese restaurants don't steam/cook it enough to make it not as hard. The Chinese broccoli here was cooked very well. Not hard at all. There's definitely still somewhat of a crunch but it's not like you're chewing rocks or something. The dim sum here was just near-perfectly done. I could actually go for some more right now. I'm not going to go into detail of each kind of dim sum I had since it'll probably be tedious for both me and you. It's good. Get yourself some and see for yourself.
author: Julia N.

description:
Went here twice during our San Fran trip. Ambiance is awesome and reminds me of being in Asia where I lived. Standard cart ladies making their rounds pushing each of their fares on you. If you haven't been to dim sum don't feel bad about sternly saying NO to things. Ask them to show you everything they have and pick and choose. No one will take it personally if you say no and you should otherwise they will throw lots of stuff at you and I guarantee some of it you won't like. On that note don't hesitate to explore some new flavors and again don't feel bad if you take one bite and leave the rest. 

As others have said the staff doesnt speak much english so basic hand signs and pointing works well enough. Its part of the experience! And also the bathrooms need some attention so use them somewhere elsw bwfore you arrive. Overall would go back any time in San fran. There is a parking garage right next door.
author: Vince R.

description:
Okay, most restaurants in Chinatown have become so touristy that none of the locals eat around here anymore. The same goes for all the dimsum places. THIS place, I hope it keeps its 3 star rating because this place is the best and I don't want tourists to come here. But then I guess I shouldn't write this review.

Pros:
-This place is HUGE. But it's still super crowded--we came at 10AM and I'd say 75% of the restaurant are full (I'm guessing this place can easily sit 300-400 people?). 
-Dimsum is LEGIT.

Cons:
-This is really good if you have big parties since it can accommodate that but you'll still need to haul your ass here early. Don't be dumb and come at 12:15
author: Diana Y.

description:
I will keep this short...

The food is mediocre at best is overstating. The rice wrappings are consistently soggy and fall apart as soon as you try to take it out of the steam tray. The food lacks in flavor and quality. 

Wait is tolerable, cart service is repetitive and lackluster, I swore I saw the same dish circle half a dozen times and pretty certain it was cold around lap 2.

Overall Thoughts

Word of advice, Don't come to Chinatown for Chinese food...ironic I know but the food is seriously not worth the trip despite some extremely rare exceptions..it overall is tragic!
author: Eddie W.

description:
My parents and relatives love to drag me to this restaurant. Their food is bland, their shrimp dumplings fall apart easily (overcooked? or overwatered dough? Who knows), their buns are mushy, it's nothing special to write home about. 

Crowded as hell because all the asians in Chinatown like to go here and of course instead of seating everyone else in the upper floor which they leave totally empty they decided to instead have a huge crowd of people waiting in the front, overfilling the "lobby" and spilling into the street, blocking the sidewalk so pedestrians are forced to jaywalk to get around them. Madness.

Maybe my review is a little biased from seeing a waiter place a tray of condiments on the filthy floor, idk. The floor looked like it had never been washed since Chinatown was first constructed. 

Attached is a picture http://s3-media4.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/BrZLFFbDKFwJx1qyg2odKw/l.jpg for your own opinion. Note the crusty brown stuff caked on the floor by the railing. Nasty. :( No wonder their health score is so low...
author: Kay D.

description: First time eating at a Dim Sum restaurant and it was goodie good good. Super busy we waited about 10-15mins, it went by quick cz the lady calling out the numbers made me laugh... Sounded like she was mad & shit.. "NUMBA ATE! NUMBA ATE!" Lol that was entertaining. Anywho the food was great especially their water... It wasn't no tap water for sure :)
author: Maridel A.

description:
This is one of the few restaurants in Chinatown that still pushes Dim Sum carts around.  It seems Dim Sum carts are a dying tradition and restaurants now want you to order off the menu and they deliver it.

The food was good, the service was what you would expect in this type restaurant.

I gave the restaurant 4 stars since they value is good and they still have the old school carts.
author: Jeff C.

description:
2 1/2 stars

The ladies carting the dim sum around did not stop much at our table. We had to flag a waiter down to order a combo chow mein dish, $13. Most of the dishes were consider large, $4.50. Medium dishes are $3.50. They charge $1 for tea/person.
Did not order more than 1/2 dozen dishes, typical sui mai, ha gow, fun gor, rice roll noodle w/ spare ribs [we thought it would be beef],  hom sui gok and it cost over $44 for 3 people. This is not much food.

No cha sui bao, no don tat, woo gok (taro), - not much of a selection to choose from.

Table was dirty. Bathroom are upstairs &  nasty. Customer service is none. 

It used to be called Asia Gardens - seems like the quality has gone downhill.

Not impressed.
author: Sukkau S.

description: I recently went for dim sum with a friend and the food wasn't good and was bland. Also note that the food took a very long time to come out of the kitchen. They all have a bad attitude when serving/speaking to the both of us and when we got the bill, it was $65. 2 people. $65 for bad dim sum. Also note that when you pay they only give you the bill and now the breakdown of the food you had. The next day we called them to ask for the menu and the prices to try to figure out why it costed $65. They proceeded to hang up on us two times. This is not only disrespectful but not acceptable for restaurant staff. Will never be returning.
author: Tesia C.

description:
Health Department need to shut them down till they remodel the ladies room which is a health hazard as I see it.
I have been to the New Asia for many events.
Recently we got there on a night when the floor was full of
dancing couples and line dancers having a great time.
Just don't go to the bathroom upstairs, it is in need up dating for toilet plumbing.
author: Sandy D.

description: Very bad service. Very rude also. Never sit in the back. You can never get service if you do. Got a table for 7 people. Left us here without tea or anything.  Asked them to get us tea. Waited for about 45minutes and no one came with tea at all. I have to say the food is good, but service ia horrible.
author: Miranda K.

description:
Their dim sum dishes are really bad, but their dinner entrees are pretty good!  

I have went here countless of times for dim sum, dinners and wedding banquets.  I must say that the place has gradually became less glamorous and more of the rundown places to go to in Chinatown!  

When I was a kid, I thought this place displayed China's modern extravagance on fine dining with their high ceilings, chandeliers. big layout, and good-sized dance floor.  Now, the layout from the furniture to the seats has been overused and outdated.  Daily customers for dim sum seem to have become more senior as well so the quality and taste of their food has become more bland.

Servers don't care that you will be enjoying the experience.  They want you to go eat and  head out quickly so they can seat others.

This place would only get 1 star for their dim sum dining and add those 2 stars for their good dinner and banquet food.

Final say: Skip the brunch for dim sum and go for dinners or wedding banquets!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Terrible service, mediocre food

Food is just mediocre here for dim sum. Terrible wait service though. I was seated on the upper level with my relatives. Maybe it was cause it was Sunday. Maybe because it was around noon so it was a busy hour. Or maybe they should be more attentive and prepared to deal with such a large amount of customers. My uncle had to get his own chopsticks, napkins and chair.. We ran out of seating because our party came in different times. We told them to add 2 more seats but they disregarded our needs. I think by the time we waited for the waiters to serve us, we would've been done eating already.. Also it took them FOREVER to clear the dishes off our lazy susan.. Piles and piles of empty plates started to pile up. Where were the waiters? NO WHERE TO BE FOUND. The food wasn't great enough for me to want to come back especially with customer service like this..
author: Virginia Y.

description: If you're looking for good dimsum and lots of choices, this is the place for you! I love the food and coming here with friends. They have big tables if you have a bunch of people coming so that's wonderful! If you're looking for a quiet place with quick service, this isn't for you to be honest though. It's definitely loud and with the number of servers they have, you do have to flag someone down if you want more food or the check. On the plus side, if you've got time and you just want something casual, I definitely suggest trying it!
author: Stephanie R.

description:
8 dishes 4 people $56 + tip
Ha gau
Sau mi
Sticky rice
Deep fried lobster ball
Chicken feet
Gai lan oyster sauce
Fried turnip cake

Food 3 yelp
Service 3 yelp
Cleanliness 1 yelp
Value 2 yelp
author: Ed D.

description:
Holy hell this is actually the worst dim sum I've had in years, I don't know how people can eat here. I assume its the large amounts of space this restaurant holds. Its absurd how many people are here. 

Tea: I ordered hot water, out came hot water in a teapot with left over chrysanthemum leaves. I mean it shouldn't be too hard to just rinse out the leaves with water but oh well. 

Food: Bland. Tasteless. Stale (for a lack of better wording). Shrimp dumplings were mushy and broken up. BBQ pork buns were cold. Pork dumplings just tasted a bit off. 

All in all, I just personally couldn't take it. I'm usually fine with bustling crowds, loud mcs reading off numbers, and rolling carts calling out food, but today just felt wrong.
author: Benny L.

description:
One word: Yuck. 

We were seated upstairs and the place was packed so we thought it was a decent place. We were quite wrong. The place is dirty. The tables are filthy.  The servers were out right rude. The ladies who pushed the carts spoke no English. It took some assertiveness to get forks and water. One of the waiters waived us off twice and muttered in a foreign language when we asked him for water. BUT he was quick when he saw we were ready to pay! 

Will never come here again.
author: Youa L.

description: All I can say is worst dim sum ever! Came here since it was the of to place when I was a kid. Well that sadly changed dramatically! It was busy, there was a wait at 1 on a Sunday. Bathrooms were pretty disgusting, dirty & muggy. Our table was dirty. Wait staff ignores you & attitude. Look, I'm no rookie. We're old school Chinese so we don't play that! Food was mediocre. Well, pretty bad actually. Not many choices & what we had we didn't want anymore! Embarrassed that this place serves such crap. What a shame. Search continues for worthy dim sum. Don't waste your time or money. The high reviews must be from young non-Chinese folk. My mom makes her own dumplings from scratch, potstickers, tamales so believe me when I say this food is less than sub par!
author: Jules K.

description:
While my dim sum repertoire may not be as sophisticated and well versed as some, I can quite confidently say that New Asia is a two star experience. You would assume walking up to this place that with the amount of people waiting to dine here that the food would be out of this world, We waited 45 minutes for a party of 3 on a weekday around 1:00pm. 
By the time our number was called we were all STARVING - we were sat and our tea was served pretty fast, but thats when it all went down hill! We could not get a cart to serve us food to save our lives, when we finally got one to come over we literally took whatever we could, simply because we were scared that if we turned her away we might be waiting another 30 minutes for a cart to come by us! I get that it was 1:00pm but they were out of EVERYTHING - pork buns were no where to be found! We ordered some roasted duck and while it was flavorful, it was mostly bones and very little meat. The carts all seemed to be serving the same thing, noodles, toro buns and well more noodles! Dumplings were pretty difficult to locate, which seriously, it's dim sum not oodles of noodles! 
Service was crappy - but I am finding out pretty quickly that that's a pretty standard practice and their establishment was kinda sketchy as well.... It hadn't looked like it had been cleaned in years. There has to be better in San Francisco and if this is the best the city has to offer, then well we're screwed!
author: Roxy H.

description: Dim Sum is just average. I was expecting better dim sum and food quality for such a big restaurant.
author: ZhiCheng Z.

description:
Full disclosure, I have a serious thing for dumplings.

I'd been wanting to get dim sum since I moved here a few weeks ago and luckily had a friend willing to go on a china town adventure with me last Sunday.  We stumbled into New Asia after a few failed attempts at finding a true dim sum place.  I mean how hard is it for a girl to get ladies with carts, a man with a mic yelling numbers and some flashy red LED chandeliers!?  Luckily for me, New Asia delivered on everything I wanted and more!  It was like a dream, fully equipped with shiny gold pillars to boot!

We got 500% too much food, including (but not limited to) pork buns, taro cake, soup dumplings, shu mai, and shrimp bao.  Everything was so delicious we really tried to eat it all.  And even with all the leftovers our total bill was about $30.  Can't beat that for great food in SF.  Will definitely be back once I'm ready for my next dumping feast.

#dumplingsfordays
author: Lindsey G.

description:
Despite it's name, this place is pretty old.. Chairs are worn down. Tables are raggedy. Don't even get me started with the bathrooms. But to be honest, I've seen worse ESP in Chinatown (aka land of cheap authentic eats and pushy grandmas). 

Although it's a big venue, the place still gets packed on weekends at 11-1PM. Seems popular for tourists and old Asian crews - in a couple of decades, I suppose I'll be a member of the latter. 

The food is hit-or-miss. Don't get the shrimp w/ veggie dumplings because the skin falls apart. The siu long bao (soup dumplings) didn't have much flavor either so I drowned it in vinegar. However, I did enjoy the dan tat (egg tarts) and the taro filled bun. The har gow (shrimp dumpings) and siu mai (pork dumplings) were just ok, but if a dimsum place gets those wrong, they're done for.

Service could be better but it wasn't awful. You must be proactive in getting your dimsum from the carts because the ladies will not come to you, but eventually you start seeing the same dishes going around and around anyway. If this place wasn't as cheap as it is, I'd probably go elsewhere.
author: Ashley L.

description:
Came here for lunch noticing a lot of people here. Thought we'd give it a shot! 
I'd never had Dim Sum before and loved the idea of just picking things as they come by. My friend and I had Chicken Spring Rolls, Steamed Pork Buns, Chow Mein, Roasted Half Duck, Honey BBQ Pork, Wontons with Sweet Sour Soup, and Potstickers. Everything we ate had great flavor and the only thing not hot at our table was the Potstickers. Definite perk of being by the kitchen exit was having first pick of whatever just came out most of the time. 
Dishes that were definitely highlights were the Honey BBQ Pork, Wontons, and Chow Mein. I think the Chow Mein was some of the best I've had! 
The Spring Rolls were the only thing I didn't care too much for. They were a lot of wrapper, not too much filling. Great crunch, just would have liked more filling. 
The service was okay. They were quick with trays. It did take us a little bit to get water and spicy mustard. A waiter also came up to us towards the end and made us feel like he was rushing us out. 
Overall, a good place for our lunch and we left stuffed!
author: Kristin F.

description: We came for dim sum on Mother's Day and it was pretty solid. I lived the har gow which were stuffed full of shrimp and the shumai. The jelly fish was just okay and the gai lan was slightly greasy. The seating is extremely crowded and not very organized but this us Chinatown so that wasn't really expected. Overall a decent option.
author: Danan R.

description:
I'll start by saying that I will not return here. I suppose the food must be good, because people were dining. Perhaps everyone is high. 

We arrived at the end of lunch. We were forced into a seat and overwhelmed with food and no menu or reasonable explanation. Everything was COLD. Well, except the tea. 

The food was mostly fatty meats and oily veggies. Sad to say that I left hungry because I was so grossed out. 

When the check came, we were forced to pay quickly because the rude server was in a rush to go home. 

Okay, so. Won't be returning.
author: Tim L.

description:
This place was quite a hike if you're coming from the BART station; it was almost at the end of Chinatown.  I was hoping that it was well worth the walk but unfortunately, it didn't.

Although the Crispy Shrimp Balls were huge, the "crispy" part was stale.  Both the Shumai and Soup Dumplings fell apart easily and tasted bland. The egg pastry was more egg than pastry so the taste wasn't quite right to me.  The only thing I liked was the Eggrolls until we got a 2nd order.  The same lady that served and cut our eggrolls was the same lady that was cleaning the dirty dishes... EWWW!!!  Plus the service was lousy, more so than others.  I asked for my Sticky Rice in Lotus Leaf, they nodded and said "okay" but they never came back with it.  The place was practically empty but they took forever on getting us food and water.  They also give you tea which I assumed was complimentary since I didn't ask for it, but they charged us $1/person.  Lastly, they hovered over me when they gave me the receipt to sign.  Awkward much?

I would like to give them the benefit of doubt when it comes to the quality of food since we did come in at 2pm (almost the end of dim sum) and that all dim sum places were like that, but I like to think that a good/great restaurant makes the same quality of food no matter what time it is (opening or closing).  Maybe that's just wishful thinking.  I was about to give them 2 stars because I wouldn't mind coming back to give them another chance until I got my 2nd order of eggrolls.  I was keeping an eye on that lady since I saw she was wiping the dirty dishes and she would serve other customers without washing her hands!  I'm definitely not keen on coming back for a 2nd visit, no thank you.
author: Deana M.

description:
I've been going here since I was a little girl, and it seems like the majority of people here are not tourists, but chinese people. I am a huge fan of dimsum so I love this place.  Because I'm not chinese, I have to rely on looking at every thing in the cart and grunting and pointing like a dumbass to get what I want.

Sure, the place is super crowded, sure sometimes I've sat with strangers at the same table, sure it's super loud, but uhhhhhhhh who cares. Everybody is friendly though.  Sometimes the carts coming to you is a hit or miss, sometimes you get them coming to you constantly, sometimes hardly any at all. Either way i've never had a bad experience.

My favorite thing is: shrimp dumplings and the chicken feet. I have NEVER left this place without getting those. YUM YUM.
author: Meena N.

description: We came here for a wedding banquet dinner.  A-ok solid Chinese food -- our faves were the fish, beef, scallops and broccoli and shrimp with walnuts.  The lobster was a bit hard to dig out the shell.  Service was a-ok, very diligent in clearing the table.  They have a spacious stage and dance floor perfect for karaoke and dancing with your group of friends.
author: Maile N.

description:
This review is strictly for their WEEKDAY DINNER.

DON'T EVER. and I mean EVER come here for dinner on Tues-Thursdays from 5pm-10pm. Unless you're tone-deaf. Or deaf. Just don't come. 

It started with a family meal (plus the boyfriend) visiting my grandmother for dinner. Our usual place seemed closed, so we came here per her request. We've come here for the dim sum before, so we know it's not terrible.

Thank goodness the boyfriend reads(+speaks) Chinese, since they had a sign in Chinese that said something along the lines of dancing from 7pm to 10pm, Tues-Thurs. We figured no big deal, it was 5pm and we figured we'd be out by 6:30 at the latest since it was literally empty. We asked, and they said they would serve us, so we sat down.

And then it started...25 minutes later. Next thing you know the projector on the wall is showing oldschool chinese songs, KARAOKE style. Can you just imagine trying to enjoy a family dinner with TONE-DEAF SENIORS belting out with no care in the world. My Chinese-American (aka we-only-know-English-regrettably) family cringed at the bad singing, but my poor boyfriend, had to endure both the bad singing and butchering of songs he knew. And this started WAY before the advertised 7pm-10pm "Dance".

Oh yeah and the food was decent. Same-o, Same-o. Honestly I can't remember the food, but the experience was unforgettable.

 But if you have grandparents that like to dance, this place opens their dance floor and the seniors get down with the waltzing.
author: Jenna H.

description:
If it is possible to rate no stars, I would. I walked in with my 16mo. Both him and I were getting hungry. The waiter seated us on the side aisle at a table for four but can only fit two because the placement of the other tables were so close together. I asked for a high chair and he came back with a 1940s high with no security strap. Best of all, the tray table was taped together with duck tape. I understand duck tapes are very strong but I didnt need my son to start peeling the germs off of it so I decided not to use it and just sat him in a regular chair.

We waited for the dim sum cart to come by and they just kept going up and down the center aisle or they would finally get close to us but turn back. We weren't even seated in the corner so I didnt understand how they can miss us. 
Finally one cart came by and we ordered two things off that cart. Considering my son only has eight teeth, I'm limited to what I can order. Him and I started eating the Siu Mai dumpling, and while he was eating it, I kept my eye out for another cart. Again, they never turn to get to our aisle. When he was done with his dumpling, he started getting fussy. I tried to wave down those carts but no one seem to care to pay enough attention. Finally a grandma asked why am I not ordering my son any food. Well geee, I am trying here. So she helped me wave someone down. Fortunately for me, the only cart that would come by was the same cart we originally ordered from. So off the ten carts I saw wheeling by, only one came to us. I packed my bags and my son and paid. Before I can even get my son strapped on me, the bus boy had already clean my table. I am Asian and I know the culture but that was very rude. I almost left without putting down a tip. 

I can't even rate and focus on the quality of food because I didn't have any. So I paid $11.25 for two tiny tapas and we walked out hungry still.
author: Jane A.

description:
Oh my dim sum! We all had been craving dim sum and were not sure where to go this weekend.  We happened to be on the corner of Pacific and one of our party happened to recall being there before.  We quickly jumped on reviews on our phones and saw the comments.
New Asia is a hopping place.  Sei sahp bhat (#48) came rapidly and we did not have to wait long. 
I of course wanted to say yes to every single cart and every steamer box that passed us.  We loved the taro buns, steamed pork buns, and many various items I cannot even name. The staff are great and show up just when you need to call for more.
It was around noon on a Saturday and of course because of the holiday there were loads of tourists in Old Chinatown, but the crowd moves so well and the organization is good.
This is now our dim sum place.  Way to go!!
author: Ellen O.

description:
Came here for dinner with the family, and the food itself was quite good! Got the chicken in black bean sauce, sweet and sour fish fillet, beef with scallion and ginger, chow fun, salt and pepper calimari, and egg rolls. The tea (was supposed to be oolong) was SUPER concentrated--almost as if it had been out for a while and had been left to steep. The rice, too, was hard (like they didn't fluff it and just took the top part). Servers were nice enough and brought the food in a timely manner.

3 stars because they didn't honor the price listed on the menu (the dishes were almost $3 more than what was listed). Very misleading.
author: Victoria W.

description: When a restaurant is nearly empty on a Saturday night, there is probably a good reason.  (spoiler alert!  mediocre food in dingy environs.)
author: Amy C.

description:
This is the worst Chinese restaurant on the planet!  

First the service was crap.  The lady told us to go upstairs for any table. My family and I sat down at a fairly large table. A waiter came our way and yelled at us for sitting at a large table.  He demanded that we take a smaller table. My mother insisted that the lady downstairs said that we could sit anywhere but he did not care. 

We moved to a smaller table and the same yelling waiter had to serve us. Then, I found my reason why I will never step foot in this place again.  My brother proceeded to poor soy sauce and out comes a FLY.  A FLY.  Should a fly be in soy sauce?  I told the waiter and he was extremly indifferent and didn't replace the soy sauce.  So I lived without soy sauce.

Food was no better.  Too much MSG, too much sauce, too much crap.  I would expect this stuff if it was cheap but it wasn't.  

When the waiter came by with our check, he wanted to take our cash (we wanted $10 back) so he would give it to the cashier.  I made sure his fingers didnt' touch my money and went direclty to the cashier.  The waiter continued to follow me downstairs to the cashier.  I asked for the manager and the cashier said he wasn't there.  I told the cashier about the soy sauce and how I would report it to the health department and our crappy waiter.  I kid you not, she dared us to send it to the health department.  Hopefully this place will shut down and this waiter never finds another job.  I feel sorry for Californians that have to deal with this place.  

NEVER AGAIN.
author: Nicky C.

description: Overall, I was impressed with this restaurant. It's a very casual atmosphere, with great food. I would recommend the BBQ pork buns, the egg tart, and the shrimp dumplings. Honestly though, they have a lot of great options! Service isn't the greatest, but a good option for affordable dim sum
author: Andrew L.

description:
NEVERRRR will I ever come here again!
DONT GO HERE!!  Youre better off going to the fruit stands with the flies flying all over the fruits


Took my family (6 people) here on a weekday for some DimSum. Although we're not Chinese (still asian), they just looked at us at the front and ignored us a few times. Fine, theyre busy, but with more than half the tables open??

We finally get seated. The host let us sit without asking us what kind of tea we wanted or if we wanted water. The ladies pushing the carts slowly came around to giving us options on DimSum. Food was cold!  The chicken feet oil was coagulated! I asked the waiters to get this heated up, then 2-3 guys talked amongst themselves in their language. They finally brought back the dish hot.  But a few other dishes were still not warm.... food was a 1-2 on a scale of 1-10, with 10 being good.  We asked for red vinegar for dipping purposes and they only gave us ONE small dish when we had 6 in our party. We asked for more and the lady gave us only one more. Like reeeeeally?????  So from here, they started giving us attitude and threw dishes on our table to a point some things spilled!  UNACCEPTABLE!

When we asked them to calculate the bill, the guy gave me back the bill and stood there next to our table waiting for the money.  I told him, please give us a few minutes.  3-5 mins passed and he came back, and I told him it wasnt ready. So he came back again 2 mins later, and one person in our group needed change, so the waiter gave us a big puff of "ugh"..... I stood up and said "WHOA!... Let me talk to your manager"  He got scared and apologized.... I let it go, but saw him smiling at the register.  Soon as he came back, I gave him the paid amount in cash.... you wont believe what he did next...........


He literally stood there in front of me, counting each bill!  HOW RUDE!!!!!!!



NEVERRRRR WILL I COME BACK HERE!
If I could give a zero rating, I would
author: Mike V.

description: I would never recommend this place. Dont let this place influence you decision of a dim sum restaurant. They were very dirty and the food was horrible, compared to any other places around the bayarea. The prices was the same as a higher end dim sum restaurant. This place is a no no for me. Tourists dont let this place fool you, places in ssf, milbrae are far far better.
author: Ru L.

description:
I'm pretty mixed about New Asia having came here several years ago before I moved to SF.  It thought their Dim Sum was delicious although they're missing some things that I like such as stuffed eggplant and tau foo far with the lovely syrup.  And I've always loved their roast duck (very crispy) and char siu (not sweet and sticky).  However, after having moved here and been a few times during week days and weekends I've been able to discern some quality concerns about this place.

First of all, it's safe to say that their seafood is not the freshest (i.e. the har gao and shumai) and it's definitely worse during the weekends.  The last time I went there for lunch back in the summer, my tummy was not happy about it.

I was seated at a table by the stairs with a pile of dirty dishes and feeling icked out by the look of the floors.  And when I asked the waiter for a plate of roast duck, one nodded and never brought it.  Another said, "We're out.." - dude really? It's 2PM and you're out of roast duck? You should close your shop at this point.

And when I paid the lady at the register snapped, "no tip?" I said I left it at the table then she does that forced insincere smile, "oh thank you thank you".  Whatever old bag.

Eat at your own risk!
author: Favoloso M.

description:
Love this place because of one thing: they have Poh Tat!!!

Poh Tat is like a cousin of Don Tat (Egg Tart). The difference is that Poh Tat is more creamy than the customary egg tart that everyone normally eats. It has a less dense texture for the cream and it is sometimes runny, which I think is really good. It is kind of like the difference between the Lai Wong Bao and the Lau Sah Bao. (Steamed egg custard buns). If you are chinese then you know what I'm talking about... and if you are not... well too bad =]

The rest of their dim sum is pretty good also, but maybe a bit more pricey than other places, but it is worth it. The place is pretty big and pretty clean and organized. They have a lot of carts running around all the time with excellent dim sum, and what more can you ask for?

Remember to spot out the cart with the poh tat and give it a try! It's a different taste and you may end up loving it!
author: Benjamin W.

description:
We like New Asia and it's so convenient, but they ARE SO RUDE and if you get sit in the back you never get served.

The pot stickers and dan tat are delicious - everything else is mediocre. We always did Dim Sum here, but there are so many great dim sum spots that are clean, nice and cheaper that it's not worth the wait, broken tables, rude service and dirty glasses.
author: Francesca F.

description:
Did someone say Dim Sum?! Let's meet at New Asia! 

 I've been told that this place is a bit touristy but I disagree. What sets it apart from most other chinese restaurants that you may find in the area, is that it is HUGE and still fairly clean! It was designed for banquet sized events such as weddings.   This place has TWO levels. When they have tons of people they open up the second floor for customers to sit at and eat.  

 The food is absolutely delicious! The size of each item is oversized! You know you are getting your money's worth when you come here.   

The little old chinese ladies are super friendly when they come by on their carts asking what you want to eat. If you speak canto, they are pretty fun to talk with while they are grabbing a steamer of food for you and stamping your card.   

The only unfortunate part of this huge place, is the second floor. If you get there too late and get the boot the second floor, you are in a world of loneliness. They have to turn on the kitchen on the second floor, and re-organize the staff to accommodate both floors. So sometimes, the second floor gets ignored a bit. They won't necessarily pre-make all the stuff already prepared for the first floor. So you'll have to flag someone down to get what you want if you can't find it on the carts.
author: Jess G.

description: Found this place on Yelp while visiting China Town with the family. Decent spot and has been around for years. It has the traditional carts that come around every 30 seconds. We had the pork buns (highly recommend), chinese broccoli (just the right amount of oyster sauce drizzled), salted fish fried rice (was okay, not my favorite), and the fried shrimp balls( tons of shrimp and crispy). On a side note, the shrimp balls that come on the cart will cost you a whopping $15! Yup, they don't tell you but the plate comes 3 orders and you don't even know it until it's time to pay. Oh well, the food was good, but $70 was pretty steep for 3 people for some Dim Sum.
author: Jennifer A.

description: Remember coming her as a kid when it was known as Asia Garden and is now known as New Asia from about a decade ago, my parents still refer it to the old name. Came here for dim sum with my friends and we were quickly seated at the stage area. It took forever to get a waiters attention for our tea and the dim sum ladies bypassed our table many times. So we got the managers attention to move to another part of the restaurant. The food here is pretty good when it comes to dim sum. We got usual spare ribs, shrimp dumplings, beef rolls, chicken feet, shiu mai, and beef balls. I would have to say this place has the worst service out of all the restaurants in Chinatown where the waiter demanded 15% tip when we were leaving which the service here was not acceptable. I would only come here as a fact that it is one of the few tea houses left in Chinatown and there is limited options.
author: Peter C.

description:
Bomb !!

Dim sum is amazing ..

Shrimp hai gow .. Perfect 
Sticky rice - great 
Shrimp rice noodle - perfect 
Black bean and pork - great 

Tea was good 

Service is good 

Huge place 

Not at all expensive
author: Faith C.

description:
I don't know which was the best part of this experience. Was it waiting for my number to be called or was it the food. This place gets really packed. When we got there we were given number 13 and they were only on number 56. The lady screams out the numbers, if only one could understand what she was saying. We had to wait about 30 minutes to be seated but it was well worth it. 

Once seated the carts with Dim Sum fly around you every few seconds. Don't even think about thinking about if you want a dish or not, if you look interested before you can say yes or no its on your table. The veggies are great, and the desserts were yummy. 

All in all it was great Dim Sum, I would return again. My ears were ringing for a few hours after from the loud number calling, but then again thats what makes it a fun time.
author: Victor W.

description: Very old school yumcha place. You have the tiger mum hostess yelling through the loud speaker, less than sanitary table cloths and chairs. The portions though are "American" size and great value. Couldn't ask for more really. The food was tasty, tea was traditional, good vibes, this is what your grandma or mum would expect out of a yumcha place. Ain't nobody got time for that fancy yumcha.
author: John J.

description:
Boyfriend and I went here for "yum cha" last weekend.

It was pretty good. It's a little expensive, but OK. The ha gao (shrimp dumplings) and siu mai (pork tumplings are very good. Everything else was OK - food was room temperature.
