author: Kathryn Y.

description:
Was in the City with Stormy recently for a few days R&R and asked one of the locals (Asian) where to go for good Dim Sum. We wanted to try someplace different as we've been eating DS around the City for the past 30 years. He said try New Asia. Its where his family eats.
We did.
I think that besides Stormy and I there was one other white person in the entire place. This was the first good sign. The second was the place was huge and full, all during a Tuesday morning at 10AM. We got in right away but just barely.
NA did not disappoint.The BBQ pork buns (both baked and steamed) were easily the best I've ever eaten being tender puffs. We also had a sticky rice with Chinese sausage wrapped in some sort of leaf thing that was great.
Lots of folks complain about the price here but Stormy and I got out stuffed for what we pay to go to our local breakfast place at home.

Recommended for a slice of something exotic in SF
author: Duane H.

description: I went to this place for a fundraiser. I wasn't expecting it to be as large as it was inside, so it's great for banquets.  Parking might be a hassle but they have a parking lot on the same block.  I expected it to be more of a dim-sum place.  While the people at my table seemed to love the food, I think I've had better.  Still, if you love Chinese food and are in the area and especially if you have a large party, you should give it a try.
author: a f.

description: It was the worst dining experience I've ever had in San Francisco. Some of the dishes we had was cold, but it was not a big deal until we saw a freaking guest cockroach on the wall crawling toward our table, aggressively as if it knows this place so well. Besides, the front desk bill collector was unbelievably rude. She was bothered to separate our bills and forced us to pay more tips indicated on the receipt after the crappy dining experience. ( p.s. Her makeup was too bizarre for her age). Anyway, you probably don't wanna go there if you don't wanna get pissed off.
author: Lucy F.

description:
The place opens at 10am on the weekdays and has a bunch of people waiting outside when it does. The place isn't that clean and has a bunch of people using it for a coffee shop. The locals just sit around ordering a few plates and sit for a few hours drinking tea. 

The food is decent, just not great. The restroom is nasty..
author: M C.

description:
This place has to be good when at 10:00 AM on a Tuesday it is packed to the brim right? 

Well, that was my friend's experience coming in from ATX to visit some friends. We got there at opening and it quickly got packed.

Service is impeccable as the people on the carts come by quickly and often.  The decor and ambiance brings back waves of childhood nostalgia as, there really isn't anything like that in ATX.

The food is actually not that special, as I've had better in Houston but coming from Austin, this was like a banquet. We got deep fried shrimp balls, har gao, shiu mi, potstickers, beef cheung fun, shrimp cheung fun,  rice noodles with pork, char siu bao, lo mai gai, chicken feet, some sort of special har gao, egg tarts. Nothing was bad that's for sure, but nothing stood out as particularly special either, which as a chinese person, that's 4 stars.

There's a lot of dim sum places in SF china town as I perused about, but this one is definitely something to keep in mind if and when I come back.
author: Wayne N.

description:
Complete uncontrolled chaos at 11am on Mothers Day Sunday morning. 
Seriously out of control. 
Plates clanking.
People yelling to hear each other. 
The lady calling out the next available table numbers. Shouting herself hoarse. 
Questionably undercooked xiao long bao dumplings. I couldn't eat any after the first one. 
Shrimp dumplings were good. 
Raised my blood pressure. 
Wanted to run out of the place like I was running away from a monster chasing me. 
Everybody else in the place seemed to think everything was pretty normal going ons.
author: Kev M.

description:
DIM SUM! I don't even know what else they have here (probably chinese food haha) but I only come for Dim Sum. This place is HUGE! But always so packed! Came on a Saturday afternoon with 6 other friends and though it was packed, we got seated shortly. Went through the drill - poured tea and sipped it as we waited for the ladies to pass by with their cart's full of deliciousness. Pretty much got everything that passed by. We missed a few carts a few times from stuffing our faces, but they pretty much go in circles so we knew we would eventually catch them again. Even if you don't know Chinese (which I do BTW haha) pointing at the thing you want will do. 

DELICIOUS! Left stuffed and only about $10 a person including tip! 

Trust me. I'll be back!
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Old school dim sum place with trolleys going around the restaurant. Taste was good but agree that some food was slightly cold when we arrived around 2pm. Go early and be ready to line up. 

Big restaurant and good for larger groups in comparison to the small hole in the walls scattered around Chinatown. These may have better dim sum but hard to go to if you want to sit down.
author: Lotta Y.

description:
I went here with my family for a late lunch, so there were only a few tables and maybe only about 3 carts being pushed around. We ordered about 4 plates of cherng fun (cha siu cherng is my favorite), a small plate of duck, 2 plates of buns, a plate of vegetables and tofu...about a dozen small plates in all. 

Compared to dim sum in New York, the flavors were somewhat bland. Despite the fact that the restaurant was practically empty, the waiters were very "busy." They accidentally gave us boiled water instead of tea, and when we told them this they didn't immediately exchange it. Instead, we waited about 5 minutes until a waiter came back and took it away, and another 5 minutes until we finally got tea. The workers pushing the carts around also had a tendency to leave them sitting around. I could have taken some free plates of dim sum. An abandoned cart with hot dim sum also started rolling and almost hit my mom. 

When the bill came, it was ridiculously expensive. About $70 (with tip) for about a dozen small plates?! You can get more dim sum for $30 in NY. I wonder how they would handle a full restaurant in the mornings, though with such expensive prices and lack of good service I wouldn't come back.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
xiao long bao- horrible. this is my favorite chinese dish and I could only eat two of them out of the six given. The inside was mushy. I couldn't take them out of the box without breaking them because they stuck together/to the paper bottom.

dumplings- thick wrapping, too much vegetable filling. I couldn't finish this dish either

har gow- good. the wrapping fell apart very quickly on all of mine. (I guess this is a good thing bc I like soft)

pork shumai- okay. pork shumai is hard to mess up. 

shrimp flat noodle- delish!

chinese broccoli- pretty good. crunchy

duck- good taste. I just wish they served it warm.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
My favorite dim sum in Chinatown for sure.  Service is fast and efficient, and the food is just a pleasure.  I personally think they have some of the strongest soup dumplings in the city (fair warning, they appear few and far between on the weekends so you have to be both patient and aggressive), and their steamed pork buns and shrimp dumplings are rock solid.  Tons of Chinatown locals eating here, so if you're unsure just order whatever they get and you can't go wrong.

I generally avoid the duck as it tends to be cold after a spin or two around the restaurant, and for the love of all that is holy avoid the tripe!  Even if you love tripe like I do, this one is a stomach bomb.
author: Christian C.

description:
This place is horrible.  The food is bad and the service is even worse.  On top of the bad service and food,  the treatment is discriminatory.  

I'm not going to waste anymore words.  Avoid this place if you can. Walk anywhere else around here and find a better Chinese restaurant.
author: Tim C.

description: At a wedding here and the service is horrible! It's someone's special day be nice to the guests. I hope they close soon.
author: Nicole M.

description:
You truly get what you pay for. Maybe I just don't like dim sum enough to tolerate the noise and the greasy food but everything just tasted too salty. I also don't like that they leave the front doors in where the smell of smoke from the chain smokers creep in. 

On the bright side it's pretty cheap but like I said, you get what you pay for. With that said, I would NOT recommend this place to any of my friends.
author: Anna K.

description: Avoid this place at all costs. I was happy to find a traditional cart pushing dim sum place in Chinatown. New Asia was a good place to go to years back but it has deteriorated down to the pits! Place is not the once neat venue for lunch. The almost empty place at the peak of lunchtime should have been a warning, but A grumbling tummy forced me to give this place a second try. Prices were ridiculous - $5 for an order of pork siumai, marginal tasting, if not bland. Would have tried other cart foods, but they look scary old, noodles & vegetables look desiccated. Opted to order basic Beef Stew Noodle Soup (Ngow Lam Mein) from the kitchen and it took 15 minutes to reach my table. I was wondering whether the waiter who took my order had forgotten since he seemed to ignore my waving. A second waiter finally came to the rescue and had my bowl after 5 minutes. The soup smells in, yellow noodles were the cheap imitation kind and priced at $12. No, YOU ARE NOT Yank Sing. Tally/Paytime wrapped up the overall horrible lunch. My pitiful noodle soup with my siumai totaled $19.80...What? $12 + $5 = $17. The waiter says they charge for tea! Really? Now fuming, I handed him two $20 bills. He came back with his tip tray and $19.20 change.  $40 - $19.80 = $20.20. I couldn't contain myself any longer but I had to leave that place. I told the waiter how bad everything was on top of the "inaccuracy" of charge. This was highway robbery in broad daylight!  I know my ranting at the waiter was futile and pitied another unsuspecting guest that may visit the place and fall prey. BTW, the waiter thanked me for the stolen dollar. Is there a negative star?
author: Clinton Z.

description:
It was packed when we came in here so I had high hopes. Unfortunately, my experience didn't live up to what I had expected. 

- Hostess was an intimidating woman who sounded like she was going to beat the hell out of anyone who bothered to ask her about a table. Also, she pretty much tells anyone who asks how long it takes that it's a "20 minute" wait.
- Seated at a table that was out of the way for the food cart servers.  
- We had a round table which had it's edges folded down to make a square; however, it was broken so when I sat, the round edge touched my thighs which made it uncomfortable to sit.  
- Table, chopsticks, plates were sticky and just overall dirty.  
- Server spilled sauce on the table since she just carelessly plopped items down.
- Food was not even decent. Dumplings fell apart easily and there was no such care for presentation overall. The duck wasn't even warm. You can get better stuff at the dim sum hole in the wall takeout places nearby.

I don't recommend this place at all.
author: J D.

description: Decent dim sum, large dining room great for groups, fast dim sum carts
author: Robert C.

description:
I ate dim sum here after running the 2014 Bay to Breakers Run.

My friends and I ate around 1 pm - 2 pm near the end of dim sum time. Selection around this time were small and slow. If you're lucky, then you'll be able to eat quickly without having to wait too long. My tip is be aware of what carts moving in case the same stuff have been around all pathway long. Idealistically, you will want everything that comes out of the kitchen immediately. Since I ate near the end of the dim sum hour, I might not be as lucky as I hoped. Eating dim sum at a large restaurant can be a bit if a gamble.

The majority of people here still speak Cantonese here so if you only speak Mandarin then you might be out if luck. Then again...I should be fortunate they understood my great English and childish mixed Southern Chinese movie influenced dialect.



The cart pushers understood English...so no worries. Pointing helps too. Just remember not to overdo it where you are left wondering why the bill is so high.
author: Robert L.

description: WORST ESTABLISHMENT I HAVE EVER BEEN TO!!!! They yell at their customers serve cold sub-par Sim Sum, try to re serve it to u MICROWAVED and then yell at u when u complain and make you pay FULL PRICE for the food u don't want. DO NOT GO HERE. I have never been so offended in my life.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Asked asian's on the street where I should go for Dim Sum and they pointed out this restaurant.

When I walked in I was overwhelmed at the size of it, very large and multi level and there was a wait, as it was packed.

When we were seated we were waited on quickly and was amazed at the quality and quantity of Dim Sum
author: ImLookingAt U.

description:
Attended a dinner there last night. When we were seated, cockroaches were crawling out of the paneling on the wall. The bathrooms were a horror. I used to love coming here for dim sum. So sad to see it decline. 

Kept thinking if the public areas were so filthy, what was the kitchen like? Drank tea and ate mostly rice. Scared to eat anything else.
author: Pat R.

description:
Best dim sum ever!

Quirky place with a band stand and balcony. Staff speak very little English. All customers seem to be local which is always a good sign. Shrimp and pork dim sum were excellent!
author: Basil B.

description: Nasty place! This place is simply disgusting.  By far the worst Dim Sum place I've ever been to. Worst taste, horrible service. I'm surpised this place is still in business.
author: Mark H.

description:
First off, please note the health score is 57 out of 100. I wish I had seen that prior to going.   It's too soon to tell, but if we experience the "effects" well update this review.
We were in Chinatown and wanted authentic dim sum. Forbs said this was the place to try for dim sum beginners.  I was a little worried it would be too Americanized, but boy was I wrong. It was very authentic and the staff was very friendly. I don't think I'm brave enough to try anything more authentic, and I consider myself pretty culinarily adventurous.  
Most dim sum places in Chinatown are take out and this place actually has carts. It also has ALOT of seating so we got a seat right away.  Overall the food was good. Beware the fried shrimp balls. I've never had them before, so I don't know if it was theirs in particular or if shrimp balls are normally balls of goo.  We enjoyed the potstickers and wontons.  Worth a try if your brave and want a place to sit.
author: Amanda F.

description: Went for dim sum. Wait wasn't too bad for a Sunday morning around 11:00 a.m. Food was mediocre and did not have alot of selection. Service wasn't horrible but maybe it's because I'm used to the way us Chinese people speak ;) overall, decent enough for 2 hungry people.
author: Sang K.

description: Can't believe they charge $1.25 for a glass of water. Yes- its not bottled, sparkling or Vitamin water. It is a top water and would cost you in your bill. Be careful with this crooks! If you argue, its written in their menu. Only went there because my favorite City View Restaurant was already closed and just saw that this one was still open.
author: Art M.

description:
The turnip cakes (see associated picture) with the bits of preserved veggies is probably the best damn 'loh bok goh' I've ever had.  

And the pan fried (?) vermicelli stuffed with chicken and veggies seems like one of those dream foods fuckin' fatties dream of, like mac and cheese pizza and Krispy Kreme burgers.  Order this, and it will feed you for days.  DAYS.
author: Jenn C.

description: This place is disgusting. Nothing is clean here. They do not have much of a variety as far as food is concerned. We came here for dim sum. The line was out the door with tons of people waiting inside too. Not sure why. The food is mediocre. There were barely anyone pushing a dim sum cart around so there weren't much food. How is that possible when you have a line out the door. It was also expensive. $70 for four adults that left hungry.
author: Danny F.

description: My first time having dim sum in the city.  The restaurant was packed in the middle of the weekday, but we were seated right away. The steamed pork buns were a favorite.
author: Annie M.

description:
Too bad Yelp does not give half stars. This place gets half a star for their service and one star for their food ONLY because their dim sum is not that bad. 

I came with a group of friends (all ages 17 & 18) and they seated us at the stage area. The waiter was nice enough to relocate us because the servers do not pay much attention up there. 

As we finished eating, we asked for the bill. The waiters were already clearing our table. One waiter was standing at our table waiting for us to pay. The moment we put the money down on the table, the waiter took it and counted it on the table. After he counted it, he said we did not tip enough.

I was at the point where I wanted to tell my friends to get up and leave, but my friend threw another dollar and tipped him. You do not count money in front of your customers because that's disrespectful. Tips are how much we want to give based on your service. You do NOT ask for more tip.
author: Daniel W.

description: I don't understand why this place is so popular. Probably because it's in a central area of Chinatown and the largest. Also, the demographic is the older crowd and they serve dim sum the old school style with the push carts. The dim sum is average and the service varies. The interior also needs some up keep as it feels a bit dirty and dated with the old tables and chairs.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
This is easily my favorite Dim Sum place around! It is the perfect experience for anyone looking for a noisy environment where the cart ladies try to put every item on your table. It's fairly inexpensive as long as you order off the carts. Anything in a steamer basket is awesome. The pork and shrimp dumplings are super, but when I ate there yesterday, I was blown away by the simple plate of chinese broccoli with plum sauce. YUM. I couldn't stop eating it.
Oh, and PORK BUNS FOR SURE!
It's dim sum, so if you don't expect a fine gourmet meal and are willing to have a little fun with it, this place is a must. Just don't be afraid to say no to the cart ladies, ask the bus-boys for water, or shove your bill in any employees path when you are finished eating and you will be good to go.
author: Audi S.

description:
When I lived in San Francisco for a year, this was the Dim Sum spot my sister and I would go to every Sunday. It holds a special place in my heart! The clientele is 90% Chinese, 10% Non-Chinese. The food comes through on carts in a giant ballroom and if you want something, you better say something otherwise SOMEONE ELSE IS GUNNA GET YOUR DUMPLING. 

If you don't want tea, make sure you tell them before they set it on your table because they will charge you for it whether you drink it or not if it's on your table. If you want to pay your check, look for the most official dude and get his attention. That way you'll be in and out to enjoy the rest of SF.

I've taken so many out of towners here, including my cousin who grew up Chinese too, and she loved it "tastes like home". New Asia is the dopeness, I MISS IT!
author: Felicia R.

description:
My family and I use to come here every weekend when I was a child. I don't know why we stopped going but we decided to return today. 

The wait didn't seem too long. We were seated kind of by the door and just sitting down I was kind of disgusted. The table cloth was kind of dirty and the dish that held the sauces seem like they have been be washed. 

The waitress came to place down these paper place mats. While she did it she almost wacked my dad with the place mats! She didn't even notice but who can blame her. Her job is pretty hard. =[

It took forever for us to get our food. I feel like there is no organization or planned efficient routes these little dim sum carts go in. What is worse is how all the patrons take it onto themselves to open each little dim sum. How disgusting. 

The food was not very good. The shanghi dumpling meat tasted funny and you couldn't even get it onto your plate without it bursting. The tripe was cold by the time we got it. The beef balls and the tofu wrapped rolls were the only items I enjoyed. We never even saw the noodle wrapped shrimp. =[

I don't want to come back ever.
author: Sarah C.

description:
The service was not so good but it's not so important here. The waiter is just to bring tea and check.
The food was ok. I thought it's larger volume as for dim sum. Normally 3 dumplings in a container or a dish, but here, 4 of them. I got full quickly and couldn't try more dishes.
The price is about average.
author: Yaeko M.

description:
Yes its true everyone. This place is certainly a dive in it's truest forms and can be chaotic. 

But..if you are craving some decent chinese food and have thick skin then, definitely try their lobster noodle dish, duck and shrimp dumplings 'ha gow'. The lobster is tasty and covered with saucy e-fu noodles. The duck is crispy and juicy. The plum sauce is sweet and tangy (doesn't taste like the typical package kind). The shrimp dumplings are huge and shrimp filling is tasty.
author: Jen K.

description:
i've been coming here since i was just a baby!! now, i'll be having my wedding reception here next year!! AHHHHHH.... i'm getting old!!

i love having dim sum here.. even though i don't love going out to chinatown. there's just more of a family feel to this place. it's more so the memories i've had here that matter to me the most. the food is still just as great, if not better, as it was over 20 years ago.

some of the workers are still familiar faces and i adore it. 

my parents had their wedding reception here 31 years ago.. 32 years later, their daughter will be having it here as well.

while having dim sum with my parents, we met with one of the managers - Chris Lee. he's super easy to work with and really friendly. he answered all questions and concerns with a smile. 

another review to come after the big day is over..
author: Ann T.

description: This place is hit or miss... I've come a few times for lunch with coworkers. The first time, everything was great! But, the next time, we must have been late, or just had bad timing... but most of the plates we got were cold and it was really disappointing. But i guess just that's the risk you take with dim sum on carts.
author: Lacy S.

description:
A friend and I wanted to go to a dim sum restaurant that had the carts and banquet feel (not like the dim sum bakeries they have all around) so we stumbled upon this place. Good find! 

Smack dab in the middle of Chinatown...this place was packed on Memorial Day morning! And the only langage I heard around was...well, some kind of Chinese! So that had to be a good sign. This got especially confusing when they kept talking to me in Chinese, but when they saw my clueless face, the servers quickly changed to English. They described the dim sum options well, and overall served us quickly and efficiently. The xiao long bao and the xiu mai were especially good here.

And as pricing goes, I thought it would be pretty pricey because of its location, thinking it would charge tourist prices. Not too bad! Nothing stand out about this place, but overall solid choice for dim sum!
author: Sylvie D.

description: After reading all recent reviews, I admit I'm terrified. This truly saddens me, but overall restaurant service in SF is declining terribly fast! No sense of customer service in this town.
author: Raymond F.

description: Disgusting dim sum! Server was confused when we tipped him $3 for our food. Yes idiot your service was non whatsoever and your food was even worse. I would never eat here again or take anyone here. I only came because a friend said it was the best dim sum in SF. Boy were they wrong!! Pretty dirty itself. Must skip this place!!
author: Shren T.

description:
Food here is GREAT. 

Please check out the photos on here. Service definitely needs improvement, but I would give SERVICE 3 stars!

I sure love DIMSUM here. (A definite FOUR STARS).

I try to get to this place at least one time per months. For sure -- I will return. 

I find that this place has great selection. Only came here for DIMSUM. And just based on DIMSUM, this place get a FOUR stars from me.
author: Nicholas H.

description:
If you want authentic dim sum in Chinatown, this is THE place to go!  If you are not Asian, expect to stand out...like a sore thumb!  But also expect some of the best dim sum you will probably ever have.

Arrive early if your are going for lunch...we got there at 11AM and it was packed within five minutes.  As the carts go by, do not be shy...ask the servers for what you want or ask them if they have anything with beef, pork, etc.  They will show you what they have and you can pick it or look at other offerings.

DO NOT LEAVE WITHOUT TRYING THE EGG CUSTARD TARTS!  Sorry, didn't mean to shout, but they are AWESOME!  The ones we got had a smiley face that had browned on the top, which made ending our meal a bit happier.  

Act like a regular...when you're done eating, taking your bill with you and pay at the front.  Don't expect anyone to cater to you and come by and pick up the bill...you could be there all day as they do not rush you.  You can linger as long as you like over your meal.  Which is also part of the fun for me.  I love watching the locals enjoy the company and the food.  They don't rush a meal like we do...the linger and savor every bit of it.

Love this place!  I always take people here when they ask to eat in Chinatown..and I don't even live in the city. :)
author: Cindi A.

description: Came and check out this place today (I'm from Stockton) for dim sum, it was super busy!  Well I be coming back, probably not. Customer service was horrible, I had to ask 4 different waiter/ waitress just for a glass of water, food wasn't all that great I loss my appetite after the 3 dish when I saw a bunch of roaches run around! Disgusting
author: Veasna M.

description: A place to go for sim sum, and boy they have a lot of choices.  The place is big but not very clean.  Definitely needs some good cleaning and training got good service.  But if you want good dim sum and don't care for these other stuff, then this is a good place.  Not sure how clean the kitchen is though..
author: Rick K.

description:
UNIQUE

FRESHly made items served in bamboo steamers come by often on carts with friendly servers.  They speak a tad more English than I do Chinese but they can tell you what type of meat is inside each item.  I recommend starting with two of your favorites and trying something new that the waiter shows you.
  
SURPRISingly delicious not sure what we were eating.  But, what I did not like my husband happily finished for me.

PRICE for lunch for two was also a surprise since everything is marked by a stamp in Chinese without prices. Ours came to just $15! and we were full!

CLEAN~ before YELP ever existed my mother would judge a restaurant by how clean they kept their front door and their bathrooms.  some of the smaller restaurants in Chinatown cannot compare.

I cannot wait to go back!

BUT~  Next time we are driving.  I think we waited over an hour for a cable car that could hold two more desperate travelers trying to get back to the pier.  We wanted to just stop in CT for lunch and continue on up the hill for a round trip cable car ride but knew we could not b/c we had reservations later that evening. SF was very crowded on that weekend.
author: Affinity Z.

description: This place is huge. We were looking for a dim sum restaraunt and one of the locals suggested this place. They use the carts a and its right in China town. Cool experience. A little hectic. Go early so everything is fresh
author: Shauna G.

description: Food here is mediocre. Service sucks, waiters are rude. My father was in the middle of signing the credit card receipt when the waiters were already kicking us out. They take forever to serve you, but when it came time for the check, they didn't bat an eyelash. DID I MENTION RUDE WAITERS?!
author: Susan W.

description: Fantastic Dim Sum at a fair price. Many selections to choose from and pleasant staff. Only drawback was the restrooms are upstairs and may be difficult for those with mobility issues.
author: Chuck B.

description:
I just went here today and the wait was long...around 25 mins at 1PM when they said it'd take 15? It was my second time here, but I remember the wait was just as long when I came with my friends last time. If you're hungry, come early!

I like their lobster noodles. Some of my friends say it's too starchy but I like it cooked that way. So juicy...yummy. I can't say the same about the dim sum though because it comes out cold. It's probably b/c the ladies push the carts around forever, but that's no excuse for cold dim sum! Another thing is, the portions are reasonable but the quality of the dim sum is unfortunately just so-so.
author: Julie H.

description: Went for lunch on the the 4th of July. Closed :( sad since I've been visiting every summer since it was Asia Garden. Loved to order their dim sum and drive to Coit Tower to picnic with it. Oh well
author: Day M.

description:
So..., I came here while visiting some buddies in SF. New Asia is situated in China Town, so I was kind of weary of tourist trap, but I thought to myself, there's a lot of Chinese peeps in SF, it might be different. Plus, I'm  game for trying places out. 

Aight, cost of living in SF is higher than Atl, so I'm going to eliminate the price factor. Also, I want to preface, we came here an hour before closing. When I first set foot inside the doors, I was impressed by the size of the restaurant. It's a pretty spacious two story restaurant. I was pretty giddy until I saw the dim sum cart. The selection was scarce and semi unappetizing. I mean, the food was not bad enough for me to say no, but definitely not good enough for me to get excited over. I was in the company of others, who thought dim sum and two menu items was good enough. Also, the servers did not want to make any new dim sum items for us and basically told us to suck it up if we wanted some. I don't blame them, but still man! 
Food verdict : meeh.
author: Han L.

description:
We were looking for a decent place to eat at. As we drove by, it looked nice so we decided to park on the street since parking at a lot was $25. As we enter, we notice there was music which sounded like karaoke but it turns out there was a live band there that night.  We did stand for about three minutes before someone noticed we were waiting for a table. Once we were seated, it took about 15 minutes for someone to take our order. I was ok with it because I was so entertained by the many couples that were dancing to the tunes of lady gaga tango style and rock and roll, country, swing, you name it! I loved watching people dance. I was too intimidated to go out there myself because they looked like pros out there!
We ordered beers, garlic noodles, chicken curry, and the egg rolls. I'm so not a big Chinese foodie by any means, but I loved their food! I'm for sure coming back!
author: Daisy A.

description:
Solid. Definitely satisfied my (neverending) dim sum cravings.

There was almost no wait for our party of 3 on a Sunday mid-morning and, of course, one of the best things about dim sum is INSTANT gratification. I liked how this place has the carts hookup but noticed how it was the same 4 carts orbiting our table.

The food was good, not great, but again...it's dim sum and our total bill including tip came out to be $30 for the 3 of us. There's room for improvement (bigger water glasses!) but all-in-all, I'd come back.
author: Furai X.

description:
We and five friends ventured into New Asia early Sunday morning for dim sum. The place was already bustling with Chinese folks as well as other tourists but we didn't have to wait too long for a table. 

We were seated upstairs and immediately, the first cart rolled by to our table. Having picked out the standard dim sum dishes, I particularly enjoyed the mochi rice in lotus leaf, siu mai and char siu bun. Despite it being busy and all, the carts with a wide selection of dim sum came by frequently.

Relatively noisy and spacious dining room. Their decor was a little tacky for my taste but I love, love their chandeliers! Overall, I liked the food and I was able to finally settle my dim-sum-craving!
author: Consuela P.

description:
I came to Chinatown to introduce a couple of friends from out of town to taste authentic dim sum. It was crowded on a Saturday morning around 11am. I put our name down and was given a waiting number to be called when a table was ready. The dim sum itself was good but not the best i've had. The staff is really personable and friendly whether you speak chinese or not. The place is bustling but the food was coming out left and right. 

Our chinese broccoli dish was a bit cold but It's still good with the oyster sauce. I liked their shrimp dumplings and their cha siu baos. They don't skimp on the good stuff in their porridge. Sad that the xiao long bao cart came out a little too late and i was too full to snag a plate :(

$45 for 9 dishes for 3 people. Great place to bring newcomers to dim sum.
author: Samantha L.

description:
2.75 stars

Pounding rain and wet feet spoiled led us to New Asia. Is this place new or are we being tricked by some golden buddha somewhere? Well, our friend recommended this place and we had the dim sum here but the food was cold, dry, and not worth the 28 bucks we spent. We weren't full and we had to stop because we were disappointed with the food we had ordered. Staff was slow even when the restaurant was only at 2% capacity. Oh wells, I have yet to find a good dim sum place in Chinatown.
author: Danster L.

description:
Horrible service, high price, old place.  Come here only because Gold Mountain and Miriwa restaurants closed down.
Been coming here since mid-1980s, but coming back less often, since they opened new restaurants in Chinatown and then in other parts of the Bay Area.  But since Meriwa closed years ago followed by Gold Mountain 2 months ago, I went in, hoping it got better.  Boy, was I wrong.  They ignored us (6) when we entered, and when I walked up to a table, a food cart lady tried to move us to a smaller table instead.  Keep in mind, this was 8:40 am, ten minutes after opening, and big tables were occupied by fewer people.  I mentioned that, to which she responded that I can just flip up the flaps to accommodate the six of us.  
Bye!  Went to Imperial Palace (formerly Gold Dragon) instead.
author: Mitchell T.

description:
We asked a very nice police office while walking around town where should we eat dim sum...he said this place was great. We got here about 2:45 for lunch and were served tea without asking (which we later paid for...and we did not drink)....so if you don't want tea say no thank you. We asked for pork shumai and we were told 4 minutes...10 minutes go by and we asked again...well wouldn't you know it we were told 4 minutes....guess what, asked again and guess what...4 minutes! We never got any pork. We asked for soy sauce three times...never got it. We asked at 7 minutes to 3:00 for noodles with chicken. Our obvious mistake was asking the rolling cart gals (which they wear purple and the waitress wears pink...who knew!) which they did not tell our waitress and 5 after 3:00 our waitress finally came around and we said we would like noodles...well, apparently they stop serving at 3:00. The reason hey stop serving at 3:00 is the entire wait staff sits down at tables around the restaurant to eat. No question of would you like anything else, just its break time. 

SOOOOO....we had three dim sum plates, no soy sauce, no noodles...and tea we didn't request or drink. I am giving them one star because the little food we were actually served was decent...I give zero stars for service, and the run around. We were also told our total, but "tip not included"...So incredibly rude to request a tip. We had awful service but I would NEVER stiff someone.
author: Jenn B.

description:
If my husband were writing this, he would start off by saying zero stars.  We stopped by here for lunch today, and it was the worst experience, both food and service.  Of course, one expects bad service in a Chinese restaurant, but this was beyond bad.  

We got there around noon and there was no wait (yay!).  The lady said to walk in and then a greeter meets you half way to show you your table.  We got the "let's not use this table unless we have to" table.  It was in the middle of the restaurant, so all the carts same by, BUT...  It was a square table for 4, but they only had 3 chairs (and there were only 2 of us).  There was no chair in one aisle side because the ladies use it as their parking space, so if I turned to my right, there was a cart up against my face.  The third chair was not used, so during the 45 minutes we were there, it got knocked from its original spot to the space next to me and then finally to the middle of the aisle until about 15 minutes later when someone moved it back to our table.  :D

Right after we got shown to our table and before we even sat down, a waiter asked us what tea we wanted.  Tea is $1/pp and we ordered jasmine.  Unless you are a kid or maybe if you order a soda, you will be charged a tea fee.  I don't think you can actually say I don't want tea and have them not charge you.  

Then came the food.  My husband ordered the baked pork buns.  They were filled with pork and thick salty sauce.  A lady carted some daikon cake and said it was hot, so we ordered.  It was room temperature at best (don't believe them!).  We each had 1/2 piece and brought the other two home so that we could pan fried them later.  Then we got the shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, and shrimp noodle rolls.  Shrimp dumplings were pretty good.  Skin was transparent and yummy but shrimp were the small type.  The pork dumplings were a little dry.  The shrimp noodle rolls were good but only room temperature.  By this time, I had asked two separate person for iced water because I was thirsty.  I waited and waited.  And finally asked a third time before it was brought to us.  This was during a span of about 20 minutes.  

We sat for about 15 minutes without ordering anything less.  Now let's review the five plates we got:  daikon cake, shrimp dumpling, pork dumpling, shrimp noodle roll, and pork buns.  We got charged for 1 small plate, 1 medium plate, 1 large plate, and 2 specialty plates.  The 2 specialty plates were $4.50 each!  Our bill came to almost $23!  Our waiter claimed that the dumplings were specialty plates.  In what dim sum restaurant are dumplings a specialty plate that cost $4.50?!

That was the final straw!  We quickly paid and left and will never return.  It's sad because in Chinatown, there are very limited dim sum restaurants, and they are probably the only one with carts.  Next time we're going to Great Eastern instead!
author: Rose C.

description:
The way they stamp the items are not like other dimsum places. I think it has changed quite a bit since the time I came here with my parents when I was younger. Today, my bf and I ordered the following:

Siu Mai (stamped as medium because they add shrimp): YUM! I always seem to like siu mai with bits of shrimp in it. The mixture of the pork and shrimp makes the best combination and the siu mai itself at this place is pretty big.

Chicken Feet: This is where I had to dock stars. The chicken feet isn't the best I have had and to tell you the truth, I would rank it as one of the worse I have ever had. The texture is there and is good, but the marinade... it just isn't good.

Shrimp dumplings (stamped as large): You won't be jipped with shrimp in this dish. Some dimsum places give your one small shrimp and then cover it up with fake shrimp paste to make you think you get your monies worth. Not here, you get a hardy portion of shrimp in each dumpings.

Dan Ta (egg tart) (stamped as special): hrm... usually in other dim sum places, it gets stamped as small because it doesn't take much to make these delicious buttery eggy tarts! This was really warm and yummy. I love egg tarts!

Ham Sui Gok (deep fried meat dumplings): I love this dish when I was growing up (until I realized this is not good for you.. so I don't eat this dish often LOL). I would have to say the stuffing in this dish was very disappointing. You get so little stuffing and so much gooey skin... it wasn't worth getting. I have had better and it had triple the amount of meat stuffing than what we got at New Asia.

Overall. dimsum carts came by often. Opt out on getting crappy seats, there is so many tables there that it won't hurt to wait a min longer to get a better table (I wouldn't recommend sitting upstairs for dimsum). I think it is CASH ONLY during lunch hours. Service is good, they clean and refill your tea pretty fast.

Total bill was $19 something for 5 dishes (two people).
author: Erica T.

description: I remember coming to this place as a kid.  But I'm sure that they've changed hands or at least now they probably have different chefs.  So it has been a long time since I've been here and I have to say, you can certainly find better places to have dim sum.  The problem here is they are trying to make their Hai Gow look bigger than they really are by putting in a little animal fat in it.  If we are trying to trick people by doing this and I noticed it, then what else are they doing to their other product?! On the plus side, their sweet tofu soup was good.  I've noticed that a lot of places put a little ginger in the mixture and I am not a fan of that, but this place doesn't do that.
author: Patrick T.

description:
This place is a scam! The staff was friendly only when they were trying to get us to come in, after that they were very anxious to get us to leave and started lifting up chairs around us to let us know they wanted to close. 

In addition, the whole concept here is very unclear. At the door they showed us a menu with dishes priced between $4-$8. When we sat they began offering us food (they claimed they were appetizers) from the carts, thinking they were around the same price as the menu we received, we happily indulged. When we came to pay we were shocked to receive a $60 check for 3 people for lunch, and the woman at the cash register was so aggressive and unfriendly that she practically yelled at us to leave a tip! 

In short, the food was sub-par, as was the service. Be warned, and stay away!
author: Sivonne W.

description:
This is some tasty dim sum. My only complaints are that it was VERY loud and really hot. Granted we were on the second floor, but it was hot even downstairs.

Another detraction was that the bathroom was small, nestled in a kitchen-ish area, and constantly slippery. It was also sorely undersized for the seating area.

One additional detraction would be that there are no fountain drinks and the pops are all by-the-can -- no bottomless pops. BAD SHOWING.

But New Asia has a lot of pluses, too. The wait staff is friendly and brings food often. The food itself is high quality with a depth of flavor that surpasses much Chinese food that I've had.

Also, the chicken feet were delicious.

There were some dishes that were exemplary -- some pork deal inside puffy dough, those buns with the sesame seeds, some kinda small pies with different fillings, and a number of other things. Almost anything with meat was great. The duck was tasty, but had bones, making it hard to eat. The chicken was cold, which is weird, and saps some of the flavor. Also, the meat inside rice noodles (wrapped in flat noodles) was strange.

Overall, a great example of dim sum but not a perfect dining experience.
author: David H.

description:
I've been here so many times for dinners/weddings/fundraisers and other events I know what's going to be served.
The dim sum is alright, so is the dinner.
author: Teresa C.

description: This is a trap. Good is cold and terrible and over priced!! Worst experience during my time in San Francisco.
author: Jimmy A.

description: This place has changed. We used to come here for banquets but now the food they served are less than it used to be.  Taste is still good just the dishes they served are less in each plate dish.
author: Belle L.

description:
When you go to New Asia Chinese Restaurant expect old school, traditional Chinese folks.  Be sure to bring the G-folks or bring someone who speaks fluent Chinese!  The place and food aren't too bad but I'm sure there are much better places in C-town to explore!   

We had the shark fin (*mushroom not sharks!) soup, stir fried scallops, fried oysters, walnut shrimp, smoked sea bass and peking duck.  Do not order the fried oysters!  They're disgusting. Peking duck...not so good either. The smoked sea bass was bomb.com - SOOOOOO GOOD.  I wanted to eat more and more and more of it but I couldn't.

To get to the bathroom you've got to go up some marble stairs - very unsafe on a rainy day.  One could easily slip, fall and crack their skull.  Be careful out there!  The bathrooms themselves were gross and typical for C-town.  The walls, floors, tables and everything else in the restaurant are sticky, grimey, greasy and need to be cleaned.  There are also TVs, a stage and a karaoke system so people can perform at dinner banquets like the one I attended.   Pretty entertaining if you ask me.

Everyone seems to think the dim sum is cheap and decent so maybe I'll come back for that.  For banquets and dinner, I would not recommend coming here though.
author: Dee H.

description: Upon arrival, the hostess gave us a number due to the long line. But she calls out the number in Chinese which we can't understand. Waited for 30 minutes to find out she's called out our number 15 mins ago. Good food though.
author: Dante M.

description:
From dim sum's point of view, this is best.  This place must have existed for over 30 years now and they are still making the best dim sum this side of the continent.

But that's about it.

The service leans on the arrogant side.  You got shoved into the table and start fighting for the attention from those waiting staff.  If you look like an Asian, they automatically speak to you in Cantonese.  The bathrooms are "traditional:" wet, smelly, and small.  The decor is for maximal occupancy, not much else.

If you crave for dim sum and don't mind the wait and bad services (like those who have lived in China Town forever), then this is the place.  Otherwise, find a more modern place.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description: Terrible terrible TERRIBLE service. There was a ROACH on the wall crawling next to me as I ate. Also, the front desk lady who wears wayyyy too much makeup was so rude. She demanded a high tip. Do yourself a favor and do not come here ever.
author: Nicolette A.

description:
Decent dim sum in a convenient location (though it is very hard to find parking if you drive there). The prices are reasonable as others have mentioned. Considering the amount of people that come everyday, they are very efficient and have a very fast turnover rate.

There are dim sum carts that come around with dishes that are mostly fresh. True, the restaurant is pretty dirty (sticky floors, stained tables), but it's on par with all the other restaurants in Chinatown. Most of the clientele are older Asian folk which is a good sign to me. You do get the occasional tourist family that looks lost which can be somewhat amusing.

Overall a good place if you know what you are getting into. If you don't know what to order, chances are you will have a hard time here because most of the waitresses don't speak English too well. Also, you can't expect great service at such a busy place, but it is still extremely rude to not pay tip cause of it; they are trying their best and have a lot of people to get to. They don't have the time to hang around while you're taking your time trying to learn the Chinese names of all the dishes.

P.S. For those of you who say that you can find way better dim sum in Chinatown, please let me know where because I've lived here practically my whole life and don't know a better dim sum place that is still in business. Thanks!
author: Angela W.

description: If you prioritize cheap, this place is for you maybe? I personally look for at least enough quality that I don't feel disgusted while eating but the grease... I didn't want to eat anything here. I tried at least 7 different dishes and they all felt like they were soaking in grease. Flavor was lacking still. I love duck and I can only think of a handful of places that can mess up duck. I felt kind of sick after eating here..
author: Linh L.

description: Probably the worst tasting dim sum place I've been to. We ordered just typical plates such as Shu Mai, roasted pork buns, taro cake, soup dumplings and seriously, everything was disappointing. The plates were all bland and tasteless and the soup dumplings had no soup in them. The soup dumplings also were all stuck to the bottom of the bamboo steamers so it was impossible to pick them up whole.  I was super excited and pumped beforehand because I hadn't  had dim sum in a while and was really looking forward to having some on the West Coast. The staff is also almost completely Canto speaking which makes it difficult to figure out what some of the plates are. Definitely would not recommend this spot.
author: Rinda K.

description:
I feel like eating in a cafeteria when I dine here.  I've been here several times with family whenever we make that San Francisco Chinatown excursion.  Unfortunately and ironically, there just aren't any good dim sum places in Chinatown (try places of off El Camino Real, south of San Francisco if you can).  New Asia is, sadly, the best in SF Chinatown. 

The restaurant is a giant ballroom filled with tables and chairs; too many if you ask me (its crowded).  Here, you'll find a mix of regulars and tourists and occasional visitors like me.  Expect a wait on weekends and be prepared to be mind boggled when it comes to getting your table.  You aren't exactly led to a table once you're called up.  You're on your own when it comes to finding it.  To me, its a place to get people in and get people out as soon as possible. 

Their dim sum is decent.  Not bad but not special.  They're generic; they serve the same usual dishes and never experiment with new dishes or even variations.  I suppose that's great for regulars and tourists, but I enjoy trying new things.  Come here if you're hungry; don't, if you have time to go elsewhere.  I personally wouldn't dine in Chinatown if I had the choice.
author: David O.

description: It's a great venue for the Kung Pao Kosher Comedy event every year during the holidays but the food...well...not my thing. But I'm just not interested in greasy Chinese food; most Chinese restaurants don't seem to use high quality ingredients and I often feel a little unsettled.
author: Leslie K.

description:
Dim Sum is okay. Better than anything in San Jose. However, if you want to be ignored except when you tell them your going to pay and asked why you didn't leave 10% tip, THIS IS THE PLACE FOR YOU! 

I was about two feet away from the server after he spoke with a customer and asked him on several occasions for things we needed, water, coke, high chair, etc. All the times I was trying to get his attention, he would straight up ignore me except when I was about to pay the bill. When I said, "Hey" he still ignored me until I included, "Hey, I want to PAY the bill." and then I got 100% attention from the server. Too late buddy! 

Then he asked me why I didn't leave 10%. I explained that his service was horrible. Why would you ask for 10% if I had to pretty much get everything myself and was ignored?

I do keep in to consideration how busy an establishment is (it was not busy upstairs) but this guy gave me HORRIBLE service and then had the nerve to asked me why I didn't leave 10%. 

I do not expect the best service at a Dim Sum spot, however, don't ignore customers every time they ask you something. 

Save yourself the trouble. Eat somewhere else.
author: Russ C.

description:
I've got to admit that I noticed the lower quality today.  First of all, my tea wasn't hot.  It was lukewarm tea.  Who wants warm tea?  

The shrimp dumplings didn't have that nice bite to it but it was rather bland and mushy.  The stuffed beef fun was very lack luster.  The noodles were not chewy but overly soft and limp and the meat didn't have much flavor.  In addition, they were stingy on the soy sauce.  The pork dumplings were surprisingly the best thing they had, it was full of flavorful shrimp and pork.  The lotus buns didn't taste as good as they used to.  The buns didn't have that delicate layered texture which is what makes the steamed lotus buns special and the filling was overly sweet.  Sad.  With tip, it was 30 dollars for three people for breakfast.  Luckily, there were local bakeries nearby and one of them had more variety of dim sum than this dim sum restaurant.  Embarrassing!  I guess I would come only if I wanted to have dim sum in Chinatown but my local dim sum place is better and it's in the suburbs.  Very disappointed.  Luckily, the garage nearby made this trip very easy and there was no wait.  However, the lack of wait is a bad sign on a dim sum Sunday!
author: Lorissa W.

description:
If only Pacific ave could talk. 

I'm sure stories of tong's, gambling, prostitution and police raids would be plentiful. As one of the oldest and richest streets in the heart of China Town I have to say that New Asia holds a special place in my heart. 

I remember coming here as a young girl and thinking how special this place is. The banquet room is huge, the chandeliers plentiful and waiters dressed in black and white. And 20 years later it's still the same. 

The food is old school, lots of older generations sitting around and slowly snacking on their yum cha. Lots of hustle and bustle. Packed to the brim. Difficult to maneuver through. Lots of families catching up in canto, endless plates clinking and rushed service. I love to see the little old ladies dressed to the nines in their old school designer duds. It's everything I love in yum cha, 

Nostalgia alone gives this place 4 stars. Food is alright too - just have to know what to order.

p.s the thought alone of the lobster noodles makes me mouth-gasm.
author: Jade W.

description: Can't exactly comment on the food, but we came for dinner and arrived at 5, which is what time their door signs and website says. They were still sweeping, setting up tables, chairs, etc. so we just sat. It turns into 530 and we asked what seemed like a manager if they were open yet. He literally just grunted and walked away from us. Finally a nicer waitstaff walked by us and explained to us that they were not yet ready. We were too hungry to wait longer so we left.
author: Stacey H.

description:
This was my second visit in 2 weeks and if I had written my review on my first experience, it would have gotten at least 3/5.

We came through during the late morning on Monday and it was fairly empty. A majority of the staff were crowding a family over to the side, we later came to think they were either the owners or some other superstar.

We didn't see anyone roll by for at least five minutes, but there was a cart sitting next to us. Do we just take a plate of their crispy shrimp balls and tell our server once she comes around to our table? After contemplating it, we told the host that sat us that we were ready to order. She hollered at a girl cleaning plates at the other end of the restaurant who, in turn, doubled as the restaurants only server. Without washing her hands, she came over and served us the shrimp balls and egg rolls. She also rolled through with a steamed cart.

The food wasn't like my first visit, actually the complete opposite. The Crispy Shrimp Balls were stale. Shaomai were over cooked, so they fell apart as they sat in the steamer. Lastly, the Har Gow were cold and the Soup Dumplings didn't taste right. The only plate we enjoyed and ordered seconds of were the Egg Rolls.

The Awkward Moment Of The Meal: After we got our bill, the host hovered over us as we signed the check. She didn't walk by our table or stand at a distance, she actually stood over us. We thought she needed the credit card plate for another table. But wait...there were only 3 occupied tables in the entire restaurant.

On my first visit, I thought I found a decent place that I would love to visit on a regular basis, but at this point I'm still looking for my "Bay Area Dim Sum Joint" - if you've got suggestions, send them my way!
author: Darshan R.

description:
DO NOT EAT HERE - We walked out. 

Let me explain. We entered and told the host we had 3 in our party. They directed us to a nearby table that was filthy. We stood by and waited for them to clean it and bring fresh linens.

Instead of a clean tablecloth they brought some white paper place mats and attempted to conceal the wet spots and food remnants that were left on the table. 

We were horrified. 

If that is how they treat their tables we were afraid to see how they treated their food. 

We literally turned around and walked out and headed to Yummy Yummy Restaurant just two doors down. 

Do not eat at New Asia. Scary.
author: Randy S.

description:
Came here for dim sum on a Sunday, and only had to wait about 5 minutes for a table for two. The woman on the microphone was absolutely hilarious.

The soup dumplings fell apart a bit too easily, and were a bit of an impulse order. The har gau were similarly fragile. The roast duck was quite tasty, as were the shrimp balls and the steamed char siu bau. The egg tarts were alright, but the dough a bit too soft.

I would have liked a bit more variety in what was circling around us, as I saw better stuff on the other side.

We were honestly in and out in around 20 minutes.
author: Harley C.

description: For a dim sum place it was just too crowded. The service sucked. It's  a Chinese dim sum in the heart of china town.  The food was good just like any good dim sum place.
author: An N.

description:
Delicious disappointment?
I miss dim sums in LA :(
Mmmm EGG TARTS (worth 5 stars!)
Sad dim sum variety
Unusually empty at 2pm
Many locals and tourists here

I came yesterday afternoon to realize that I've been here before! haha This place is relatively crowded, especially in the morning and brunch times. I wasn't too impressed with the variety of dim sum here. I'm biased. I still like dim sum in LA a whole lots more (more variety and cheaper!) Our bill for 2 somehow came out to $30! O_O I think it might have been the nasty shiao long bao that made our bill go up! 

But LOVED their egg tarts!!! The custard was yummmm! I think they are way better than Good Mong Kok Bakery's!! If you see the egg tarts, get at least 3 orders worth! You won't regret it! :)

Next time I'm here I'm ONLY ordering
+ shu mai
+ EGG TARTS (LOVED!!! they run out quick!)
+ bbq pork pastry stuff

Dim sum "no no"s
- shiao long bao (expensive and NASTY, doughy and meat tasted uncooked)
- har gow (funny shrimp after taste)

Depending on where you sit in that restaurant, eating dim sum can be a good or bad experience! The cart pushers speak some English and Mandarin, but mostly Cantonese. Also, if you parked in the Golden Gateway Garage, they VALIDATE!!

I'm still in search for a good dim sum place in the bay area! Help!
author: CeCe C.

description:
As the Lazy Susan turns...

Chances are, if you're Chinese--or in my case half, not only have you been to a TON of Chinese Banquets, you were probably the star of the occasion at your first one.

Life's Big events: when you're born, get hitched, have kids, leave this world, and my absolute favorite, Family Reunions. Last month, 150 of us met up at the not so new, New Asia Restaurant to celebrate our family connection. We took over the entire first floor with 4 generations.

When I arrived at the doors, I had an instant flash-back of several crazy, insane, "Wait, I didn't want that dish and where's my chow-fun?" dim-sum lunches. It's a typical Chinatown joint: tile floors that weren't sticky for a change, a sea of tables, stage, big screen TV, wait staff in a constant flurry of slowness (how is that even possible?), and a little lacking in its dated ambiance. I realize that I could almost be describing anywhere, but you get my point. 

8 good, but not great dishes (gotta throw in a lucky eight in there!) including Seafood Lettuce Wraps, Steamed Pork with Egg, Duck and a soup that tasted fishy but not in an especially good way.  We ordered way too much, but no one seemed to be taking it home except for me, cuz who doesn't like free leftovers? It was probably a 2.5 Star sign...

I've got 20 more Chinese Banquets to chow down at in the future, I hope! However, not sure I'll be spinning the dishes 'round this one. All I've got to say is:

"Can someone please pass the 7-up?"
author: Kira R.

description: It is okay, not bad, not good. The service was lacking and the prices were alright, not cheap, but not expensive either, just fair. Taste was meh, typical dim sum.
author: Terence C.

description:
A very large dim sum house, there is always a table available once you come. Two floors, can fit small to large parties, no problem! Tons of people, very loud and rude service; which is expected in any dim sum house. The dim sum isn't as good as other places I have been to, but there is one thing I can't find else where and I know they will have here..   

PORK BLOOD . JUR HONGGG. and INTESTINES . AoU JAP all in one dim sum house! 

YEAH,. those are my two favorite dishes when I am at a REAL dim sum house!
author: Chanel L.

description:
3 of us for a Dim Sum brunch during the week. 

It is a huge restaurant (no waiting during the week) with giant glass chandeliers (read tacky) looming above. Not a Yank Sing vibe or atmosphere, but but also not the Yank Sing price. 

Fast food delivery to the table of the  Dim Sum staples. It was good, not great. (although one dish was cold when it landed on our table)

Lotsa tourists especially now, in August ... many from the revered countries of France & Germany. While dim-sum on Clement or Irving is much less expensive, most places are dingy (sp?) 
Also, what could be better than eating Chinese food in Chinatown?
author: Matsuo U.

description:
The only reason this is 2 stars is cause the food is decent. I've been here a few times and took my parents when they were in town to visit. I'm not sure if it was because we got there at like 2:30 and they close at 3 or whatever the deal. I doubt it was the time because a big grup came in at like 2:45 and they seated them BUT the service was HORRIBLE this time. LIKE ABSOLUTE WORSE. The servers were rude and it took forever for me to get us waters. No one came to check on us and I had to chase someone down to order off the menu. When the food came, the waiter didnt attempt to clear the empty dishes until we asked. 

While it was the table next to us that experienced this, it def was a wth moment - the table paid and was just talking and the manager (i'm assuming) came to get the signed payment. He looked at it and came back and asked if there was something wrong with the food or service bcecause the tip wasn't that much. I think it was that the food wasn't that great but he literally stood there arguing for like 5 minutes of how tip should be 10 - 15%. OK yea i get it that food and tip aren't related but REALLY? WHAT I DID EXPERIENCE WAS, when we left, i saw one of the waitresses get up and look at our bill to see if we left tip.... seriously?!??!

otherwise, food was ok. its the typical dimsum dishes. variety was low though cause we were there a bit later in the afternoon. time to find another dimsum place.
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
Happy New Year!
We came for new years day brunch with good friends and family and had a blast.  Dim sum is the way to go to start your year off right, I think noodles are good luck like black eyed peas or something.
Anyway its like a warehouse/auction house the way they get you in and out of here and the dear hostess is screaming your number and waving you away in the very loud mic.  I think she said, "You take a cruise now!', or maybe, "never you come this way".  Either way, we did what she said.

I had all meatless fare while we were here.  big fat rolled up noodles, bao, dumplings, chinese broccoli (my fave), spring rolls, tofu...the works. The boyfriend didn't have one thing without meat, he wanted to take the hanging roasted pig home for a nosh in the car.
Dim sum is so fun with friends and especially in china town, so come early, take a cab and stroll to union square on your way out.
author: Kristy C.

description: Its hit and miss here, last time I went, Har Gow were soggy in the middle.
author: Patrick E.

description: I have been in Yelp for years and never had to do this. Ok I am here now for a wedding!  The Brides family is pay a hefty sum for this restaurant!  At least they could do is clean this place!  Words can't describe how bad the  bathroom are. And this whole restaurant smells like mouse piss.  I just wondering what the food will be???
author: Arlene H.

description: One of my favorite places to take ppl visiting from out of town, you can find better dim sum but the atmosphere is great and everything is fresh. Always busy which is a good sign.
author: Matt B.

description:
Chinese restaurants are not known for their customer service.  I don't expect great service, but I don't expect to be ignored either.  However, I do expect GOOD food!

Although New Asia Gardens has never been my favorite dim sum haunt, this had to be the worse experience ever!  

Brought relatives visiting from the East Coast for a a visit.  Suggested they try dim sum from SF and compare their experience to LA.

We arrived at New Asia Gardens on a Saturday around 10:30A.  There was a short wait.  When our number was called, we were directed to a table.  When we found our designated table, there were people sitting there.  I went back to the hostess and told her there were people sitting at the table.  She said I told you table #4.  I said yes there are people sitting at table #4.  She got on her walkie talkie and started yelling at the guy setting up the table.

Finally things got straightened out and we were seated.  Next a server brings out a pot of tea.  (Aren't they suppose to ask what kind of tea you would like?)  I told the guy I wanted Jasmine, he said okay, it's coming.  Never saw him again.  Oh! I also asked the server setting up our table for 2 forks.  He said let me set up your table first.  He never came back.  I asked another guy for a fork and he said okay, but never saw him again.  Tried a third time and finally gave up.

When we ran out of tea, I opened the lid to signal to the waiter we needed hot water.  Lid must have been opened for at least 10 minutes before I could get someone's attention. 

So much for customer service.

Now on to the review of the  food.  Custard tarts were burnt, maybe they were suppose to be Macau style?!?  At least they were warm.  Ribs were fatty and gristly.  The wrapper on the shrimp dumplings were mushy.  If you tried to pick one up with your chopsticks, the wrapper would disintegrate before your very eyes.  The Shu Mai was edible.  The bean curd rolls were bland and pretty tasteless. We added soy and chili sauces to give it some flavor.  The Char Siu Baos were probably the best part of the meal except they were cold.  I could go on, but I think you get the picture.

We were finally able to flag someone to come over and calculate the bill.  I told my husband he should ding them for the lousy service.  Hubby decided to stiff them instead.  When the waiter brought back our change,  he had the nerve to point out that we forgot to leave a tip.  Hubby told him the service sucked and tips were for customer service.  

I guarantee we will not be back!  Thanks but no thanks.....  

The only reason we came to Chinatown was we wanted to pick up some custard tarts from Golden Gate Bakery and they were closed.  What a major disappointment!
author: Susan H.

description: I've been coming to this place my whole life and have never reviewed it. When I was a little kid, the food was pretty good. Service was quick, and portions were large. I used to play games upstairs with my brother and cousins after we ate (mostly dinner parties with really loud Chinese singing and less-than-appealing dancing). In the 10+ years I've been to this restaurant, service and food quality have both declined tremendously. The upstairs for the most part has been closed off due to lack of business. We really only come back for nostalgic reasons and because my grandparents can't let go of their ability to host giant banquets. You can do better in almost every other Chinese restaurant in Chinatown, and it would be far cheaper.
author: Danny C.

description:
Really surprised at the low reviews here.

This place is not fancy nor do they sport the cleanest restrooms but the price is right and the food is tasty!

Just yesterday I went with a group (3 total) and we were filled to the brim with delicious dim sum (including those melt in your mouth shanghai dumplings!) for under $30!  Yes, sometimes they can try to push way too much food on you, but I've learned to stand my ground, take only what I want and ask for the things I don't see.

Also -- I've been here with groups from 2 to 7 and never waited more than 20-25 minutes.  Granted, I have gone on weekdays -- but generally during the 12-1:30 lunch rush.. and they have been pretty good at seating us as quickly as possible.

All in all, I'm down with New Asia.
author: Lily B.

description: Food was okay but they put the tip in for us when I got the credit card receipt to sign. Really?!?!?! I will never come back again.
author: T Y.

description: This place has gone downhill.  It used to be our favorite place for dim sum in Chinatown.  My family and I went there for old time sake because my parent recently returned for a visit.  They wanted go to places we used to visit.  The food was horrible.  It was made with no care.  Everything looked colorless and unappetizing.  Wish they would have kept up with their old standards.
author: Yich L.

description: The food and service is horrendous and this restaurant is filthy. They seated me at a table without changing the table cloth (Filled with oil spots and filthy stains). In addition, my favorite dim sum dish "chicken feet" was a mega disappointment. They steamed the living hell out of it!!! So sad :'(.
author: Janny W.

description:
Dim sum from carts, which was just what we wanted.

Everything we tried from a cart was good: the greens with oyster sauce, the pork belly, various dumplings (all with their own side of sauce), to the tarts and doughnut at the end.

Avoid the red tray of random items - a waiter served us some cold, rubbery BBQ duck from that tray.

Seating and service were quick, even though the place was packed and it was 10:00 AM on a Saturday.

The man who handed us our bill circled the tip area in red, which I found obnoxious, but I would still love to go back.
author: Craig D.

description: AVOID THIS PLACE. Came here as a last resort and it was the biggest mistake of our Sf trip. Came in and was seated quickly, then came by the rude lookalike waiters who didn't come to serve us 15ish minutes from once we were seated. The food was okay, it felt a bit rushed as the food came out a bit messy. Overall the service they provide is absolutely bottom line and rude. Only thing good here is the shui Mai. Oh and there's a manager with glasses here who has absolutely no common sense or any idea what he's talking about when dealing with customers. He's like a oriental robot who can only say TIP?! TIP?! TIP?! Even after you tell him the service was bottom line he can only reply tip?
author: Eric C.

description: Please do not come here for dim sum lunch. The food is just plain awful and disgusting. This place is pricey too.I came because I've haven't been here for a long time.
author: Peter N.

description:
02.18.11

Another reason why Chinatown is going downhill.  I remembered this place being pretty amazing when I was a kid.  It's big, the dim sum is fresh, the ladies are nice.  Now it's about 1.5 out of those three.

They still make my two favorites dishes pretty well: siu mai and ha cheung.  Get it and love it.

Total damage for three: $45
author: Jenny L.

description:
I was born and raised in Chinatown so I think I know my dim sum better than most. This place is the only restaurant that my parents and I would pick for dim sum on the weekends. They have a good selection of items and I love their steamed buns. 

It gets crowded on weekends (duh!) so if you know your party is going to be big, send one person ahead to get a table. They will seat you even if the rest of your party is not present. Regulars, like my dad's extended family, can, and probably would prefer, to refill their own teapots.
author: Maggie L.

description:
The dim sum here was amazzingg (:
Better than some of the stuff we have in Seattle... 
It was however super duper crowded and the wait in line for the bathroom was killer... 
Service was alright... overall, pretty cool place.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
2nd time coming there and it never fails me!
Their service is super fast and the dim sum is delicious! It's $41.80 for 11 dishes of dim sum. Not bad for a delicious dim sum place.
author: Debbie C.

description: I wouldn't eat here. Went on a weekday late afternoon where there were still a good amount of people. First I cannot stand dirty restaurants, and this was one of them. Service was not the greatest especially when the waitresses basically shout amongst themselves, gossiping about other people. It was so rude listening to them trash on others, while having the slowest service, and trying to look past the filth. Many other restaurants with way better dim sum and service. This was my first and last time.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Absolutely horrible. We came for a late lunch. He demanded to charge 1.25/person for tea because it is a "tea place". After we agreed, we got seated, he brought the tea and disappeared forever. They barely had any dim sum left. With nothing appetizing to eat and horrible service, we just left.
author: Andy N.

description:
This place does not deserve the A-OK title. 
Things to Note: 

Do NOT come if you do not speak chinese. luckily my boyfriend did but it still didn't help.  

The carts do not make their way to every table because some tables are situated in the middle of other tables. I was seated next to the stage and so the carts would have to go backwards to get out. Needless to say... no carts wanted to go to me. 

Now....
The dim sum was gross. The har gow had a chewy tough exterior and very little taste in the shrimp. The shrimp wrapped with chow fun had a chewy consistency. The shrimp balls were freaking oily. the turnip cake was barely crisp.

I got a lady to come to me. I got some food, had one bite...ordered a little more in hopes it would get better. Tried those.. then asked for the check and walked out. NOPE didn't finish my dim sum. I just went to mcdonalds.
author: Samantha H.

description: We were here on vacation a couple of weeks ago, had planned to go to another place but they were closed on Mondays and the other places with great yelp reviews were mostly take out places. We wanted a sit down place, which is nearly impossible in Chinatown, but someone pointed us to this place. We ordered the basics: chicken feet, siu mai, rice noodle roll with beef, shrimp steam dumplings, fried pork dumplings, and small order of fried rice for my son. They really did not have anything that I have not seen before so we tried what we normally order. I have had dim sum from Chicago, Vancouver, Seattle, Phoenix, Dallas, Toronto, LA, Salt lake city, Minneapolis, Las Vegas, and others and this has to be the worse I have ever had. Funny thing is I see a bunch of locals here, which I would think they know the difference between good and bad dim sum. Maybe all those places I have been to before were bad and I just have a different reality? I do know between good and bad food and this place really sucks. It cost the most of any of any places I have been before and the lady in front is very rude too. All in all, we went to a bakery across the way and found something a whole lot better.
author: Gary H.

description:
This place is always packed! I was told this was the best Dim Sum in the area, I am from LA and I still think that Monterey Park has some of the best dim sum ever! It took a long time to get a table, we were finally able to sit down and all our our plates were dirty and it took 30 minutes to get us tea.

Food was ok, service was pretty lousy. This place is very large and can sit many people.
author: Kevin K.

description:
By far the best dim sum place.  I come here everytime coming to SF.  Last time, I went on a Thursday at 11:50AM and got a seat for 2 without any waiting. Lucky me!  Food is readily rolling around -- nonstop.  We got everything we wanted in a second.  Food is so delicious I remember coming once from Oakland with friends just for dim sum and went home.

Some complaints are that they are SUPER LOW ON STAFF (i.e. ppl not pushing carts, bringing checks.  I spent 5 min to get a staff to give me a check and that cost me an extra hour of parking at the garage!!) Also, the seats are so close to each other you are definitely sitting with another person to your back.  Oh, and the bathroom is, well let's say slippery.

But no matter what, I think they have already put a spell on me to come back each time I'm in SF.  What can I say? I'm a sucker for really good food =x
author: K C.

description: Disgusting! This place is so dirty I lost my appetite! I was really looking forward to xia long bao at the end of our trip and I chose this place. What a disappointment! The dumplings were not good and it was hard to eat and not notice the degree of uncleanliness all around. We couldn't finish our lunch and had to leave before one of us got sick. Stay away!
author: Bianca D.

description:
Although I am not a regular dim sum eater, I have tried many dim sum in the LA area. This place was passable because it gives you the dimsum experience (with the carts and the dishes) but the quality is just mediocre. 

What I really didn't like is that their servers tries so hard to push food on you and many of the food aren't even dim sum (i.e chow mien and such). 

On the plus side, it does have good variety of food and there wasn't any wait even on sunday at noon. We didn't eat too much so the bill was pretty manageable.
author: Pin X.
