description: Good dim sum. They have delicious chicken feet, roasted duck and har gao. Though the quality of food is inconsistent, the seating service is quick and reliable. Located in the stomach of china town, this place is a must for dim sum diners.
author: Farah Z.

description: One of my favorite places to have Dim Sum when in San Francisco! Great food with a free Chinese lesson ;-)
author: Edward G.

description:
I was here two months ago and I love this place and it fills up quick. The only dim sum house I have seen where they communicate with walkie-talkies. Even with this rush at lunch the staff are still usually slow to act after being seated. Cleanliness also seems to be an ongoing issue here as a trip to the bathroom on the second floor will gross you out. 

The food on the other hand is one of the best dim sum I have had in San Francisco. I came here years ago and it has stayed consistent in taste, still very good.
author: John M.

description: What a busy chinese restaurant in the middle of Chinatown in SF! When my girlfriend and I went to this place, it was full of people. Since most of the servers didn't speak English, it was very difficult for us to order. But somehow we got it done and ordered our favorite dim sum plates. Eh, I'm not good with names to begin with haha. Portion was slightly bigger than other places I've been to and the food tasted pretty decent. Can't remember if food was expensive or not but I'm sure it wasn't out of ordinary. We got here around 11am and we were glad that we came early. A huge crowd came soon after noon and people were lining up outside. Service was very slow but I'm sure that's because there were so many people in the restaurant.
author: Sean K.

description:
I was looking for the screaming cart lady style dim sum IN Chinatown and New Asia totally fit the bill! We had one opportunity to get some dim sum while in SF on a rainy Sunday and hubby wanted to go to Clement St. He was right that we could probably get better food out there, but I also wanted to play tourist in Chinatown. I won. 
I yelped around until I found the reviews for New Asia and off in the cab we went, over hill, through tunnel, running stoplights, to be dropped off at a mostly empty New Asia around 10am on a Sunday.
Not only does this place have screaming cart ladies, it also has headset-wearing hostess calling numbers! Fantastic! We were seated immediately but by the time we left, the waiting area was packed. I was, if not the lone, one of very few, white patrons in the restaurant. Lots of old people drinking tea. Lots of families.
It was a bit challenging finding vegetarian options for the veg. member of our group. We ordered some noodles that took about a day and a half to come out, but we weren't in a hurry.
We ordered a pile of food - ended up taking a lot with us (including most of those noodles) to be enjoyed later. Total bill (inc. tip) for 5 = $78
I would go again. But next time I'd go to Clement St. Hubby gets to win sometimes, too.
author: Diana H.

description:
Came here on New Year's after a crazy night of partying. 

Dim sum seems to hit the spot when you are hungover. 

Nothing too special about this place other than the Lobster Noodles- holy cow that was delicious. 

Glad they had cart ladies!  Seems like it should be a standard for dim sum but not always.  They didn't pressure me too badly either! 

The wait was pretty ridiculous at noon but there's a waiting area to sit. This place is HUGE!  Saw pictures on the walls of people using it for wedding and events. 

Enjoyed the food but I wholeheartedly feel that South Bay has better dim sum than Chinatown in SF.
author: Anya R.

description:
Disclaimer: this review is from an experience I had in August 2008.  If you're like me and always look at the dates to see how recent they are so you can track a restaurant's ups and downs, I thought you'd appreciate that disclosure.

I'm not a dim sum connoiseur or anything, but I'd like to think I know my basics, and this dim sum experience was great, if a little unusual.  The place was crowded, but we got seated almost right away.  Almost as soon as our butts hit the chair, three or four ladies with carts crowded up to us and started waving their wares around in the air and yelling, creating a very chaotic air where we really had trouble distinguishing what was being offered.  It was my boyfriend's first time eating dim sum and I had cautioned him against making any gestures or facial expressions that could possibly be interpreted as 'I may want this dish...' because before you know it the dish will be on your table and the waitress will be gone.  He did pretty well at this onslaught, we chose a few dishes, the women went along their way, and we began eating.

(I'm still not sure why they rushed us like that.  Maybe our table just happened to be on a collision course?)

We had some kind of shrimp chive dumpling that had something extra in it (not crack, but with the same effect) that made it sooo savory and good.  Shrimp-stuffed eggplant followed, and the eggplant was nicely seared and still soft in the middle.  

At this point another lady came over with her cart.  She had some kind of beef wontons that were filled with broth.  She REALLY wanted us to have these wontons.  We were indifferent.  She kept insisting, 'it's good!  it's good!"  We kept being indifferent.

And then... she set them down, stamped our receipt, and rushed away so fast that we were left gaping!  Did one of us make a 'maybe so' face?!  Not that we were aware of!

But the beef broth dumplings WERE good.  Not that that excuses it.  But, I'm sorry, they WERE good.  Everything was.  I couldn't complain about a single dish we got.

Maybe just less overbearing service, as a suggestion?
author: Hannah E.

description:
You walk along Pacific and there is no way you would expect such a large dim sum place. It's massive for Chinatown. There's even an upstairs.

Shame the food could not live up to the dream of a good dim sum place in Chinatown.

Having been a couple of times before writing this review, I'd have to say the dim sum is average and probably on the lower side of average based on the places that I have been to across the world.

One thing that stood out was the cheung fun which was understeamed and chewy when it should be steaming hot and almost slurpy like. There's few things I can't eat and that was one of them. The other dishes, e.g siu mai, har gow, beef balls etc. were standard.

The other thing was the layout. I can understand you want to ram in the masses and put tables wherever possible but that means carts cannot get around and if you are unlucky enough to be in a far corner or worse in the middle of a bunch of tables, it means not being able to see the carts. 

Overall a shame really.
author: Nick L.

description:
After walking through Chinatown for hours this past weekend we decided to have dim sum at this restaurant after seeing the massive crowd of people waiting to dine there earlier that morning. It is quite a large restaurant and it was packed with Chinese diners, yay! 

Usually that is what I hope for when trying any new restaurant that specializes in a distinct cuisine.

We both were amazed at the large size of each dim sum serving as well as the price. For $23 we must have had 8 different dishes: including duck!

Still we both agreed, it was not as tasty as the dim sum served in Las Vegas restaurants. Sorry world, but Vegas really does seem to have the lock on dim sum. Who would have thought?

One note: they serve dim sum until 3pm on Sundays.
author: Autumn H.

description:
In my 35 years in living in this planet,I've been to over 100 weddings including my-own,friends,families,and past and present co-workers. More than half of the banquets that I've attended were held at this disgusting restaurant in the heart of Chinatown.

My long-time friend Wilson and his wife had their banquet here. The recent banquet at this restaurant,that my family and I attended, conditionally has never changed. The atmosphere was filled with filth and has aged dramatically, which means it is time for a remodel. The floors including the bathroom,were dirty and sticky as a adhesive sticker. The stereo/ entertainment system were old,and have no capable wires or adapters to the laptop or IPods. The only positive addition to the restaurant was acquiring 10 flat-screen tv's,installed to the walls,for those people who sits far away and can watch the MC's and/or center-stage through the TV. They also do Karaoke during the weeknights. I'm also optimistic of the selection in music they play during the week.

The combination set-dinner portions served at the restaurant,by the request of the newlyweds, were horrible in many ways. The peking duck was oily. The fried-rice was dried and crunchy. It was probable leftovers that was left behind from a previous wedding the week before. The only good thing about the banquet was the long-awaited dessert of the wedding-cake,which came from Schubert's. An "excellent" choice in dessert and worth the wait.

Eventhough the aging condition of this restaurant has flaws,it is still the most popular restaurant for banquets and daily brunches. They have banquets every weekends,and with the constant busy schedule,remodeling this place seems unlikely and tough to plan. I'm very fortunate that our wedding-banquet was not held here,and my strong-advice to you single Yelp-member,who plans to get marry in the future,don't do your banquet dinner at New Asia. You will actually thank me from getting severely ill.
author: Matt G.

description: This place is ALWAYS crowded on weekends for dim sum, and I'm not entirely sure why. The dim sum is ok, but not spectacular. Items I would recommend is their Lobster Noodle, Po Tat (Portuguese style egg tart), the Fried Taro Ball, and their rice noodles. The Shrimp har gow and rice noodles (cheung fun) is ok too. It looks pretty dirty, and everything looks Again, it's not a worth the wait type of place, but somehow we still come and wait..
author: Ken W.

description: A nice, and quite spacious dim sum restaurant in Chinatown. The carts are generous, and the food was good.
author: Wade M.

description:
I'm torn between rating them well because the few things we had was really tasty, but @ the same time the service could definitely have been better...

I will note that we did come late (around 2ish) BUT it was really unorganized, we had to seat ourselves and all of the tables were incredibly dirty and gross. The waiters were upset because their tables were broken and the expanding portions kept falling into my aunt's lap. 

Like another reviewer said, I've also never been to a dim sum place where you have to flag down the carts or they just passed us up on MULTIPLE occasions. Also, before we were finished ordering, they were already onto the next table...uh, whaaat? 

It's really expensive for what you get and also the grunge. I think that Ton Kiang was cheaper for the service and amount of food we received. 

I wanted to like you New Asia...but it's not really worth it for me to trek down to Chinatown to get such bad service and to pay for such grunge.
author: Alison N.

description:
Back in the day, (and by this I mean 20+ years ago...wow, I just realized I'm really dating myself here) this was *THE* place to have a full-on, decked-out-to-the-hilt wedding banquet with the Chinese dragons and gaudy ambiance.

Now New Asia is more of a place for everyday dim sum.  It's two floors huge, but still always crowded and a wait.  Average dim sum, moderate prices (I'm a tad perturbed they charge $1 per person for tea) and standard Chinese food service (this means service is pretty much non-existent).  Super plump shrimp dumplings, fresh and crunchy Chinese broccoli, yummy chee cheung fun, and specials like lobster noodles.  This place is a must-visit Chinatown landmark for any out of towner and a to-go spot for locals and anyone else who makes the occasional day trip to SF.  Basically, everyone!
author: Sandee L.

description:
One of the more pricey dim sum restaurants in Chinatown, but also one of the more cleaner ones. 

I used to come here all the time with my grandpa but we thought the food was not that great and that the price is high only for the cleanliness. So we decided to try other dim sum spots in CT (Chinatown) and found out that the quality of the food is about the same. Ever since then, we stop coming to this place.

If you ever eating in CT, do not come here because it is not that good and it is pricey.  Go somewhere else and enjoy the same quality of dim sum for a cheaper price.
author: Daniel L.

description:
3.5 Star

Came here for dim sum today after walking around in the Chinatown festival. Got seated once my parents, bro and I entered the restaurant. It was crowded but got served pretty quickly considering the fact that they were so busy at the time.

They serve dim sum here with push carts at this restaurant and this is what dim sum places typically do. We ordered shrimp dumpling, shanghai dumpling, egg tart, siu mai, fong jau (soysauce chicken feet), chiu jou fun gor, steam bbq pork bun and lau sa bao. (sorry guys... don't really know the english names)

All of the dim sum we ordered was piping hot and fresh! It was pretty good but was hoping for more dim sum selections. Unfortunately they were running out of dim sum food because it was nearly 3pm in the afternoon... so I got here a little too late.

Customer service at this restaurant is good... they got me what I wanted fairly quickly... I will definitely come back again!
author: Mi H.

description:
The last time I was here the place wasn't even a Dim Sum restaurant. It must be a good 15 - 20 years since the last time. Got here around 12 noon and didn't leave until 2PM and during that whole time the place was packed. 

Food was good and the service was typical of a Dim Sum restaurant LOL Just kidding. Service was good and the price was right too.
author: nasdaq y.

description: Fantastic tasting, beautifully prepared and very fresh dim sum. So Sad that we both got food poisoning. Since the food was definitely fresh, i think this comes down to a worker hand sanitation issue. New Asia, please conduct training on the importance of thorough hand washing and hygiene with your staff. Terrible to produce such wonderful food and have it ruined by poor hygiene.
author: hari m.

description: Some friends and I (total of three of us) are visiting from Los Angeles and strolled through China Town and came across this restaurant. The restaurant setting seems like a banquet hall, and a place that looks like events are held there. The table had a pot of tea, and you assume it's complimentary. We were seated, and we waited over ten minutes and no one came to greet us or start us off. We had to flag people down, we basically did throughout our entire time there. We had to stop someone to take an order, and no one cared to come to the table. I ordered a chicken fried rice & it was decent. My boyfriend ordered a pan fried noodle and that was delicious! But after our meal, we had to flag someone down for a check again. And we get charged three tea's and only two of my friends ordered that. I explained that to the server and he tried to convince me that they charge that per person when I didn't even have a cup of tea. It took them 5 minutes to finally just take off a tea that was $1.75 and overall the service was just horrible. That was the worst experience I had in all of San Fransisco. My friend didn't want to tip because he didn't feel like his or any of our experience were good in any way. I work at a restaurant myself and I've always understood the importance of not just tip, but the importance of service. People tip because they feel like they were served well, they don't need to feel forced to. My friend signed the bill and she stopped him and said tip!!! You forgot tip! And he personally didn't want to. She goes ahead and says "you have to tip $5" forcing my friend to leave a tip! What kind of disaster!!! I said "he actually can tip what he wants" and he tipped upon force! I do not recommend this place at all.
author: Maria H.

description: I came here for dim sum Sunday with a party of 5. I'd recommend making recommendations for a big party. Food is fairly decent and overall we were satisfied with the quality of the dishes. My only complaint is that I didn't know that tea was going to cost $1 per person. We shared one pot between the five of us and had to shell out 5 bucks. I'd definitely come again but will skip the tea.
author: Jay S.

description: Been here a few times. Once for lunch for dim sum which I thought was pretty good. Lots of variety and different plates to choose from. It was very crowded! Next time, we went for dinner and the dim sum was not offered. Thought we would stay and eat dinner anyways. Bad idea!  Food tasted just like the local hole in the wall restaurant that holds 25 people except it cost a whole lot more. Also, they had karaoke that was making my ears bleed and it was super loud. You can't even talk to the person next to you.
author: Becky D.

description: I've been here with my family for a lot of times. Food is good, service is OK -well, when they are not very busy. The reason we usually choose this restaurant in Chinatown is, it is really big. You don't need to wait for like an hour, while some restaurants are actually beyond capacity.
author: Katok K.

description:
Coming from a New Yorker who has been craving dim sum since we landed in LA, we were voyage to find some really good dim sum. The locals we have encountered introduced us to New Asia Restaurant. First impressions are always  what sets in the mood for things. 
When we first arrived here, it was PACKED. Saturday morning, ok no biggie. We've experienced worse back in New York. It took us roughly 15 mins to get seated (seat 41). It was seat 18 when we got there. 
To judge a dim sum place, i judge them on their food. Portions, Freshness and taste.We ordered chicken feet(2), short ribs(pai gwut), chueng fun(beef), har gau, siu mai, and white tripe. We tried to order the regular tripe in brown sauce.. and flagged many carts for it but couldnt find it.

Chicken feet: Too hard, not tender enough. I guess cause it wasnt cooked long enough. Had to actually chew on it till it broke apart. Compared to the ones in New York, it had the "melt in your mouth" feeling. 2.5/5

Short ribs: OK, wasn't that bad. 3/5

Cheung Fun(beef): ..... The beef inside had no flavor at all, tasted more like regular cheung fun with nothing inside.1/5

Har Gau: The shrimp inside was alright. I had a big problem with the glutinous wrapping it came with. It was WAY to chewy for a har gau. 1/5

Siu Mai: Im not sure if this is the standard they make siu mai now, but the plate that we got tasted old. The wonton skin that they wrap around it was dry and hard. It had a brownish color on it which i dont believe should be the color of siu mai. It should be a bright yellow color. 2/5

White Tripe: This tripe was actually a little decent. It wasnt to the point where chewing on it made it an olympic sport but was desirable for seconds. It just lacked a bit of spicy kick to it. 3/5

Service: There are so many things they can improve on the service. Besides cleaning up after the tables and putting new settings, perhaps they can actually serve their patrons? I had to flag the same waiter down 3 times just to get 3 glasses of water. In the end.. i just stood up and tapped another waiter on his back for some water.

I'm not sure if New York has set the standard for good dim sum for me, but the dim sum at this place wasn't good enough to come back every other weekend to have dim sum with family or friends.
author: Steven B.

description:
My parents were regulars when dad was still with us.  Back then, I will join them once in a while.  Dad knows people and will tell me what's good or not, what's fresh...yeah, I miss him dearly.  

Anyway, for dad's sake - we came here for dim sum.  It was late, after 1pm, and it wasn't packed like normal but the food was beyond subpar.  Maybe because it's no longer the peak hours so they won't be offending their regulars but simply tourists and schmucks like us?   Who knows but what little we had (we just couldn't risk anymore bad tasting dim sum after 4 dishes) were just not good - let's say it's bad enough that even hubby won't finish it, enough said.

A table of 2 americans sat nearby and they were so ignored and frustrated that they left no tips - this is the first we've seen.  We didn't go that far but it will take some serious convincing for us to return...
author: Gloria H.

description: Came here with a party of 6. The entire time I felt like I was in the middle of a fish market. The waiters were literally SCREAMING across the floor and moving left and right so fast I was scared that one of them would hit me. I like the setting because the ceilings are super high and the place is very lively and crowded. However, the food is typical of any dimsum place - cheap and oily. Overall I would come here again for a special occasion, but not for regular eating out.
author: Kat Z.

description:
It's the only place in sf I go for dim sum!
My family and have been coming here for years
author: Victor G.

description: We had our wedding here in May and we took over the entire restaurant. New Asia was very flexible with my needs. I had a lot of special requests and they were able to accomodate them. I like the restaurant because it is large with high ceilings. Everyone loved the food and the price was extremely reasonable. If you are having a large Chinese banquet wedding, I would highly recommend this restauarant.
author: Helen C.

description:
I just had dim sum here this morning and I would say it was so so... This place has been around forever from what I remember. The place is a little bit run down so don't expect too much if you are going to try this place out. 

We got in to the restaurant pretty early, maybe around 9:30 - 10am. The wait was only abut 5 - 10 minutes for us. 

As I sat down, I already noticed my chair wobbly and then as I sat down, I noticed my side of the table was folded inward (usually it expands for larger parties). But the problem was that my expansion piece wouldn't lock into place so it really sucked having it in the way.

The food was average as I've had better. I would say the price wasn't too high so I guess we got what we paid for at this place.

I do have to say it took the carts a long time to bring food around to us. We even tried asking the waiters for specific Dim Sum when we waited for a long time, but they waiter told us don't worry, it will come around.
author: Anthony L.

description:
I dug this place... it was huge... the carts kept coming... and very authentic... really everything I'm looking for in a dim sum restaurant. The oft-mentioned egg tarts were the best I've had, bar none. 

Staples like the sui mai and ha gow were large and tasty. The ha chong fun was so-so, the shrimp balls were very nice.

Damn, I'm getting hungry...
author: Sean B.

description:
Let me sum this up....  DO NOT EAT HERE if you have cleanliness standards for the establishments you choose to frequent. 

I am not sure what turned me off more:

1.) The horrible service and very rude staff.

2.) The only fish in the seafood display tank floating dead.

3.) The horribly dirty tables with stained table cloths and crumbs that were not mine. 

4.) The lack of Dim Sum at 7pm at night on a Monday.

With all that said the food was very good. I probably should have waited to post to see if I am alive and well tomorrow but heck there is always an edit available.....  I hope!
author: Jonathon S.

description:
One of the strangest restaurants I have ever been to - twice.

I ate here for dinner with a group of about 20 family friends - all Chinese.
The first time most of the food I did not like - not because it was "bad" but it wasn't for me.... I tried the chicken feet and jellyfish testicles and I could  not enjoy them (I know, I suck). I wish we had tried their dim sum.

However, the duck is good, the lobster lo mein is good, the west lake beef soup is great and the shrimp fried rice was wonderful. 

Service is AWFUL - very slow, complicated to get a bigger table and water refilled. 

Here is the best part.... they have ballroom dancing - which many of the older patrons participate in - to a karaoke singer (her and him are C- talent singers), who are belting out classics such as: Lady Gaga, 80s love songs, a few choice oldies and many more. 

They give group lessons, some are decked out in ballgowns. The singing is LOUD - like awfully loud, it hurts. The dancing is the best people watching EVER. There are also 2 big screen tvs - one with Asian movies on and the other with Asian celebrity reports or something - all have Chinese subtitles.

You can bring your own alcohol if you want. Bathrooms are upstairs - for prime viewing the craziness on the dance floor.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I love my parents dearly, but one sort of difficult thing about traveling with my dad is that everything is a negotiation.  I can't just pick out the best places on Yelp and say, "This is where we're going."  I have to take distance, parking, where some random woman on the street told my dad we should eat, and a variety of other factors into account.  In other words, choosing a restaurant is not all about ME and my own "research" methods.  I hate it when that happens.

But in the case of New Asia, it worked out just fine.  Even though my dad decided singlehandedly that we should eat here based on the recommendation of aforementioned random woman on the street, it was some of the best dim sum I've ever had.  I was hella nervous because of course as soon as he pronounced our destination I looked up the Yelp reviews on my Treo and they were none too glowing.  But either we were here on the right day or my scale for great Asian food is skewed by my residence in Texas, because I loved it.

We arrived at New Asia before it opened on a Saturday.  By the time the doors were unlocked, there was a substantial crowd waiting.  One person told us that New Asia had new owners as of a couple of months ago, so that gave me some hope despite the mediocre Yelp reviews.  And once we got inside, I was delighted to see that the very spacious interior filled up very quickly, and maybe 95% of the clientele was Asian.  A good sign.

The carts started coming, and we started eating.  And eating.  And eating.  It was awesome.  The shu mai were fantastic - plump, flavorful, and with a little bit of crab roe sprinkled on top.  We also tried a number of things that I'd had before elsewhere and hadn't loved previously, and all were great (unfortunately, I'm not real clear on what any of them were, so I can't list them here).  The only minor beefs I had were that the har gau weren't that good (we had some much better ones at Gourmet Market later in our trip), the spareribs were a little sparse, and I wished they had some pan fried dumplings (I didn't see any at all - only steamed).  Also, while the custard tarts (dan ta) were seriously delicious and super buttery, they didn't taste at all like the traditional dan ta - the filling wasn't "eggy" enough.

Decor is "Chinatown fancy" - in other words, it was probably nice-ish by Chinatown terms at one time, but it's kind of outdated and a little worse for the wear at this point.  And I would not recommend using the restrooms here unless it is an emergency.

Still, for great dim sum, I'll overlook much.  Next time I'm in Chinatown in search of dim sum, New Asia will definitely be on my list.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Ginger egg tarts!!!!

A nice break from the traditional egg tarts (dan tat), these ginger flavored ones are really good! Gotta give them a try! Trust me, I crave them all the time after I had a bite of these pieces of heaven!

Their dim sum is not too bad either, although I wish their churng fun was most silky and less rough =[
author: Maggie C.

description:
i've had dim sum in l.a., ny and now s.f. and i would have to say of all the places, this one had the best service.  this was the only dim sum i tried in frisco and i have to say, i was very impressed! the service was absolutely incredible, staff was so friendly and prompt. not like the places here in l.a. where they are rude and have bad attitudes. 

the place is pretty big, it has one big dining area. we went on a friday, during lunch time. it was our first day there as our flight arrived @ 7am. i actually had planned on having dim sum for lunch so i had a very light breakfast. 

i had read reviews of various dim sum restaurants in s.f. and i remembered reading about this one. so as we strolled through chinatown (which is huge btw), i pulled out my trusty blackberry and did a quick search on yelp mobile for a dim sum restaurant nearest to the location we were at. and new aisa came up, so we walked one block north on stockton, looked left on pacific and there it was! 

the place was packed, we waited about 10 minutes before we got seated. the staff there spoke cantonese and broken english. they didnt have many cart ladies....probably about 4 or 5 that i saw. and a handful of them carry trays around. 

the food was very authentic and delicious! we were surprised to have gotten the BBQ Pork Bun (cha sao bao) so quickly, its my absolute favorite! at other dim sum places, it usually takes awhile to get them cuz theyre so popular. 

for the two us, about 10 dishes later, our bill came up to be approx $35. not bad at all, we even had leftovers to take back to the hotel with us.
author: Sara C.

description:
Avoid at all costs.

The culturally insensitive chinese lady at the front will shout and yell at customers in chinese and english. She will hasily point you towards your table and leave you to look for a chinese waiter in the back of the restaurant waving to you. While you have some expectation that you won't get the best service at a chinese restaurant, getting yelled at by a rude lady on a loud loudspeaker is not my ideal start of the morning.

- The table was broken and uncomfortable.
- The table was filthy when we got seated.
- Plates were disgusting, had to wipe them off with a napkin. 
- Lukewarm and poorly assembled food.

Plenty of other options around the area - look for something else.
author: Kevin G.

description: Great food, not bad price, and huge dumplings!
author: Lindsay L.

description:
It's too bad you can't give negative stars.

The dim sum is not that great. I've found better elsewhere. In fact, any other dim sum joint has something comparable or better. I wasn't wow-ed.  I've been eating dim sum since I was a kid, so I've had a whole lot of this stuff and I know what's good and what isn't.

They threw a bunch of paper mats on a dirty table, threw cups and place and dropped some tea. Then our servers disappeared. There are a bunch of push carts and generic pushy servers, so you have to make sure you say no so they don't slam random food you don't want (my friend ended up with a 20 plate of dim sum this way once) and be firm. 

The worst part of our experience is that they provided sub par service (and I'm the type of person who doesn't care about service so this is saying a lot) and they yelled at us for not tipping enough. Really, yelling at your customers for not giving you enough tip even though they didn't even provide halfway decent service? I've never been to any establishment that is this rude. Even in countries where you don't tip I've had better service.


Please, I am not patronizing this business nor recommending anyone to go here. I'd rather take my business else where like to ANY of the dim sum joints on Clement Street.
author: Lilly K.

description: My visiting cousins wanted real dim sum (selected from carts) near their hotel on Kearny. This place fit the bill perfectly. We're not adventurous eaters but we respect other cuisines. My cousin ate duck feet and liked them a lot. We more timid eaters had several kinds of dumplings, bbq pork buns, and egg custard tarts. The servers were helpful, food & Tsing Tao were served quickly; tables looked clean to me and like everyone says, there is a delightful atmosphere of local families looking very happy as they chow down with everyone from tiny babies to ancient grandparents. Only thing I did not like was the roast duck. Be sure and have some of the bright green broccoli; it's a great palate cleanser between all of the savory and rich flavors.
author: JJ H.

description:
I grew up eating here so this is the Dim Sum standard. You either are as good as New Asia or you go home.

Never a bad experience here. The wait is nuts on a weekend. Parking is not good. It is always crowded. If you don't speak Cantonese, you're screwed.

I like the fried wontons with sweet and sour sauce. and the Sweet Tofu. and the Shrimp Rice Rolls.

3 stars for the food alone.
author: Mike W.

description:
DIM SUM REVIEW:
This place is so busy during lunch. Definitely request a table along the pathway of the dim sum carts; otherwise, you'll never be able to get anything to eat. 

Some of the dim sum/entree items I tried were:
- Shrimp dumplings- Lots of shrimp with very little shrimp paste. Pretty good!
- Chicken feet- Meaty, but not spicy
- BBQ pork buns- okay
- Chives dumpling- had cashews in the filling, which gave it a nice crunch
- House Fried Seafood noodles- The noodles were very odd. The cooks probably didn't use the regular egg noodles, since the color didn't look right.
- Beef Chow Fun- Oily, but the flavor was good.

I think this place is overrated with the dim sum. Service is lacking since we asked for cold water several times. 

BANQUET REVIEW:
Just a couple hours ago, we were eating lunch at New Asia. Now we had a wedding banquet at the same restaurant! 

We were in the banquet hall located on the second level. The setting was intimate as there were 9 tables overall.

The food came out so quickly! At a typical Chinese banquet, the guests would wait over an hour to be served.

Overall, the food was pretty good. It's 10x better than banquet food at Empress of China. The menu was typical, but some entrees stood out better than others.

1) Special Combination plate of chicken, duck, pork, jelly fish- The meat had mostly bones.

2) Shrimp in crab claw- The shrimp was hot! I burned the roof of my mouth since I was greedy to eat it. The shrimp ball was a good size! Nice and plump.

3) Scallops and prawns- Everything was sauteed and with veggies. Nothing too special.

4) Shark fin soup with crab meat! Yay!

5) Abalone with mushrooms and bitter choy- The abalone wasn't overcooked! 

6) Crispy chicken- Aww.. there weren't any shrimp chips. The skin wasn't that crispy, but the chicken was moist.

7) Lobster - very meaty!

8) Smoked "cod" - This was Chilean Sea Bass!!! YUMMY! I devoured my smooth and fatty pieces. Best dish of the night!

9) Red bean dessert- Someone burned the red bean :( You can taste it! Yuck.
author: Jackie S.

description: It's really good! The taste is very authentic with great quantity and quality, especially the durian dessert! It's real and fresh durian inside ! The only problem is that they are too busy! poor service.
author: Dandan Z.

description:
The wait may be long, the tables may be disorganized, but this is the place to go for cheap yet good dimsum in Chinatown.  

The one offputting thing is the $1 per person charge for watery tea.

Oh, it'd be best if someone in the group can speak Chinese (preferably Cantonese).  Otherwise, the numbering system and front desk may be a bit hard to communicate with.
author: Eeway H.

description: I came here for an event.  Thus I happened to experience some of the blandest Chinese food I have tasted since I randomly pulled off of a highway in rural South Carolina.  I imagine that the event picked this venue cause it could fit a large group, but if you are an individual, do yourself a favor and eat at any random place elsewhere in Chinatown instead.
author: Mavery M.

description:
This is a review for their baquet dinner.  Cheesy decor.  No ice bucket on table for drinks.  It's really weird that the steamed rice comes in a metal container shapes like an ice bucket.  Appetizer dish of BBQ pork (not red color) and fatty duck left me with no appetite at all. 

Waiters asked us to put our empty soup bowls on plate so he can take them away.  Terrible service!!
author: J B.

description:
Really disappointing experience.  For its size, the small number of carts is truly ridiculous.  It took nearly 10 minutes before we got any food.  And everything I asked for the lady said, "Oh all gone" or "Next cart"... and then didn't even offer an alternative.

Every other time I've gone to a larger dim sum place with carts, I've been bombarded with choices and eventually you have to turn them down.  This place seemed to have given up trying.  

And the sticky rice wrapped in a lotus leaf was horrible.  It had a grainy, cornmeal like texture to it... really strange.
author: Paul H.

description:
I walked through the doors with my family. I was famished. As soon as the lady screamed, "DIRRRTY-FIE, NUMBA DIRRTY-FIE!", we made a beeline to the back of the restaurant. There, a waiter asked us what tea we would like, and my uncle replied with "Oolong" in Chinese. We sat. 

A cart rolled around several minutes later. Spare ribs with rice noodle rolls. Tripe. Chicken feet. Siu mai. I wiped down my chopsticks (and you should too -- Chinese places are pretty dirty) and chose one of the four pieces of siu mai. I broke it in half with my chopsticks, and

WHAT THE HELL IS THAT? IS THAT A HAIR?!

Not believing my eyes, I tugged on it. It was of the thick variety. (Dare I say...pubic like?) I was thinking it might be a long, black, Chinese herb. Nope. It was a hair. Nearly two inches long, and thick. 

My stomach lurched. My mother called the waiter over, and he took my plate away, as well as the siu mai. Then, he took it off our tab after consulting with the dude in the blue shirt.

Forever will I be traumatized. I pledge to always cut my food into little pieces and inspect it from now on. 

Now, if we were NOT Chinese, I suppose they would have done that AND offered to deduct a certain amount from the bill. (Yes, I was forced by my mother to stick around and eat a little bit more.) 

In the words of an African American preacher:
I ask you brothas and sistas: is this FAIR? 

NO!
author: Betty T.

description:
My friend and I have been religiously  going to this restaurant  for Breakfast for over 10 years now every time whenever we go to San Francisco(approximately 4 or 5 times a year),  maybe because we always went to Bay Area on the weekends, I was vastly surprised at those bad reviews left by Yelpers, because we always found their foods fresh and delicious, we tried foods from other Dim Sum served restaurants whenever new restaurants were open, but at the end we always went back to New Asia. I've been revolving around Chinese foods and restaurants all my life(my family and relatives own them all over the little city I live in), so I can say I am not a novice when it comes to Chinese foods. 

If you are looking for a great service in Chinese restaurants around San Francisco, you will be disappointed, you will be lucky if you aren't be rude at.
author: Chung W.

description: Great tasting dim sum at a great price! There were seven of us in the party and we ate until we stuffed ourselves. The bill came out to about $100-- ridiculous! I recommend trying the soup dumplings and egg custard tarts.
author: chris s.

description:
don't know what's up with the low reviews.  i grew up here in chinatown been to new asia since a kid.  dim sum mostly, but few times for weddings back in the day.  if you coming to chinatown don't expect service, it just ain't happening.  what you should expect is rude and loud chinamans, dirty bathrooms but great food.  that's new asia.  ain't nothing wrong with the dim sum, it matches totally with price and the wait time especially with more than 6 people.  try getting american brunch at some yuppy small ass place with 6 or more people.  trust me i've done both and you will wait forever at some eggs benedict spot in north beach in lines and then you don't even sit with your folks.  WEAK... i'm so over these "brunch" spots that people be waiting forever on a saturday morning.  just eggs and pancakes, not too hard to make.  dim sum, do not try to make.  you want pretty dim sum and clean, go pay 5 times more at yank sing.  although i love yank sing's shanghai dumplings for 12 bucks a rack, i come to new asia for the basics.  ha gow, siu mai, churng fun...

and check out the ambience below...i'm gonna check off "Classy", LOL
author: Kevin L.

description:
Came here a lot of times with my boyfriend and his family to "yum chaa." This place is always crowded, but it takes a little while to get a seat. 
I don't like that a lot of their foods are kinda REALLY oily, but then, aren't most chinese restaurants like that?
I prefer the dim sum two blocks up from this place.
author: Sophia G.

description: Decent dim sum place. Come here whenever parents are visiting and seeing the gparents. There was this one time that a waiter said "That's not enough tip yet/ That's not 10 or 15% yet." Who does that?! Anywho.. service is not that good.
author: Amy C.

description:
And now for an episode of Reenactment Theatre

Almost Teenage Daughter: "Mommy, I want Dim Sum for lunch."

Mother: "Good idea!"

Father: "Let's check Yelp. Here's a place. It says we walk 3 blocks and turn left then another 2 blocks and a right turn then a left. (walk walk walk) . .  Ah ha! Here it is!" (We are at a funky little walk up window.)

ATD: "Noooo! I want a place where I can sit down. I'm hungry!" 

ATD does the pouty arms crossed eye squint foot stomp.

F: "But there's a line out the door... I bet it's good...." 

F's voice does the sing-songy upward spiral like he's trying to coax a 3-year-old into taking a bite of broccoli.

ATD: "NO! I want to sit down. I want the carts. I want steamed hum bao."

F (shaking head in sorrow and disbelief almost as though his cat has died): "Siiiiiiiiggggghhhhhhhhh" 

M: "Hey, look, right here - it says dim sum. Let's look inside"

Cut to interior: a vast crowded sea of mostly Asian faces. Carts everywhere. 

F: "Let's see what it says on Yelp."

M: "Oh, please. Who cares? Look at this place. It's packed on Monday morning. Don't  people work in San Francisco? We're on vacation. What's their excuse?"

It was absolutely delicious from carts that came at break-neck speed and just what we all craved. More importantly we found it mere seconds before the pout turned into the pre-teen meltdown. For that alone New Asia earned 5 tasty stars.
author: Carrie L. B.

description:
This review is based on a visit Sunday morning for Dim Sum.

Good basic dim sum.  If you want authenticity then this is the place to go.   First language spoken is Cantonese but don't worry if you speak English you can still order.   99% of the clientele when we were in Sunday morning for dim sum were Chinese. 

Read some of the negative reviews. OK if you want authenticity then things are going to be a little more chaotic that Westerners are used to.  

 Didn't go to the restrooms when we visited.  All that being said the waitresses were friendly to us even though they were rushed. 

  We were lucky to be able to get a table in front soon after we arrived and at first we were wondering where the carts were but after about five minutes they started rolling by.  Enjoy the jasmine tea while you wait.

For four people leaving the place stuffed I think the bill was around $34.
author: Kool M.

description: This is kinda hard coz there's no option for ZERO stars!!! I searched for the best dimsum in Chinatown and this is what came up. We went and ordered from the first dimsum cart and they said there's no more after that cart. We said we'll jst order from the menu but every waiter/ waitress we called either ignored us or said "later". We decided to wrap it up and moved to another dimsum place. Asking for our check and paying took about another 15mins. Never recommending this place and never coming back here!!!!
author: Leah G.

description: I got gypped.  On Sunday, I went with my family of 4 to enjoy what I thought was decent low priced dim sum.  We ordered 11 dishes and the bill came out to $52.  Outrageous pricing for such a dirty joint.  The only plate that was out of the ordinary was this 3 piece Durian pastry.  I thought the last time we had it was $4 something and the cashier who came to resolve my billing said it was an extra special plate and it's $8.  $2 + for each piece.  Other than that, we had 2 plates of Beef Rice Roll, 1 Beef Meat Ball, 1 Shui Mai, 1 Har Gow, 1 ribs, 1 tripe, 2 egg yolk bun and 1 deep fried pastry with taro.  All ordinary stuff.  I am never going back there again.
author: Jay Z.

description:
Nothing groundshattering, but it has pretty good dim sum. Service is a lil lacking since its kinda a giant place.

And its loud, very loud. But as are most dim sum places. Lots of fresh dishes and not greasy
author: Justin N.

description:
My bf and I always come here with his mom for dim sum whenever we take her shopping in Chinatown. It's part of the routine of the day. Drive up, pick up his mom, go to Chinatown, shop a little, go eat at New Asia, keep shopping, go home.

The dim sum here is decent. Lots of locals and tourists but the wait goes by fairly quickly.  It's helpful if you go with a local who can speak Chinese. Luckily for me, I didn't have to mime a thing. 

It's a pretty typical Chinese dim sum restaurant. Lots of tables squished together and rolling carts filled with food. The last few times, they didn't even bother changing the table linens after it's been dirtied by previous diners. Just thin paper covers that soak up some of the stains left behind.  

But it's still part of the routine. I'll be here again soon enough.
author: Julia W.

description: Big place, pretty cheap for Dim Sum. Got lucky on a Saturday and didn't have to wait-miracle.  Not in love with it but not bad if you have the cravings...very loud.
author: F T.

description:
I have been coming here for the last 30 years and I felt it was time to do a review for this place. This place brings back a lot of good memories with my grandparents, every time that I visit.

I highly recommend this place if you're looking for good dim sum. The food is always consistent and hot off the cart. I also highly suggest that you bring someone that speaks Chinese too (Cantonese seems to be the preferred language). Be warned...this place is always chaotic.

The only reason I didn't give this place 5 stars is because of the cleanliness. Although I don't mind it, I'm mostly there for the food and to visit my grandparents.
author: Spencer C.

description: I had the worst Chinese meal ever at New Asia restaurant.  It cost the same as any other place up and down the street, but it made Panda Express look really good.  This is NOT what I come to Chinatown for.  And then there is the obnoxious Chinese karaoke and ballroom dancing.  I gather that it is not every night, but it was pretty bad the day we were there.  The dancers (older Chinese couples) were pretty serious about their ballroom dancing, but I notice that they also brought some of their food with them.  To a restaurant.  Not a good sign.
author: Eric N.

description:
I came here with families before Chinese New Year.  We had a party of 8, but was still promptly seated.  The place gives me an old Cantonese tea house feel, very chaotic and noisy, but familiar at the same time. 

We ordered the usual dim sum dishes such as shrimp dumpling, shui mai, pork short ribs, bbq pork bum and etc.  The taste is very average, nothing too special.  

Here comes the complaint.  The wait staffs were terrible.  One guy STUCK HIS FINGERS IN MY TEA CUP and tried to pretend it never happened until we said something.  How can I eat here if they don't understand the basics of personal hygiene?

Also, the price point is above average for Chinatown.

Tips:
Avoid this place all together just because of the hygiene issue.
author: Johnny G.

description:
I'm a dim sum-aholic, an addition for which I want no cure.
Love this place!  Yeah, it's greasy, and a few things came off the carts cool to room temp, but overall it was awesome.   Great flavors, a huge variety.  The cart ladies were very nice.  Love the dive vibe + the crystal chandeliers.  I was surprised that I did not get an MSG hangover like I have gotten at Yank Sing.  In fact Yank who?  I'll  never go to Yank Sing as long as there is New Asia.
author: Cinnamon Z.

description:
Being chinese, I am used to the huge area with lots of tables and the atmosphere being very, VERY noisy.

On that note, I am not rating this 5 stars because of atmosphere or ambiance, or service, but FOOD.

The atmosphere and ambiance are clean, which is a plus, but kinda noisy.  The service, well I went for Dim sum so you don't really get served.

As for the food, I have been in Boston for a couple months and the Dim Sum is kinda crap here.  So coming back to SF was really good.  I don't remember how it compares to others places around Chinatown, but I remember the Dim Sum just being really good.  Like, REALLY GOOD.  The best I have had in a long time.  Can't really go wrong with anything there.

ADVICE: if you can, bring someone who speaks Cantonese, it makes things 10000 times easier, plus the servers are more friendly that way haha.
author: Ryan G.

description:
I came here for dim sum with my family.  It seems to be a popular place, since they start calling out numbers during the lunch rush.

They have the usual dim sum cart pushers.  Some of the ladies are pretty aggressive!  A few times, they will place dishes on your table unless you tell them no.  I had to shake my head NO many times..lol.

The dishes are ok.  I think the dim sum in Milpitas or San Jose is way better.  They have the typical shrimp dumpling, pork dumpling, rice noodle, etc.

I noticed a lot of the workers only speak a little bit of English.  I'd reccommend you come here with at least one person who speaks Chinese =).

The customer service here is not that great.  If you ask for a dish, they tell you to wait for it to come around. 

I don't think I'll go back.
author: Rita V.

description:
The Future In Laws and I have been here about four times now, three times for dim sum and once for dinner. Let's start with the dim sum.

Dim Sum:
Overall, it's pretty good. The prices are reasonable (unlike Koi Palace in Daly City which is kind of pricey) and the food is decent. It's not the best dim sum I've ever had nor is it the worst. It's just three-stars-a-ok. This place is almost always busy, like most dim sum places in the city, but it was pretty easy to get a table since the space is pretty large. I think the fact that it's mainly filled with Chinese people authenticates the decency of the food! Don't be surprised if they sit you at a table with strangers - this isn't a Chinese thing, it's a restaurant thing. There are two levels (the bathroom is on the second level). 

Dinner:
Oh man. Have you ever walked into a Chinese restaurant expecting a normal Chinese dinner and then walked into a scene straight out of a bad-Chinese-food-induced-Saturday-Night-Fever-nightmare? New Asia on Thursday nights, my friends. 

So I don't know if it's every Thursday night, but I'm guessing it is. We parked in our usual parking lot (the one on Pacific a few doors down from the restaurant) and walked up to the front doors. For a few seconds, we thought there was a private party going on because the middle of the restaurant had been converted into a dance floor, a matchstick-jeans-clad Chinese man in sunglasses was sashaying on the raised platform singing into a mic and a mini rotating disco ball was flashing from the ceiling. Oh, did I forget to mention the 20 or so couples who were ballroom dancing and otherwise boogie-ing on the dance floor?

But no, it's just Special Dancing Night! Seriously! That's what the menu said! We walked in and were seated at one of the tables around the dance floor. It turned out to be really entertaining. Who knew that middle-aged and old Chinese folks like to cha-cha-cha and waltz?

Anyway, the food (which is the main point) was decent. They have a Special Dancing Night menu which we glanced over but didn't order from. It took us a while to flag down a waiter who finally brought us an English menu. I think we ended up getting the salt and pepper pork, a fried shrimp dish, some flat rice noodles, pork fried rice and steamed whole fish (you have to ask for it). Since I'm not Chinese, I don't have the specific names for these things, sorry. 

The manager came over a few times to check on us and encouraged us to dance. We think it's because they might add a Special Dancing Night tax to the meal, but if they did, it's nothing too steep. Also, watching the folks dance with such serious expressions is pretty fun. The singer, who was wearing Bono sunglasses, and his partner, who was wearing a fur vest, switched between soulful Chinese music and songs like "Get This Party Started" and "Bad Romance" and "Happy Birthday." No joke.

If you're looking for a good time on Thursday night, go to New Asia!
author: Christine P.

description:
I was bummed.  I had really high hopes of finding a decent dim sum restaurant in Chinatown.

The sadest part is that the food is actually tasty.  The selection was good.  The flavors were complex and authetic, but the execution was poor.

- Roast Duck:  It had all the hallmark of a luscious duck.  It had a thin skin and tender meat.  The balanced flavors of 5 spice powder and star anise was lovely.  Unfortunately, it was cold.  Not tepid, but only a short step away from chilled. Cold duck fat is NOT tasty.

- Chinese Broccoli:  It was hard, undercooked and was fresh-out-of-the-fridge-cold.  It tasted like someone forgot to reheat it once it came out of the ice bath.

- Shrimp Dumplings:  Bamboo shoots and white pepper, the flavors were spot on.  However the shrimps were chewy and the skin was hard around the edges... like they've been kept warm on the steamer for a long time.

- Xiao Lung Bao:  The meat was tender, but not mushy.  Plenty of sweet broth inside the dumpling.  Unfortunately, the broth was tepid and the skin on the dumpling was tough from sitting out for too long.

- Steamed Pork Ribs:  This was the only dish that was hot, tasty and delicous.

I was there at 11:00 a.m. on a Saturday, during the Flower Street Festival.  There were a ton of patrons, so turnover on food should be hot and fast.  The dim sum would have been fantastic if it was not served cold or over-heated.  It was obvious that a lot of love and skills went into the preparation and seasoning, so it makes me mad to see a short fall on something so elementary.

New Asia, just serve the food while it's fresh.  It's not that hard.
author: Cherrie C.

description:
The restaurant was huge...two levels! The place wasn't great, but that didn't matter. The dim sum is what counts.

The dim sum that we ordered were the following:
1. Shu mai- Pork and shrimp filled with a wonton wrap on the outside was a bit salty to me. However, these were pretty big.
2. Shrimp wonton- There was two shrimps inside the wonton! That was pretty cool, usually it has only one. This was actually my favorite.
3. Shrimp noodle wrap- This is one of my favorite dishes too with the soy sauce on top. The shrimp was very tasty.
4. Cow stomach with potatoes- The stomach didn't taste as well as I thought, kind of chewy...The potatoes were very soft and had lots of flavor in them. 
5. Tofu wrapped with vegetables- This didn't taste very good at all...
6. Chicken feet- Too oily and not enough spices.
7. Lobster with ye mein- The lobster was a bit harder to chew and the ye mein was not cooked properly. The sauce was a bit bland, but overall it was ok.
8. Steamed BBQ pork bun- My favorite dim sum...this place failed. The bun was very sweet and the pork tasted weird. 

Service here was kind of rude...and not that quick. And sanitation...ya...no way. So disgusting...especially the restrooms.
 
Oh and by the way, watch your step when going to the restroom upstairs...they are slippery for some odd reason. 

Overall, I think this place isn't a good place to eat dim sum. Parking is horrible too...
author: Connie C.

description: so, I didn't think New Asia was that bad (though nothing worth writing about) until I came home to LA this week and ate at Ocean Star in Monterey Park. I've never been to Koi Palace in Serramonte, but ugh, there is seriously no decent dim sum in SF.
author: Becky T.

description: Great variety of dim sum.  Fresh tasty selections to feast on.  BBQ pork buns are a must.  The atmosphere is quite chaotic and loud but interesting to watch.
author: Lori S.

description: This place deserves 3 1/2 stars but it doesn't have that option.  Seriously, the food is not great but it deserves more than just three stars.  Portions are huge, hearty and tasty.  Unfortunately, this place gets two stars for ambience.  It's been the same for the last 30 + years.  FIVE stars for a super friendly staff!!
author: Nancy L.

description:
I haven't been to New Asia in decades, but that doesn't stop me from eating their food almost every week...hehe!!!

I like their bell pepper/shrimp thingy and the deep fried shrimp ball when hot. 

A must try/have is the durian pastry - VERY GOOD - it's sweet creamy/cheesy taste is oh sooooo yummy!

A bit "nicer" interior than most dim sum places in Chinatown, but a tad more expensive too.
author: Peter L.

description:
Great dim sum!  My favorite in Chinatown.  We used them for our post-wedding brunch.  They took reservations for our large group, had the tables set aside and waiting for us upstairs, and did a good enough job getting carts over there for everyone.  We were satisfied, the price was pretty cheap, and the food was great.

4.5 stars.  Only subtracting half a star because the bathroom is kind of small and unclean.
author: Chad H.

description: You can really do better in SF Chinatown.  Not much to write here because there is really nothing spectacular here.  Really - take the effort to look elsewhere in Chinatown on Yelp.
author: Mark M.

description:
3.5 stars.

This place was a really good spot to fill our dim sum craving while hanging out in Chinatown. 

Definitely felt like an institution-of-sorts with its grandeur. It took us no time to get seated despite the fact that it looked like many people were waiting. The table was filthy when we were led over - and they didn't do too much to change that. They didn't remove any of the little food/crumb droppings from the people before us. We watched them simply throw down white placemats to cover it up. 

But we came for the food. There was never a moment when carts weren't rolling past us. We loved the shrimp noodles and the shrimp dumplings (har gow) also hit the spot. They were also very efficient with my Diet Coke request. The one thing was that we were going to get a plate of sauteed greens. She wrote down $8 on the running tab - we actually then gave them back. I mean it was sheer principle - this portion couldn't have cost more than $.10 at the Asian market where they get the produce from. 

Oh - should also report that the restrooms were very clean. That's always a good thing. :)
author: Jen N.

description:
I've only been for dim sum and I have to say that it's one of the better places in the city. They tend to be crowded and you might have to fight to get the attention of the servers. Definitely a good option if you don't feel like venturing out to the Richmond and not too pricey. 

I like their siu mai and beef meatballs. I always order the har gau and while there is a lot of shrimp, the skin breaks apart.
author: Jackie T.

description:
I never been here for dimsum but i always eat here for my grandpa's association dinner. I have nothing really to say except for the fact the restaurant is really big. Good for weddings and banquets. I always thought New Asia was kinda dirty but Chinatown is dirty in general. 

PS. Parking sucks but you can park in the yellow zones after 6pm.
author: Carol Y.

description:
I came here over the weekend to grab some dimsum, being away from it for so long.

I expected a lot from it cuz a friend of mine highly recommended it cuz that's where she goes everytime she stops by at SF.  So I came here, the wait was fairly quick, I only wait for 10 minutes for my party of 4.

The style of the restaurant is typical, you sit down, get a card, chinese ladies rolling around with carts, young asian guys getting you your drinks and cleaning up, etc etc.

They have a serious lack of variety of food.  The quality was okay, it wasn't bad, it wasn't great either. It was a decent meal but nothing I would look forward to.
author: Willis C.

description: Average prices and taste.  Usually has the shortest wait-time of all the dim sum places in the area.
author: Javier G.

description: I have been eating dim sum since I was a little kid and this is by far the best I have ever had.  I recommend going a bit early to avoid the crowd and try all of the different types of dumplings and the radish cake.  Unlike some of the other reviewers, I found the food cheap and the staff nice.  This is the dim sum place to go!
author: travis l.

description:
This was a recommendation for dim sum while just having an afternoon in the SFO area. Specifically for dim sum, as there other choices but this one got the vote.  
HIGHLY RECOMMEND!!!  This was fantastic and great offereings.
Quick to come around with the carts to choose from and filled up quickly.
The egg custard for dessert was filling and FRESH pastry!
Affordable and would go back.
author: Fred R.

description:
New Asia has some pretty tasty dim sum I will give them that. It is not the best that I've ever had, nor the cheapest but it sure is good and not too pricey. I have only been twice for lunch so I can't speak for their dinner menu but when I've been for lunch a few friends and I have split several tasty plates. 
Seafood chow mein, yang chow yellow rice, Singapore style vermicelli, dry scallop & seafood fried rice, roasted duck with thick noodle soup and a few others. All were tasty and big servings but the seafood chow mein and dry scallop fried rice were the dishes I enjoyed the most. Each dish except for the duck soup were $10+ which is something I'm unaccustomed to paying at a dim sum restaurant. 
A beautiful building and a great staff provide a unique experience while enjoying this delicious, authentic Chinese food. If you're visiting SF or even if you live here and just passing through China town, I would suggest eating at New Asia if the budget provides.
author: Elaine M.

description:
I will never come here again, I suggest you go to GOLD MOUNTAIN RESTAURANT! I usually eat here with my parents, so I decided to come here with my friends. The wait was about 15-20 minutes. You go up to the lady and they give you a number; but the lady was so frustrated you can totally see it in her face. I asked her how long the wait was, she said in Chinese 15 minutes! Others following behind me was told the same thing! When our seats were available, she shouted out hella loud in English and Chinese using her mic, "Number 28! Number 28! Number 28!" Is that really necessary? She didn't have to be so mean. I'm pretty calm about it and wasn't in too much of a hurry, but hey, we're here to have good food, but with that attitude, we should've walked out while we can.

Food-wise, it was alright. What I wanted to eat didn't even come out until we were more than half way done with the "eh" food because we were hungry so we had to get something. Also, we went around lunch time, so they should know to prepare more dim sum. What's more rude, they asked me to give more TIP! BEWARE, THEY WILL ASK YOU FOR TIP!
author: Helen N.

description: Among dim sum restaurants in San Francisco's Chinatown, this seems to offer variety and decent quality.  Waits could be long on weekends.
author: Franklin W.

description:
Place is pretty big for Chinatown area and the food aint bad. The price is fair but the service could be better

Pretty much everything was just like every dim sum place but what stood out the most were their shui mai. I guess you can say they are the Barry Bonds of shui mai.. huge, must be on steroids. I was pretty impressed with the cart service though coming around frequently so you dont just sit around with one item for everyone to fight over. Just make sure you catch them cuz they move around really fast, its like they got their turbo button held on constantly.

Remember first thing you sit down and do is ask for water cuz once you start grubbing on all that oily Chinese food, youre gonna hate yourself if you dont have at least 2 glasses per person.Better yet get a pitcher. haha. At one point I think I was waiting for my ice to melt so I can get a few sips in =/
author: Tony H.

description: I would have given this zero stars if Yelp would have let me, but i guess 1 is alright. I've had a lot of dim sum in my life and this place had to be the worst by far. The moment I walked in, I could just tell that their service was bad. There was no clear indication as to where the waiting line was and when seated at a table, the dishes were dripping with water and the server literally threw some chopsticks onto the table. All that was fine really, most Chinese restaurants tend to be...messy, but the food was not good at all. I can't really explain it, but my taste buds were not pleased one bit. The chicken feet(which I get at other places) was just a bad combination of seasonings. It was sweet, but salty and had a bad addition of spice to it. I couldn y even finish eating one! This happened with every item that I ordered. I will not be returning to this place.
author: Olivia H.

description:
New Asia is one of the oldest large Dim Sum joints in China Town!  I remember coming here in the 80's for wedding banquets and red egg and ginger parties.  The decor hasn't changed much.  It features a lot of red and gold (lucky colors which represents prosperity and fertility) and actually puts out a pretty authentic dim sum house vibe.  

The food was just as good as I remembered.  The har gow and siu mais were large and meaty.  The portions are to par and the flavors are delicious.

My only complaint is that the place cane use a thorough cleaning.  The floors were grimy and the stairs were black from dirt and grease.  Other than that a great place to go for dim sum!  LOL
author: Henry S.

description:
My kids and I have been having dim sum here since the '70s and it is just as good as ever. My first visit in thirty years after sampling dim sum all over Asia including Taipei and Hong Kong with which it compares favorably and at a lower price.

Six hungry diners = $ 60. Beat that Yank Sing!

Very crowded - 20 minute wait - but hey, it is Chinese New Year! Gung Hay Fat Choy!
author: Paul D.

description: I came here with a party of 4, killed hella plates and it was quite expensive. Food was decent here and doesnt get too crowded on week days. Opens kinda late too!
author: Frederick A.

description:
First of all I'm asian, so I have very low expectations from an asian restaurant when it comes to customer service...but this was so bad I had to write something about it.  We were there with a couple of friends and we sat down, the waitress came over and offered a whole bunch of dishes...good so far.  Then we asked for water.  It never came.  We had to ask like 5 times to 5 different wait staff before they brought it out and they kept passing the buck.  Then a waitress came over when we were just starting to eat to ask if we wanted something else because they were closing up for the lunchtime hours.  We said no...but we felt super rushed since we just started eating and it wasn't near 3 pm yet, their closing time.  Then she comes by and plops a check on our table while we're eating without us even asking for the check yet.  A couple of minutes later she comes and says "can you pay now" when she sees we haven't put a credit card on the check.  My husband tells her we're still eating and she says "please pay now we are closing you can continue eating" and then she leaves.  She comes back a couple min later and my husband went ahead and placed a credit card...she quickly grabs it, went to process and came back with the signature receipt.  
With such poor service, he puts 0.01 for tip.  Another waitress comes to grab it and shortly after comes back and says, "you didn't include tip" which my husband tells her "yes I did, it's 0.01."  THen she walks away.  Another waitress comes and says "you need to include tip" and my husband tells her "why? you guys don't bring us water, rush us to eat, make us pay, it's poor service" then she walks away.  Again another waitress comes and say "why you not including the tip"...and again he tells her the service was bad.  

I've been here a couple of years ago and I didn't think too much of the food but my friends wanted to come for dim sum.  But this has got to be the worse service I've EVER had anywhere...and the wait staff need to learn to use their quiet voices when they are talking..sounds like they are arguing all over the place...and they need to learn to actually wait on their customers...it's part of their job title "WAITress."

If Yelp allowed for negative Stars, I would have rated them negative 10 stars.
author: J H.

description: They are rude n their food taste really nasty
author: Allison K.

description:
Being the first time going to Chinatown in San Francisco.  I wasn't sure what to expect but was hoping to have some fun.  I just love how you can go a few blocks north of  Union Square and end up in a totally different world.  Chinatown is awesome.  Walking a few blocks and visiting a few shops ( I bought a lucky cat with the swinging arm and a hand fan for my mom ); my wife and I find ourselves in front of the New Asia Restaurant.  Going inside the place is one huge hall with round tables everywhere.  Being early afternoon the place was packed with many of the patrons being of asian desent.  It was cool to see where ever you looked families were sharing a meal.
My wife recommended this place having come here before on vacation with her girlfriends.  So I wanted to give it a try.  To get seated you have to get a number from a person behind a counter.  When they are ready to seat you they call out your number on a intercomm system.  The funny thing is that at the time it was a older chinese woman who would literally scream out the numbers in a thick oriental accent.  It was like something out of a Sienfeld episode.  Hilarious.
Once our number was called we are escorted to a table right next to the kitchen.  At first I was thinking that they seated us at the worst table in the whole place.  Later I felt it was the best table because that is where all the carts of food came out from.  Let me explain.  The way the place worked was the ladies would come around with carts of food.  If you saw something you liked they would put it on your table.  You get charged for the number of plates of food on your table.  So if you have a problem like me with liking everything you see you will have a table full of food like we did.  We had so much food our fridge in our hotel room was bursting with chinese food.
As for the food, I found it to be pretty good.  Not the best chinese food I have ever ate but good.  The prices aren't that bad either.  What I found out is that Chinatown all together is pretty cheap.  From the shops to the restaurants, your money goes a long way.  I thought the service was pretty good too.  The cart ladies treated us both well.  The place all around was a fun experience.  If you can find it.  You should try it for yourself.
author: Paul S.

description:
Wandering around Chinatown like the tourists that we were, we Came across New Asia. The dim sum carts confirmed a dim sum joint and the profusion of Chinese clients made our mind up.

The service was certainly a lot more polite than you'd find in London's Chinatown. The trolleys came by frequently and our empty tea pot was quickly refilled with hot water.

The dim sum were certainly of American size! Kind of felt like I had shrunk a bit like in Alice in Wonderland! The woo kok and siew mai were nice. Pastry for cheong fun a bit thick.

Still, a filling and reasonably priced meal. Felt like a local!
author: Yee Gan O.

description: Our beloved Gold Mountain has closed, so we walked to the nearby New Asia for dim sum.  We didn't have to wait long for a table and the first cart came immediately.  The steamed dumplings were hot, but everything else was cold.  We asked for a vegetable dumpling and received a dumpling with vegetables and beef.
author: Emma Q.

description: Way too expensive for dim sum. I guess I'm used to the place I usually go to in San Gabriel..we wanted to eat somewhere clean, and this placed looked good. Didn't get very many dishes..about 6 dishes and a soda and it cost $24. Yowza. I love egg tarts but the one here was soft :( Service was ok, we got what we wanted quickly. If you know anyone who lives in SF, ask them for recommendations.
author: Angelina L.

description: I have not been to New Asia in a while but my experience was disappointing.  Lots of people there which is no surprise but I am disappointed with service and the quality of the dim sum.  Lack of taste and lack of employees paying attention to those who need help.  You had to walk up to a waiter to get your check and even get a refill on your tea.
author: Wayne W.

description:
I would think that dim sum in the heart of Chinatown would be bomb...but it I was wrong.  

First off, the hostess.  She told us the wait would be five minutes but it turned into 15.  She also uses a microphone to call out numbers.  "Call you" is an understatement.  She was screaming...INTO A MICROPHONE! Who does that? Her voice was booming across the entire restaurant, I'm sure.  When we sat down, I seriously couldn't even concentrate on ordering food off the carts because I felt I was sitting in the audience at an auction!  

Luckily, my starving party and I quickly ordered the usual dim sum dishes...shiu mai, har gow, chicken feet, fried shrimp balls, roasted duck, steamed meat balls, and tofu dessert.  The har gow and shiu mai were much larger than other places I've been to and were very good.  

I felt like the same dishes were being carted around.  Saturday lunch time is prime dim sum time!  I can't believe they didn't have a larger variety of food. Also, we decided to eat dim sum because we were all craving ja leung, sweet custard bun and chive dumplings.  And they didn't have any of those today!!!  Seriously?!  

Check please.
author: Helen V.

description: My gripes with this restaurant are the questionable cleanliness and horrible service. My grandpa once had to pay a waiter $5 to bring us some hot sauce during a banquet. Along with that, I did not enjoy the food items and would not come back for dinner. However, I think the dim sum is delicious. I don't find any items for dim sum too oily, and the dumplings are pretty large which means they don't cheap you on the servings. Good dim sum in exchange for poor service? Pretty common so I'm not worrying too much about it.
author: Brittany L.

description:
This is a review on their dim sum which we had for Sunday brunch.  Arrived around 10-ish and the wait was around 20 minutes; the place is packed and very busy.  The hostess calling out the numbers is free entertainment.

The har gow and siu mai were excellent:  large and tasty.  They really make excellent baked dim sum such as their bbq pork buns and seasame balls were very flavorful.  The best was the egg tart, the flaky crust and flavorful filling.  The leafed wrapped chicken rice (lor mai gai), was a disappointment but they redeemed themselves with the spare ribs.  Spent $35 for dim sum for three; just about right.

I've been eating dim sum for more than 30 years and this is what I have in mind when I think of dim sum in SF Chinatown.  People who are disappointed cause their waiter didn't refill their water glass or have the sauce they want should look elsewhere.  This is a crowded, noisy, dirty bathroom, but great tasting dim sum.

To me, dim sum isn't about white tablecloths, a side of caviar and champange.
author: Lester C.

description: I am going out on a limb here........  This place must have been grand when it first opened.  It doesn't seem to have been maintained since.  Not being a big city folk myself, and with my sheltered stucco PF Chang sanitized view of how kept a restaurant should be, I find it hard to overlook the condition of the place.... then........ the in-law orders, the table fills, and nobody talks.  Perhaps this is life in the big city.
author: Jamie B.

description: Came here for post lunar new year celebration. Food was very westernized.
author: Danika Z.

description:
whenever i eat in chinatown i feel a bit dirty.  the places are just dirty!  we came here on a saturday afternoon at around 2pm. there were still people eating dim sum but they werent busy and ther was no wait.  this is one of those places where you want to wipe your chopsticks and plates and cups down before you eat with them.  

their har gow is humongous!  they had like 8 mini shrimp in there.  the shrimp noodle roll also had the same mini shrimp.  they should use bigger shrimp.  they had a lou sa bao that was weird.  i opened it and all this oil leaked out.  we opened the other two and they were the same so i guess they were supposed to be like that.  we didnt eat them.  the lotus past buns were good.  chinese brocoli good too except the second plate we got was cold.  the stir fried noodle rolls we got were cold the waitress said she would microwave it for us.

and for the final shocker when i went to the bathroom i saw a cockroach.  running around near the kitchen.  i almost wanted to barf.
author: claudia y.

description: Come early and be ready for a wait.  Still one of the better dim sum spots here in SF.
author: Rich S.

description: Came here during the autumn moon festival and the food was fresh. Some of the dims sum was disappointing and the food was overpriced. Other than that, the ha how tasted the best.
author: Jamie F.

description:
Since I was a kid, every year my family and I would visit New Asia some time after Chinese New Year. My uncle used to buy 2 tables (now it's more like 1 table) from the Chinese Association and he'd be gracious enough to invite family to partake in the typical Chinese-style banquet, as we rung in the new year with fellow Chinese Association members and their family and friends.

New Asia is the place chosen by the Gee association (each association is made up of Chinese last names who dine at certain restaurants in Chinatown for about 1 month after the new year) so I've become familiar with the place and the food.

I remember the food being better and we had more dishes. We'd always get buckets of rice, tea and each table had a bottle of apple cider and 7-UP. The night we had our dinner, we were served:

-Chinese cold cuts
-Vegetarian dish
-Squab
-Seafood soup
-Chicken with deep fried chips
-Mushrooms and Taiwanese bok choy
-Catfish

The place can accommodate 500 plus people (there were 500 people the night we went) and the upstairs wasn't even full.
