There's lots of gold decor in the place and strobe lighting equipment as well as a disco ball hanging from the ceiling so I expect they hold night time events as well, or karaoke nights since there are televisions set up downstairs.

Service was average. Bathrooms could have been much cleaner. Parking is wherever you're lucky enough to see an open spot in crowded Chinatown.
author: Janel Y.

description: It's your typical big banquet hall dim sum/ chinese food mecca.  We caught the tail-end of dim sum - har gow, steamed ribs with black bean sauce and rice noodles, ham sook guk (the meat inside of this was eh.. had better in NYC).  It was standard tasting but wished the food could be warmer.  We ordered beef chow fun and chicken pan fried noodles along with leftover dim sum.   The noodle dishes were tasty though despite the beef chow fun was on the oily side.
author: Salena M.

description:
I have been to a handful of Chinese wedding banquets at New Asia, however, this review is for dim sum only.

Woohooo, dim sum coming around on carts!  In my past couple dim sum Yelp reviews, I complained that fewer and fewer places are serving dim sum on carts.  This was a plus for New Asia.  However, despite this positive, they still seemed to lack several key dishes.  They didn't have the pan fried chive dumplings (gow choi gao) for example.

All in all though, food was tasty and inexpensive.  Not sure it really warrants a huge trek from the East Bay unless you are meeting with SF friends.
author: Christopher W.

description: So many Chinese restaurants in Chinatown and while deciding which one to try, a local man suggested this place.  Walked in - it is HUGE!  A literal dining hall with glitzy chandeliers to boot.  Warehouse style seating but I'm not complaining about that.  Service was not too bad for a warehouse.  Typical dim sum plates and bamboo baskets but the food quality was lacking.  I hate to say this but I do feel we were not offered the cream of the crop stuff as quickly as the Asian family next to us.  Me, brunette pushing 50 and two early 20's blonde girls.  Skip the fish-ball soup that was nearly poured on me, as the server was so enthusiastic about how "good" it was.  Curry sauce was ok but the tasteless rubbery balls and slimy (?tripe?) was too hard to slice up to eat.  I wanted to slurp it but my daughters would have beer horrified.   The steamed chicken and rice in lotus leaves tasted more like it had been smoked in cheap tobacco instead.  Pass on that one.  Steamed pork buns not bad but I've had better.  Recommend the Chinese broccoli and basic good chow mein.  Interesting to try: tofu "soup" that is thin, delicate texture, and you pour sugar water over it.  Like a very light flan.  I might have given New Asia 3 stars had I tried the chicken feet!  They were quite popular!
author: Laura S.

description:
Us old schoolers still call it...Asia Garden.

Its decor is a throwback to the 80's (which is in again):  brass columns, art deco wall paper & trim, & glittery Dynasty-like crystal chandeliers.  We had banquet food-8 dishes, cookies + cake on  that amazing device...the lazy susan.  Tea, 7-up & apple-like cider, rounded out the meal.  My favorite dishes include pseudo shark fin soup, yee mein, jellyfish & roasted chicken.  

10,000 calories & over a dozen ear-piercing Chinese karaoke songs later, we emerged, too full but thankful the streets of Chinatown were quiet enough for a quick walk home.  

AG aka NA, thanks for the memories. How did we survive going to 5-6 yearly when we were kids? (No karaoke then, thankfully.)

Note to self:  always, always bring ear plugs to future Chinese banquets.
author: Jen L.

description:
My whole family game here for dim sum Christmas lunch.  And so it also happened the gf's family also happened to choose this restaurant independently.

I think my dad's words perfectly captured my feelings - "I could've made better dim sum at home."  So, I can't make dim sum.  And it so happens that my dad owns a restaurant and has made dim sum before.  However, that doesn't make his statement or my feelings less valid.

Worst dim sum.  Just stay away.  For me.
author: Bob C.

description: Overall good dimsum, very tasty. Bbq pork buns were a little fatty. Good, friendly service. This guai-lo was fat and happy!
author: Greg F.

description: The dim sum is mediocre at best but the egg custard and Chinese donuts are the best I have had in Chinatown yet. A very good place to go to experience the Dim Sum by cart service; however, the place is too pricey for me to become a regular patron.
author: John C.

description:
This place is not very nice looking. This is a typical Chinese style with gold metal everywhere. 
But their Dim Sum's are great. This place is laid back.
You can eat well for a reasonable price. We are used to stop by this place when around Chinatown. 

It is always a good bet to stop by this place to get good lunch time food.
author: Tristan L.

description:
Never coming back here again. This place gives dim sum places a really bad reputation. I took my boyfriend here one time and I could tell he's still pretty scarred by the experience. The place is filthy, stinks, and the service is just plan horrible. I know that the servers do something extra to non-Chinese speaking folks to get their attention about the food that they have in their carts (since they announce it all in Chinese), but I think that repeatedly poking the customers is too much. As soon as we got say, shumai or something from one cart and we're about to eat it, another server would approach us, poke or  "tap" our shoulders and really force us to get what they're offerring. It happened the entire meal that it just made us really frustrated. Get your hands off my coat. I mean it. 

Normally, I'd be willing to forgive bad service (to an extent) if the food is great, but this is not the case here. I'd say it's decent at best. 

Oh, and what's up with the old lady in the cashier area who almost shoved the bill up my face after I paid because she wants a bigger tip? She was literally "more tip, more". WTF. 

Stay away.
author: Erika I.

description:
Another Sunday, another dim sum restaurant to review!

Nothing too out of the ordinary to report. It's in Chinatown, so inherently parking is a biatch. I don't really head out there on the weekends, but I had some friends from out of the town, and they had just finished running a a half-marathon, and they chose the restaurant, so who am I to balk and complain?

The place was packed downstairs, but there were still plenty of tables on the upper level, where we ended up being seated.  I arrived a little late (trying to find said parking), so there was plenty o' food on the table already.  

* Chinese broccoli
* Siu mai
* BBQ pork buns
* Pork spareibs
* Shrimp dumplings
* Shanghainese dumplings
Etcera, etcera, etcera

No major complaints, but then again no raves either.  

The highlight of the meal was seeing a strange old Chinese man tell my friend's friend's 2 1/2 year old son sit down (he had been standing completely upright on the chair)...and the little dude actually complied and had a total zombie like look on his face, after having completely ignored his parents' exhortations.  That had nothing to do whatsoever with our dining experience, but it had us in stitches!
author: Evelyn K.

description:
Came here for a celebration of life dinner after a funeral.  Have not stepped foot in this restaurant since the 1990's when my sister had her wedding banquet here.

I must say the food is all still pretty good.  The walnut prawns, one of my all time faves, was perfect, not too much mayo and quite crispy.  Another dish that was good was the steamed chicken with ginger/onion salt.

All in all, a very delectable meal.  The reason for the two stars is the nasty place settings!  I don't think they washed them very often.  More than half of the soda glasses on our table were filthy.  When I say filthy, I mean dried up black gook on the side of the glass.  Some of the dishes and bowls were greasy before we used them!  Just downright gross!

Word to New Asia ~ please oh please hire a new dishwasher!!  Or maybe the issue is that they don't have a dishwasher!!
author: Sharon S.

description:
New Asia is a Hong Kong-style banquet hall -- replete with gold gilt, red velvet curtains, and that shade of pink that reminds you of shrimp cocktail or salmon bisque. Mmm .... salmon bisque. 

Anyway, the place is HUGE and always very clean; the seating is prompt, and the wait-staff is well-managed. The dim sum/yum cha on the weekends never disappoints, and I highly encourage you eavesdrop on the conversations in Cantonese when a gweilo tries to order an orange chicken rice plate when all the churchies are dishing up 100-year-old duck eggs over braised pea sprouts, see-through rice dough steamed shrimp dumplings, fried taro balls in wonton strips,  and duck tongue in soy sauce. 

For the price, it's about on par with You's Dim Sum (casual take-out, dimsum only), but minus the attitude from that crazy lady with black drawn-on eyebrows.

The new Chinatown classic. 
Plus, there's flamenco with the locals on certain nights -- and KUNG PAO KOSHER: Jewish comedians raking in on the Christmas irony with some General Tso's chicken :)
author: Lisa L.

description:
I thought this place was amazing and was certain I had found the best dim sum place in the city. 

Then I RUINED my life by logging on to the Department of Health's website and found that NEW ASIA only got a 38!!!!!!! Can you believe it, I can't believe the place is still in business. I can't believe I didn't die! HIgh risk insect and rodent problems, not washing hands! No hot water???? 

The moral of this story is: If you really, really, really love a restaurant, DO NOT go to the following link. It could ruin your life. On the other hand, it could save it! 

http://www.sfdph.org/eh/Violations/FrameMain.asp
author: Katherine B.

description: We went there for brunch upon recommendation from a local. Price is good and portions are huge. The decor won't send anyone home in awe, but for regular lunch with friends, it's OK.
author: Alfred L.

description: Good Dim Sum, have tasted better..but my out of town freinds love this place, fast, good, fairly priced. Great variety of food, service is friendly and do mainly speak Chinese, but you just gotta talk with the hand motions when the dont understand you..I would say a must try at least once when visiting Chinatown.
author: Jaime P.

description: Was recommended to New Asia by our hotel for dim sum.  The place was packed when we got there with many Asians waiting to get in (which is always a good sign).  After waiting only about 10 minutes, we were seated.  The dim sum we ordered was very good.  The service from carts was plentiful and the carts came by frequently.  Having dim sum frequently in New York City, I'd have to say that this definitely measures up.  Excellent recommendation and we enjoyed every bite.
author: Ellen L.

description:
For banquet only:

It seems like their food got worse than before. I went here for a family banquet this past Sunday and in TWO of our dishes, I found hair... I understand they have to make 100 something tables of food, but still, there's a reason for hair nets.

Aside from the hair incident, the later dishes were pretty okay but left my throat a bit dry afterwards. I blame the MSG.

Facility wise... the carpet upstairs is very sticky when you walk on it. Gross.
author: Natalie G.

description:
My mom, sister and I were in Chinatown today in hopes of looking for a good place to have dim sum.  We actually went to Lichee Garden first, but sadly they no longer serve dim sum.  After wandering around for a while, we finally settled on going to New Asia.  It was about 12:30ish when we got there and the place was packed.  Fortunately, we were able to secure a table after only waiting 15 minutes.

Although the quality of the dim sum is pretty good, I was really disappointed by the variety of goodies that they offered.  They basically had har gaw, siu mai, Shanghai dumplings, chicken feet, shrimp rice noodles, spare rib rice noodles, pig's blood, some fried stuff and egg tarts.  I saw carts with the same items come by multiple times.  Anyway, we had seven dishes and our total was $29 before tip...eek!!  Whatever happened to food in Chinatown being cheap? =/
author: Katelynn L.

description: The dim-sum here was pretty mediocre when we went.  The selection was ok, but the quality and temperature of the food was lacking in some respects.  We were charged $6 for a plate of Chinese broccoli.  Quite a mark up for a vegetable whose only flavoring was a drizzle of oyster sauce.
author: Karen W.

description:
I was here this weekend and and am still laughing.  Something that will remain in my head forever!!!!!

I will never forget when these two asian ladies performed, "Dont cha wish your girlfriend was hot like me", with a very heavy Chinese accent will crack me up for life!!!!

DON'T ya!!!

stinky tofu


oooh yeah...food is like 2.86 stars, improved a bit, however. The place is still dirty, too much clutter with extra tables and chairs everywhere, making it a not so pleasant banquet dining experience.

BUT.....the performance was classic!! way better when the guy did it in "Wild Hogs".
author: StinkyTofu S.

description: I didn't think I'd find something for dim sum I like more than Golden Mountain, but I think I did.  Pork buns were amazing, as were the ha gao.  I loved the gin dui (sp?) too.  We came in, waited for about 5 min, and were seated.  Fast service and fresh/hot/amazing dim sum.  I'd rec it to anyone.
author: Julia D.

description:
came here with family and friends for christmas. overly crowded with tons of people. however we got seated right away. dun dun dun.. 

after we were seated, chinese ladies rolling with their carts roaming around with food. we ordered tons and every dishes we got were warm and freshly made. food is alright, but after awhile i realized how much m.s.g they put in those food. myyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy gosh. i was dying of dehydration, seriously.. overall, i thought its okay..
author: Valerie N.

description:
I was introduced to this place by a nice guy the morning after (well... afternoon I suppose) we met at a bar. I thought it completely endearing the way he ordered us items from the carts in his hesitant Cantonese, and sweet how he related to me that as a kid his parents used to drive the family into the city from the East Bay just to eat dim sum at this place.

A few days later, he was asking me my plans three months into the future to see if I could accompany him on a weekend camping trip. Needless to say, my relationship with the guy was quickly terminated. My relationship with New Asia, on the other hand, continues to thrive!

True, it may not have the best dim sum in the city. And yes, their version of "cleaning up" the last customers' mess is to simply cover up the soiled tablecloth with a few paper placemats (who KNOWS when was the last time they did their laundry...). The wait on a weekend can be horrendously long (make sure you take a number), and I swear that just because I'm not Chinese the bill always seems a little higher than it should. Oh, and the waitresses will serve you water and tea... hopefully after you've asked them for the 5th time. 

Despite all this, I can still honestly say that I'm a fan of this place if for no other reason than the fact that it straight up, full on CHINATOWN. From the host calling your number three times in at least three different languages over a mic like a Chinese racetrack announcer, to the immensity of the space itself with easily over a hundred occupied tables and gaudy chandeliers and widescreen tvs (just in case you were interested in what the people on the other side of the restaurant look like while they're gnawing and chattering away), to the carts upon carts of steaming wrapped goodies pushed around by loud ladies (who seem angry and rude but are actually pretty nice and helpful... the Chinese culture lacks tact), New Asia is an experience. I've loved it enough to bring my own family there (twice) as well as my more adventurous friends (btw I hope that guy doesn't read this, though I guess I do give him all the credit...).

If culture is what you seek, New Asia is your place. Not for the faint of heart!
author: Kate V.

description: A very large space for dim sum.  It is passable, but I wouldn't necessarily say the dim sum is the greatest.  What I find though is it is pretty fast and fairly cheap compared to other places around the city.  Unfortunately, at that expense, you do lose some of the quality in the food.
author: Lawrence E.

description:
I wouldn't suggest coming here unless you have someone with you who knows how to operate in the place. The inside of the restaurant is as hectic as Chinatown is outside of it. The ladies manning the carts are pushy and sneaky at the same time, attempting to fill your table with as many of the dim-sum dishes as you can fit. And each cart has a number of different options that aren't readily identifiable. I can see how coming here without a "guide" would quickly become hectic and overwhelming. Thankfully, I was in good hands, and I was able to sit back while my friend's uncle skillfully quarterbacked our meal. If you can stomach Chinese food and dumplings in the morning, then this is definitely a place to try. Our table was full of steamed baskets of dumplings that I really didn't bother to learn the names of (not that I would want to - definitely not coming here without help) that tasted awesome and were surprisingly filling. Didn't taste anything I didn't like until I encountered some odd soupy soy dessert thing near the end.

Bring your appetite (and a friend who speaks Chinese) and don't expect a relaxing environment, but definitely worth a try if you have the dim-sum itch.
author: Taylor C.

description:
When my family first moved to San Jose from Long Beach about 20 years ago, SF Chinatown was the only place in the bay area with good chinese food and dimsum. Of course now, San Jose is the hub of all that is Chinese/Taiwanese, but back then, it didn't exist. I can't count how many times we've driven up to SF, parked in the Portsmouth Square garage, and made our way to New Asia. Back then, everything was cheaper, including parking. We would always get dim sum, and it was always good and cheap. My mom would always order me the chicken and salted fish fried rice, which is FAB! 

I have to admit, recently going back there, the place looks like a huge dump... but appearance aside, I thought the dim sum was still excellent. They just need to fix up the place (and the bathroom) so it doesn't look like a cheap chinese karaoke restaurant (or maybe that's the charm of the place?).
author: J K L.

description:
I had the day off today so I decided to take my wife and my mother to
brunch. I haven't been in New Asia for almost 2 years basically because the service was equal to DMV, and no dim sum unless you wait by the kitchen door and grap the dim sum ladies with the carts
before they hit the closest table.(but now history) . The place looks like
new management and more common sense of how to run a business. but overall a very good experience and food was very
available the 3 of us spend $26 on 7 dim sum dishes. go 11am to avoid the crowd , will go again .
author: Howard J.

description:
This is my dim sum place of choice in the city. To me though, dim sum is more or less about the food you get and the service is a bit secondary. I'll admit that the service here isn't anything to write home about, it's quite average, as there have been times I've been overlooked by the busy waitstaff. But, I swear, the carts are not avoiding you on purpose here!

The big space means that waits are usually not too bad, but be prepared to sit a bit at rush time. All my usual dim sum favorites are served here and done well, I can't taste anything wrong with them. I'd prefer another place for a huge group (6+) since most of the tables are meant for 4, but a small group is perfect for this place imo.
author: Roland C.

description: Best dim sum place ever in SF,we always go only there in SF. Fried durian is my most fav!
author: Heather S.

description:
0 star for the food.
0 star for cleanness.
0 star for customer service/ horrible customer service.
I'd rather go to Four Seas Restaurant for better place, better dimsum, and better customer service.
I wont be back for sure !!
author: Ty N.

description: This place use to be really good. The service was nice and the food was good. Now it's interiors been upgraded but everything else has downgraded. Not all the staff is a disappointment, but the three I encountered just ruined it for everyone else. My mother asked politely several times to have the tea water refilled, and each employee she encountered redirected her and gave her the annoyed look. At one point I wanted to get up and knock one of them out.( excuse the angry remark, but that's how bad it was). Definitely not coming here again.
author: Shirley M.

description: Is this the worst Chinese restaurant in China Town?  In San Francisco?  Maybe not.  This place is huge--think Soviet Factory Commissary with tasteless chandeliers,  Greek  columns and sticky floors.  Really more of a banquet hall than restaurant.  The food!  Mass manufactured consumables brought quickly to the table from the assembly line, bland and tasteless by robotic servers.   Even the obligatory fish tank was empty and growing scum.  There's a reason you only have to wait 5 minutes for your meal to arrive.
author: Thomas M.

description:
8 dim sum plates for $35, couldn't really ask for more where you can get a good authentic dim sum. the most expensive plate was my veggie which was $8 and was probably $2 a pound if you bought it outside but what the heck. i love my greens!

i think this is my 3rd visit here. Always the same: huge place and loud. Which is probably the reason why this is rated low and will be a definite culture shock for first time visitors, foreign or not.
author: Viola C.

description: The place was packed on a Monday morning at 11 AM! Egg tarts (dan tat) were very good; had a noodle dish with lobster; lo bak go (turnup cake); ha gao (shrimp dumpling); char sui bao. All authentic and very very good. Good value too.
author: Phil G.

description:
Never again!  It was my first and last time here.  I don't plan on chasing dim sum carts, asking multiple times for the same thing or get my own place settings.  The food was not that great.  The place is huge but only 3 full dim sum carts to serve the entire room.  Ridiculous!  

Oh yeah, they even came back with the bill and asked for more tip because it was less than 10%.  Well, if you offered better service maybe you'd deserve it.  I couldn't believe they actually asked for us to change the bill and when told their service was bad the lady said, "oh sorry", stepped away quickly to get the bill adjusted.  real sincere .... really.  (i pull my eye socket and stick out my tongue at you, New Asia!)

Yes, Yelp it is a well deserved one star: "Eek! Methinks not" rating.
author: Christina C.

description:
Been coming here since birth... simple review...

Good Food! Bad Service and worst Bathrooms! But the FOOD!!!!! YUMMM! Please don't watch the others eat and when you hear some small chinese woman hacking a lung... don't watch... she's probably gonna spit it out... BUT The food is great!
author: Bobby T.

description: It has been a long time since I had eaten here. I had out of town nonasian guests to drive aroundand this was an experience for them to try something they have never had. There are other places that I eat at but it would not give them the same experience. With curious eyes they asked what was inside each of the dishes as they rolled by. They had enjoyed all the dishes such as shrimp dunmpling, pork sui maih, ha cheung fun. They ordered fried egg rolls which was familiar to them but were hesitant to try the pork ribs (paih gwat) or sticky rice that was very flavorful although a bit small. They also liked that they were full but it was easy on the wallet.
author: Vera L.

description:
3 stars for a fairly decent banquet meal, despite the shabby-looking decor and suspicious glass/table ware.  You always have to inspect the plates and glasses and wipe them down with your dinner napkin to make sure that things are as clean as they can be.  Otherwise, you may end up with some unappeitizing food stains on your plate.  Despite the somewhat unsanitary look of the place, the food is quite good, especially considering the fact that they are serving 25+ tables at once.  Though service can be a bit slow, you'll usually end up with what you ask for (extra napkins, hot sauce, forks, steamed rice, etc.)

The meal that we had was a late Chinese New Year banquet held by a Chinatown association.  After the requisite firecrackers, lion/dragon dances, and the speeches by important dignitaries, the meal was on.  The best part of the banquet was the deep-fried shrimp balls, the whole crispy chicken, the sliced steak and onions, and the deep-fried fish fillet.  All of those dishes were surprisingly good and tasty and it really helped that the restaurant serves very good steamed rice to go along with them.  The steak and onions in particular are good.  You don't really expect the steak to be as tender as it was, nor do you expect the onions to be sweet as they were.  It came stir-fried in a lovely sauce that begged to be eaten with rice.  We debated for a while to see if we could figure out what was in that sauce so that we might replicate it at home.  

The whole crispy chicken was also surprisingly moist, with a delicious, well-seasoned crisp skin.  My table ate the entire chicken, which is pretty rare for us seasoned banquet eaters.  The deep fried shrimp balls and fish fillet were great because they were yummy (like all deep-fried things) without being oily.  They were HOT though, likely coming straight out of the fryer and onto 25+ platters.

The other dishes - the cold appetizer platter, chicken/squid with broccoli, seafood egg drop soup, and winter melon slices with pork and mushroom- were still good, but not spectacular.

Overall, its very likely that I will be back at New Asia in the future for more CNY banquets (the association has held them here for years now).  The food seems to have gotten better over the years, though the furnishings have remained the same.  New Asia would benefit quite a bit from some new floors, updated restrooms, and new decor overall - something where the room matched the quality of food.  In the meantime though, I know what to expect of the place and will try to keep my mind off the dirty floors and instead, on the delicious food.
author: Angela H.

description:
You know that pushy old Asian woman who elbows you to get on the crowded bus before you do?  Now, imagine her with a plate of tasty sticky buns. 

That pretty much sums up New Asia.
author: Shawn S.

description: Had dimsum here today. It's a fantastic environment - super bustling and upbeat and spirited. The food was normal, but the dimsum ladies are REALLY aggressive. They come up to you and try to give you plates of food, and you have to be like NO, thank you. A little more on the expensive side, but I really just like the ambiance. When I walk home, I always pass by this restaurant, and there is ALWAYS some kind of party/reception in there with all these happy elderly asians.
author: Melody L.

description:
****4/20/08 Update***
Heard that the dim sum chef from Yank Sing came here, so I decided to give it a try.  Everything tasted a bit better than the last time I was here, but presentation wise is still shoddy and service is really lacking.  It doesn't help that their bathroom and kitchen area is so near and I saw puddles of ice water in buckets and I hope they did not use those to serve its customers.
************************
Dim sum here is really okay.  I don't like how they put msg in their dim sum.  Most of the dim sum places don't do that anymore.  They use real ingredients to bring out the flavors, but not here.  The selection is okay.  They need more selection and to create some new dim sums.  They are expensive in the Chinatown standard.  This would probably  be my last resort for dim sum.
author: AhLin C.

description: I always wanted to eat at a Chinese restaurant full of Chinese families sitting around big round tables and talking loudly because that's the indication of a good Chinese restaurant, right? Well, this is the place. This place was packed during weekday lunch around noon and we waited for about 10 minutes - no prob. Their dim sum was pretty good, service was sub-par which was no surprise since I didn't come here for a 5 star service.
author: Kris S.

description: This is one of the better dim sum places in Chinatown. I used to hate the smell of durian pastry, but my client forced me to eat it and I have fallen in love with it ever since. Warm, mushy durian with light crispy shell on the outside is mighty delicious...
author: kate w.

description: Went here for dim sum on a Saturday afternoon, lunch. Considering other dim sum options or lack thereof, surprisingly in Chinatown... It's average, compared to other places I've tried in LA and Chinatowns in Canada. It was loud with a lot of people, but I don't mind that. The wait was surprisingly not that long for my party of 6 (? I forgot...). The dim sum was normal quality.
author: Vera W.

description: If you want dim sum, then this is the place to go.  The food was excellent.  The service was excellent.  It is no wonder this place is packed on the weekend for lunch.
author: Samson W.

description:
This is a pretty good Dim Sum place for a Sunday / Saturday morning. Get there before 11AM to avoid the lines. They have excellent sticky rice, pork buns and shirmp dumplings. 

Parking is a pain but, its in China town so it is to be expected. Find a 2-4$ an hr parking spot and save yourself a headache.
author: Kristina A.

description:
It was packed and crowded.  The shrimp balls were great, but the other things were decent.

Watch out for ordering though.  When we went to pay, the cashier came up with three "totals" for our two person meal:  $42, $28, $36.  The manager screamed bloody murder when he recalculated the total a fourth time AFTER we paid. 

$8 for a dim sum-sized chinese broccoli?   Hell, nah.
author: Marcel M.

description:
I was just at New Asia for a friend's wedding and -- though I was very happy to share this special day -- I wish I had been equally happy with the food.  Instead, it was bland and utterly uninspiring.  The McD's of dim sum.

The faded/peeling wallpaper and the soiled napkin originally placed at my table didn't exactly set a charming ambience, either.

Service was decent, sound system was fine.

But -- and true, this isn't the restaurant's fault -- whatever you do, DON'T PARK AT THE LOT HALF A BLOCK DOWN!  In big print, I saw "$2 per 30 minutes."  Okay, not cheap, but not bad.  Imagine my surprise and disgust, then, when I was told "$25".  Then I noticed the fine print ("$25 from 4 hours, 1 minute and onwards.")  I was parked for 4 hours and 7 minutes.  Bastards.
author: Adam L.

description:
My dim sum place of choice in SF.  Warning: lots of tourists wander in here.

Dim sum hours are 10am - 3pm during the week, 8:30-3 on the weekends.

On Christmas Eve, I'm not sure if they still do this, but at one point they had a Jewish stand-up comedy group here.
author: Brian D.

description:
This might be the last time I ever eat at New Asia.

So I went in a group of five, got a number and waited. We all knew our number. We heard numbers shouted for groups of 3 & 4. But then we heard a table for 6, and I'm wondering, "How come they get to sit down before us?!"

We talked to the lady who was in charge of shouting the numbers. She looked down at her paper, and apologized for missing our number. And then proceeded to seat us.

CUT!

YEAH RIGHT. I WISHED.

I go over and see that that lady had CROSS OUT our number before she even called it.

My Mom talked to her. And the lady gave us attitude! Said that she ALREADY CALLED our number and we didn't respond.

Here's a tip for New Asia.

IF YOU'RE GOING TO LIE TO CUSTOMERS, MAKE SURE THAT:

1. We're old and senile.
2. We're totally deaf.
3. We're wearing earmuffs for some strange reasons.
4. We're not in a group.

I mean, COME ON! We all were standing near her podium listening to her shout numbers! We were HUNGRY! HOW CAN WE HAVE MISSED OUR NUMBER?! WE WERE RIGHT IN FRONT OF HER!

Lost my appetite.

Sat up on the second floor, seemed like the waiters and waitresses were ignoring us.

For my last words: LADY GOT PWNED.
author: Christin A.

description: More expensive than a pure take-out place like Delicious Dim Sum, but I suppose you have the ambience of actually sitting in a restaurant versus a take-out shop. We ordered assorted dim sum for four people and it came out to around $33, so it wasn't terribly expensive either. Don't go towards the end of the lunch rush (~1:30) because by then they'll be out of a lot of dim sum dishes.
author: Alexander L.

description: Authentic dim sum, cheap, but be sure to come early for full selection
author: B R.

description:
I want my dim sum on carts damnit and New Asia fulfills my dim-sum-on-cart fix. I only come here on weekday afternoons when it isn't busy but the carts are flying out the doors. 

The two great things about this place is that the carts are always out, pushed by really nice Chinese ladies that make fun of you when you say a dish wrong and the following dim sum dishes I always get: marinated chicken feet (the red kind), shomai, har-gau (shrimp dumpling), tripe in chili sauce, and the best dessert in the house: flaky egg custard cup things (check out photos here: http://empresspavilion.com/images/dish/egg-custard.jpg).

Last but not least the place is huge, red, and around Chinese New Year (or a reception/banquet) you'll be lucky if lion dancers suddenly storm the place. It's happened to us twice already. 4 stars because parking is a hassel, you'll have to park either in one of the garages in Chinatown or be lucky enough to find metered parking. Either way have fun!
author: Albert B.

description:
There's nothing really special here. I'd probably say it's a tourist trap, but there seems to be more locals than tourists. 

Despite the space, I only saw 4 or 5 carts rolling around. The main things like shrimp dumplings, pork buns, shao mai (not sure of spelling), and fried treats are all here. It seemed to lack everything else. Not that I eat anything else, but I like to believe in completeness. 

$20 for 6 little dishes split amongst two people. $10 per person, and it was not filling. The to-go dim sum places up and down this area is cheaper and from what I can tell, look the same or better for much less.
author: Justin L.

description:
The first time I went here it was so exciting. I had never had dim sum and had no idea what it was all about. Then out come several Chinese ladies pushing carts full of small plates. Luckily I went with a friend who knew what she was ordering and now alot of the dishes she ordered are still my favorite ones. If you know someone who has never done dim sum this is a great authentic place to go where the locals go. 

I enjoy the shu mai (meatballs), rice noodle rolls (white noodles that look a bit like an enchilada served with a black sauce and can have shrimp in them), taro root (pictured here - looks like refried beans formed into a ball with a light crispy outer shell), shrimp dumplings (clear noodle filled with shrimp) and then the standard BBQ pork buns (good for those less adventurous types). The only think I tried recently that I would never do again is the flavored rice (flavored with what I don't know but nothing good)
author: Dianne M.

description:
The short and fat:  
Better than average Dim Sum.  Price is cheap.  Crowds are nuts.  

I haven't been there for dinner, so this is only a review of Dim Sum.  If you go Sunday or Saturday morning, get there early.  If you don't you will wait for a long time.  The crowds are truly like those in China.  Everybody pushes and shoves.  No personal space.  The dim sum was one of the better ones in SF.  Yank Sing is the best, but you pay for it ($$$$).  New Asia is much cheaper and the quality is pretty good.
author: Anthony L.

description:
I've only been to this place for dim sum....and I've tried to give it a fair shot. Been here probably 3 or 4 times. And each time, I'm disappointed.

The pieces of dim sum are just too big. They tend to choose quantity over quality and it's just not that good. 

Regarding their service, it's terrible. I've grown up around Chinese restaurants all my life. I'm used to the way they function and their attitudes, but if I have to wait a half an hour for my water after they already screwed up calling my number while I was waiting for a table....I definitely have to dock them for it.

Find a different restaurant for dim sum. It's their location that keeps them afloat.
author: Irene D.

description: I've been to this restaurant MANY times and I still quite like this place. The restaurant is a huge room filled with tables...so you can bet that it's going to be loud in there. I think the atmosphere, noise level,  and amount of people in the room just add to the experience of eating dim sum in Chinatown. The food is always consistent and I've been going here for years. We always order the sticky rice in lotus leaf, chicken feet, pork dumplings, barbecue pork buns, shrimp dumplings, shrimp in rice noodle, tofu, egg tarts and the list goes on and on...all of it really delicious. I love how the servers still serve the food on the metal carts and it just adds to the experience of eating authentic dim sum. It's located in the heart of Chinatown and if you're in the area, I recommend trying this restaurant if you enjoy eating some good dim sum!
author: Christiana R.

description: This is a great place for dim sum. My co workers and I trek over here during the week and are always reward with fresh and tasty food. The char siu bao and har gao are particularly delicious!
author: Y C.

description: We've gone to this restaurant almost every time we are in town and have noticed a gradual decline in the decor and the food quality.  The decor is dated but you're going there for the food... The dim sum is not as good as it was, compared to the increased prices.  Yes, it is a large restaurant and can get loud, but that is typical of a dim sum restaurant in Chinatown.  As for the language barrier, the fun is in the pointing at the food and being surprised (in a good way, not to diminish any food allergies) at what you're getting.
author: Yummy T.

description:
I came here with one of my couples and her parents.  She's Chinese and promised me a safe first time dim sum experience, sans chicken feet or anything crazy.  I definitely love trying new things and was happy to check it out.

I thought it was cool how people just push around carts full of steamers and different dishes.  My bride's parents kind of took over (which I was thankful for because I had no idea,) and asked what I liked so they knew what to grab off each of the trays.  We had shrimp balls (is there a more eloquent term for that?) chow mein, Chinese brocolli, egg rolls, some kind of noodle dish with lobster, and some baked custard dessert.  The shrimp balls were really good, although it was kind of annoying that there was so much wrapper and it kept falling apart as I was trying to eat it.  The chow mein and lobster noodle dish were both really good, although I'm not surprised because those were definitely our "safe" items.  I love brocollini so I was pretty happy to have some green stuff on the plate.  We started jokingly calling the egg rolls "fried egg wrappers" because there wasn't much in them and it was pretty much all wrapper.  The custard was really good but I was completely full by the time I got to it so I didn't get to enjoy much.

Just like other people have said, and I wasn't really expecting, the service definitely isn't a 5 star standard. But I'm pretty sure you don't come to dim sum for that.  The women pushing the carts around were all friendly and there was always someone around.  It was super loud but I figure if the place is packed it must be good.  My bride's parents took care of the bill so I'm not sure how much it was, but I'm pretty sure it was really reasonable.  I would definitely come back here the next time I'm in SF.
author: Kim J.

description:
I was once a fan. I've since lost faith.
The food was (once) decent, the atmosphere is somewhat authentic, and the prices are reasonable. With that said, my most recent trip to New Asia will be my last. Why?
1) The waitress preemptively calculated her tip into our bill for us. I know you don't go to Chinatown for 5 star service but come on! 
2) The food gave four college students, who are used to eating dining common garbage, food poisoning.
author: Courtney C.

description: We dined here in the evening, which clearly was a mistake - the dining room was devastated from the lunchtime dim sum service, so there was trash all around on the floor and only two other parties dining. The potstickers were very good, but the cashew chicken was bland (poor quality chicken used) and the veggie chow mein was made veggie with--onion?  The service was average, but I wouldn't recommend this restaurant for dinner at all.
author: C R.

description: Make sure you go before the lunch crowd for dim sum or expect a wait.  We went at 10:30 which was good.  There was a long line when we left.  Lots of dim sum coming by on carts and very good.  The staff can speak English so don't be afraid to use it.  I was nearly the only non Chinese customer and to me, that's a good sign of a great Chinese restaurant.
author: Bonnie F.

description: More like 3.5.  For china-town dimsum this so far is one of the better ones we've tried.  Fairly good price per quality ratio for the area.
author: Mike S.

description: Plenty of tables, extensive Cantonese menu and the food came out very fast.  They do typical Cantonese "meat over rice" dishes well and the chow-fun with beef and peppers was delicious.  Very casual and can go any time of day.  My family went mid-afternoon after visiting the Chinese Historical Society and the docent there recommended this place.  He obviously knew what we liked!
author: Wayne Y.

description:
took a cousin-in-law here this past saturday around 1pm.  restaurant was full and we waited for about 15 minutes to be seated.  dim sum is there specialty, and wow, these things are huge! think dim sum on steroids times 10.  lots of tasty choices.  minus one star for the non-attentive service...although i will give them credit as anytime we waved them down, they did stop and try to help us, except for this one lady who kept passing us up.  seemed like she was a supervisor for service of some sort.

be prepared to look for parking, or just make it easier on yourself and park in the lot down the street.

good stuff!
author: Ray R.

description:
I have been to the SF Chinatown more times than I can remember, but I have never gone with a tour guide. My chef instructor set up a tour with Rhoda Yee for this past Saturday and I decided to go and maybe learn a few things about chinatown. We had a group of 22 and walked around for about 3 hrs. The guide chose New Asia for our dim sum experience. When she told us, I realized I had been there before many years before. I remember it being a decent place. Well, since we were eating with a bunch of people that had different backgrounds and food budgets, we all decided she could order for both tables. She ordered the standard stuff, like shrimp dumping, pork dumpling, deep fried taro ball, chinese gai lan, bbq pork bun...etc..

Well, all I can say is my tastes have changed dramatically since the last time I ate here. All the food was mediocre to bad. Not a single dim sum dish was outstanding. I was full when we were done eating but not satisfied. Luckily the bill came out to be $15 including tax and tip which is not too pricey. But on the way to this place, we walked past a dim sum restaurant that advertised $5.99 for all you can eat. I think that would have been a better deal. I have been spoiled by Joy Luck in Cupertino and Koi Palace in Daly City which are heads and shoulders above this place.
author: Andy B.

description:
I remembered coming to New Asia a couple of years ago when a friend from New York came to visit. Expectations were never too high when having dim sum in Chinatown. We knew it wasn't the cleanest, but we do know it was cheap. We ordered a few items and started to eat. 

As I picked up my Xiao Lung Bao, my friend was tells me to wait, he sees something. I turned it around and find a mouse poop stuck onto the bottom. I was horrified and immediately grabbed a waiter for an explanation. At first she claims that it's probably just a burnt rice, and I shoved it closer to her face so she can have a better look. She finally admits to it and offers to exchange for another order of Xiao Lung Bao in a real UNWILLINGLY way. I was like no way.... they all came from the same batch. 

I was so disgusted in what I found and disappointed in how they try to take care of the situation. They didn't apologize or anything. I just paid the bill with no tip and just stormed out of the restaurant.

I will not be going back to New Asia any time soon!
author: Ray W.

description:
Old School Dim Sum and Banquet Hall

New Asia is your parent's parents dim sum restaurant.  The food is cheap, the service is rushed, and the crowd is old.  During the morning and afternoon, New Asia is a bustling dim sum restaurant.  By night, it turns into a dinner and banquet hall.  Many weddings and special events have been thrown here over the years.  To fully enjoy your experience at New Asia, you will have to follow my grandmother's infinite wisdom.

Granny says:  Give me you chopsticks so I can rinse this off before we eat.

To be fair, I do not believe that New Asia is dirty.  I rarely trip over the cleaniness of this place. But, New Asia is old school when it comes to sanitation. The servers clear tables by tossing everything into big black tubs while wiping off tables with left over tea and a dirty side towel.  Remember to treat your paper placemats like gold.  The bathrooms are stinky, lets just leave it there.

One thing that is cool about New Asia is that your table can become communal at anytime.  During peak hours, you can be sitting along with complete strangers.

Granny says:  I've been sitting here for 5 minutes and I haven't seen any pork buns pushed by here yet. Waiter! Let's get some pork buns!

New Asia offers dim sum cart service. The food is very standard.  You get all the usual favorites.  Har gou, siu mai, pork buns, chickens feet, egg rolls, etc.. Remember to be aggressive because your favorite item might be gone before the server has made its round to you.

Granny Says:  Don't you sell me that same plate of egg rolls you were pushing around here an hour ago.

Granny Says: Make sure they marked that plate of har gou as a small plate on our card.

I'm not saying New Asia will try to rip you off.  But I trust my grandmother's infinite wisdom.
author: Sam T.

description: Great Dim Sum place. Walking into the restaurant is impressive. It's huger and you have to go down one small set of stairs. You basically look over a fully seated area with chandeliers hanging from a high ceiling when you get in. The food is very good and service is fast. .
author: Erdmann R.

description:
This is the ideal dim sum place for English speakers, and there are tons of tables so you won't have a long wait on those busy weekend afternoons.

(P.S. Is this really technically Nob Hill??)
author: Rego S.

description:
We came here with my best friend's granny on a weekday and there was a HUGE lineup! Well over 1.5 hours wait. Luckily the little granny had the hook-up with the manager (??) so we were able to skip that ...

I must say I loved the dan-tat. Big and creamy. Yum. And the food was all enormous .. it looked like it was pumped with steroids. Can't really go wrong ... ?

But while it was pumped with steroids, it was also laden with MSG. I think I still tasted the MSG two days later. Now THAT ... is pretty gross! 

Overall, it was decent. Perpetual MSG is pretty yucky, but you can't really ask too much from cheap dim sum.
author: Emily C.

description: attend a big dinner banquet here, about 30 tables, and very impressed with their dishes. Didn't expect much from such a big party but everything dish is good! Not easy for such a big party. So I am going to come back for dinner soon.
author: Jenny C.

description:
OK, so I actually am giving this place 5 stars for memories but it's a definite 2 star for the food. I have never eaten here except for my annual family dinners. Every year since I was little my family has taken this restaurant over for a night and the family association Dinners are held. I can remember the food being a lot better hen I was younger. Better in quality and quantity. But the world is a changing place, no more sharks fin soup, plates come to us congealed in their own fat, either the squab got smaller or I got a lot bigger. The ducks aren't as meaty and the veggies are way to blanched out. I don't think I would recommend anyone looking for an authentic Asian fare to come here. It's only a few steps away form being Panda Express. 

The place is kind of dingy and I always wipe my utensils but when I come here I feel like I have to use purell for everything.
author: Alia D.

description:
At first glance the place seemed to offer a wonderful meal. We were seated very fast. 

For dim sum, we were disappointed. The tastes were blend, we couldn't have shrimp dumpling which be told we would get it. 

Go elsewhere for better dim sum.
author: Chin C.

description:
Xiao Lung Bao Rating: 2 Baos 
(good soup dumplings but RED VINEGAR?!?!?!?! AIYA!!!)

New Asia is our default dim sum place for any weekend morning. There's always a wait but we've gotten used to the ritual of hanging out with friends outside the restaurant on sunny days and chat away. I don't know why some people would complain about this wait when they happily wait HOURS for mediocre brunch at Mama's, puh-lease.

Dim sum here is decent. More like the Hong Kong neighborhood style than the up-scale expensive TsimShaTsui waterfront kind. They still use the dim sum push carts. We usually pay around $15 per head but then remember we eat like pigs. SO for normal people it'll be around $10 per head.

Best attribute is that they have ToFuFa scooped up from the wooden barrel, so old style and yummie. Lady always gives us more syrup if asked.

I just love this place. Go to City View / Koi Palace / South Sea for upscale dim sum. Come to New Asia to be happy, loud, obnoxious, warm, dirty, get soy sauce all over the table cloth kinda fun.
author: DANIEL T.

description: I checked up on their food score at the DPH.  It is now in the range of the 50's (out of 100).  In LA they would be hanging an F placard in their window.  But, this is San Francisco were the restaurant lobby is more important than people who could die from food poisoning or contract highly contagious diseases from poorly maintained/prepared foods.
author: Robert S.

description: Came here yesterday for a dim sum lunch...was disappointed.  nothing we ate was good and to make matters worse, they kept turning off the AC--we were hot and sweaty sitting in the back.  it was not an enjoyable lunch...food wasnt good...the only thing decent was the lobster and e-noodle dish....3 stars for that dish....1 star for the dim sum.
author: sonya h.

description: Good dim sum, really good price.  Kinda long wait though, and can be tough if you don't speak chinese.
author: Matt F.

description:
This is by far the BEST-est dim sum restaurant in Bay area!
I have eaten at so many so I know :)
Har Kow, BBQ pork bun, tan tart, oyster kai lan - my personal favorites.
author: Tina O.

description: We were a group of 6 going for lunch on a Saturday at around 12-12:30pm. We waited in the lobby and were later seated. We ordered a variety of things from chicken feet to baos and Chinese broccoli. I think the best thing we ordered was... the broccoli. The baos were just O-K and the chicken feet was COLD! It was as if the dish wasn't entirely heated up as the dish was room temp/cold in the middle. The flavors and spices weren't flavorful at all. As a visitor to SF and it being my second time having dim sum in the city, I was quite disappointed with this place.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Well I guess everyone knows how the restaurants in Chinatown is like - good food but without decoration. 
3 stars for dim sum and 4 stars for dinner at this place. 
Dim sum is on the average side and so is the service but dinner is surprisingly good. The dishes were less salty and greasy then I thought it should be. I highly recommend their seafood dishes (stir-fried shrimp with veggie, etc) and their roasted chicken. 
Oh, their deep fried fish fillet with pepper and salt is so good that I had 5 pcs in a roll. Very thin batter so it doesn't cover up the taste of the fish and the fish is very fresh.
author: Ms Piggy W.

description:
I understand this isn't the best dim sum in San Francisco - but selfishly I would make my friends come with me so I wasn't suicidally trying to do dim sum for one.
There was a method to my madness though!  The first time I randomly wandered in I had bao that tasted exactly like the ones my grandmother made!  Unfortunately for us, she just called them "sweet bao" and "salty bao," making it difficult to order them at dim sum.  Imagine the looks someone trying to order "salty bao" would get!
Sadly, I never found those random bao again.  :(
author: Adrienne W.

description:
The restaurant has decent food and the atmosphere is nice. If you don't mind Chinese people chattering, it's quite lively on weekends. Price is standard. Expect $10-$15 a person. Wait time is usually 10-15 minutes max. 
--------------------------------
As a general note, you should be paying on average:
$3.50 for Small
$4.00 for Medium
$5.00 for Large
$1.00 for Tea per person (refills are free)

Remember those stamps on the paper? That's the tab keeper for the dishes. First line is Small. Second is Medium. Third line is Large. The last couple lines are chef specialties and off-the-cart orders aka menu orders (prices vary in restaurants for these two). You can easily get an estimate if you follow said price guide (excluding the special lines). Anything priced more than above guideline, the food better be mind-boggling. Keep in mind, dim sum is not something you can easily slap together in a few minutes like those $10 dishes in chain restaurants. Each one is hand made in authentic Chinese dim sum restaurants. So don't expect dim sum to be " super cheap" unless you want to sacrifice quality. 

Also, learn to be more aggressive. As a rule in Chinese dim sum restaurants, you are expected to assert yourself. They aren't going to wait hand and foot on you like a dog, unlike American waiters. Sure, they'll check up on you maybe once, but they give you your space. You are there to talk to your companions and not your waiter. If you need something, flag them down. They expect you to. 

/end tips
author: M W.

description: This is a great place for authentic dim sum. You will not get great service. You will not see a great ambiance (by western standards), but you WILL get excellent Chinese Dim Sum! There are far and few dim sum places that still push the dim sum carts around the restaurant. You 'll actually get great dim sum (like Yank Sing, but 1/4 of the price, literally!). For a great Authentic Dim Sum experience, I totally recommend. To dress and impress with ambiance and service... not the best venue. I come back here for my dim sum soul food!
author: Kathleen T.

description:
I don't eat dim sum too often, but when I do, this is the place I go.  
I was entertaining some friends from out of town and they want a Chinatown "experience".
Went right before noon on a Friday and the place was packed.  As an Asian friend told me, the more Asians in a Chinese restaurant, the better it is.  Let's just say my group was the only non-Asian table there.
We got seated immediately and before we even had a chance to settle in, we were bombarded with food.  We were in a bit of a time crunch, so that was helpful.  The servers don't speak English too well, so just be patient and they can usually tell you if you're eating shrimp, pork, beef, etc.
Long story short, the food was great, got to try some new and interesting looking items, and at the end, the bill came out to $60, for four guys.  Not too bad in my opinion. 
Will definitely go back.
author: Robert F.

description: If I could give them 0 stars I would!  My husband and I were visiting San Francisco and were so excited to go to China Town there.  When we passed by this restaurant and saw Dim Sum, we were excited to have real good food.  Everything we ordered, was left half finished.  If we weren't so hungry, we wouldn't have ate anything!  The food was very tasteless and messy.  I had a stomach ache after I ate.  The atmosphere wasn't set for dinner.  The news was on!  News flash for the owners, it is very unhealthy to watch news when eating a family dinner!  When we got our check, we tipped 10%.  We are in a service industry and when we tip, we usually tip 20-30% but in this case we shouldn't have tipped anything but did tip 10% because the person delivering the food was nice.  When our waiter saw that we tipped 10%, he looked at us and said, and I quote, "We require you to tip 15% or more."  You never tell a customer what to tip because it's a TIP!  I don't have more to say... would not recommend to anyone.
author: Acsanna G.

description:
CONTEXT:
Came here for cousin's wedding banquet, so obviously didn't have dim sum but banquet food.

FOOD:
-Type: Chinese Wedding Banquet 
-Variety: chosen set
-Quality: not bad, not spectacular. it was good. no hairs, not too greasy.
-Quantity: more than enough for a table of 8. 
-Price: the wedding couple paid so i wouldn't know but i suspect at least 300-500+ per table including the hennessy

SERVICE:
-Employees: quick. no time for friendliness. 
-Timeliness: fast.

ENVIRONMENT:
-Location: easy to spot from street, parking on street can be difficult to get
-Ambience: typical chinese banquet feel. 
-Decor: 2-story restaurant, hd-tvs to show the main wedding couple table which was pretty cool. well-decorated for weddings. open wide space.
-Cleanliness: could be cleaner...some plates are chipped...

OVERALL: the wedding banquet hall looked great. the extra star is for the tvs. didn't seem to have a hitch with the food.
-Would attend again? it's out of my way. i live in san jose.
author: Amy C.

description:
I think a 3 or 3.5 star rating is in order for this place.  It's a pretty authentic dim sum experience, due to the immense size of the place, the hustle and bustle of carts, and the tasty dishes.   One particular aspect of the food:  the har gow and siu mai seem to be bigger than other places that I've been too, which is a good thing IMO, and the quality is there.

It's pricier than dim sum I've had in the Outer Richmond, but the fact that it's walking distance from my apartment is extremely appealing.
author: Andrew G.

description: Very so so.  It's huge, so it's good for a big group.  It's relatively inexpensive, and it's cart dimsum (which you can point and pick from ongoing carts rather ordering from a menu)  However, the quality of dimsum is not that great.  It's flavorful and serviceable, but lacks the delicacy.   I'm still in look-out for that perfect dimsum place - taste, delicacy, variety of dishes, and reasonable price.  ( Yank Sing would been good except for $$$$ )
author: Yoon L.

description:
A great go-to staple for dim sum whenever I'm in the SF area.

I've been coming here since I was a wee boy and my grandma dragged me with other relatives to yum dom cha. 

It's your classic dim sum place with waiters pushing carts shouting out their wares, and you telling them what you want. The food is always good and there is a slight wait (5-10 minutes) sometime as it can get busy. They also host a lot of weddings, events, kaoroke, etc.
author: David L.

description: Can I give this zero stars. This is a restaurant I have rated highly in the past, eating there over forty times in many years. The last three times we noted the food and service and even cleanliness have definitely gone downhill.  Today we decided to try it one more time. We had a hard time getting any favorites off the carts.  There was little selection. What we did get was inferior dim sum. The service was rushed and rude.  Noise was unbelievably loud. The restrooms were filthy.  When I commented on the problems to the lady taking our money, she shrugged with indifference.  Goodby old favorite. We will never eat there again.
author: Kathleen P.

description: This place is ginormous. All of the typical food from a dim sum place you would expect would be here. Service is plentiful as there are nonstop carts. Pretty reasonable prices. I would expect it being expensive for being in such a large and nice venue. Not bad for a quick stop! It is definitely crowded during the lunch hours but the wait isn't usually very long.
author: Spencer H.

description: Don't be scared off by the loud Asian woman screaming out the numbers. Embrace her. She beholds the right to offering you your table amongst the dim sum crowd. The dim sum fare was pretty average in terms of selection. I enjoyed the carts that were being pushed around. I hate how dim sum in Chicago is starting to turn more into ordering off a list instead of the carts. Everything was pretty delish except for the chicken feet. It didn't seem like it was cooked all the way and the gelatinous saucy/fat was still....gelatiny. A nice surprise was the siu long bao. Definitely don't have that in Chicago dim sum.
author: Diana T.

description:
Was not very impressed.  

The gailan - with oyster sauce - the oyster sauce was oystery (not a word I know)   but oyster suace typically doesn't taste like seafood so when it does i get scared.

The radish cakes - were like microwaved
The salty dumplings ( fried dumplings balls) had barely any meat inside althought great crispines on the outside.
author: Joey N.

description:
i went here today to eat Dim Sum at lunch with my grandparents.
it's really bust the Dim Sum is pretty good but not the best ..

I also saw some tourist eating a couple tables away.Most tables where full by Noon.
author: Eric W.

description:
Great food, and very reasonable prices. We all left stuffed, with leftovers, and paying about $12 each.

The building is kind of an experience in itself - it looks like an old ballroom, kind of tacky, with goldish chrome on everything, disco balls and presentation screens hanging from the ceiling and walls, clearly a multi-use area. The entrance is supremely crowded and noisy, with the hostess calling out numbers in english and cantonese with a wonderful sort of rhythm. Unused chairs and broken furniture are unceremoniously stacked next to the waiting area. For me, this all added to the charm, the sense that this restaurant wastes not and wants not, the sense that this is truly a Chinese restaurant.

I can't compare this to other SF dim sum restaurants, but this beat the stuffing out of dim sum in San Diego and Chicago.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
Having yet to find a decent dim sum place in my hometown of Dallas, I was anxious to get to New Asia when I was in San Francisco  this week. In fact I was so homesick for good dim sum that I insisted my sisters and I go straight to get Dim Sum when we landed at SFO.

New Asia was filled with Asian people speaking Chinese to each other. It has a massive dining room. The ladies roll out the dim sum carrts in front of you and you point (if you can't speak Chinese) and they place the item on the table.

We ordered the standards, har gau, siu mai, shrimp pouch (tasty and not greasy, don't bother with the mayo sauce), and baked char siu bao. The baked char siu bao was delicious, and just the right size (4 to an order). The taro gok was so lovely. It had a smooth and silky texture and the outside was crispy and delightful.

Our favorite dish was the gai lan, the broccoli.  It surprised me at first because it was cold, but it was cooked just right to preserve the beautiful green color. The addition of the oyster sauce to dip the broccoli in was a nice touch.

I did not try the lobster noodle, although it was quite popular and ordered all around us.  Maybe next time...the dim sum is what this place is known for.

About the bathrooms...if you have been to any restaurant in Chinatown you experience as my nephew puts it, "going into a third world country.'  Well we decided before we go up to Jackson Market we needed to go to the powder room before we left.  The bathrooms were clean and decent, what a relief.  I know it might be tacky to discuss the bathroom facilities of a restaurant, but I am telling you this is of utmost important. You know the theory...filthy bathroom, filthy kitchen.

This is my favorite dim sum place.
author: JC F.

description: Here is how I rate the Dim Sum Restaurants.  By far the best and most expensive is Yank Sing...mortage the house before you go.  Second Tong Kiang on Geary Blvd. then New Asia.  That being said.. I went there with out of town guests and wanted something in China Town.  I loved the fact that it was big and bustling felt like i was in Hong Kong.  I completely agree   that  some of the cart people were rude but that may be part of the atmosphere.  We went late 1:45 so the choices were limited but what we had was quite good, but no buns with the duck, and no  bbq pork.  The Ha Gow (shrimp dumplings) were the best,, big filled with whole shrimp.  Small baked pork buns good too .  If you want chow mein (kid is not fond of Dim Sum) you have to order it of the menu the cart ladies do not bring it around. Defenitely would take out of towners back again for the food and atmosphere.
author: rassors T.

description:
Chinese restaurants are difficult to rate. Some people like to eat "American" style chow mein, fried rice and sweet and sour pork and will downgrade restaurants that have anything that vaguely tastes authentic. Some people like it loaded with grease and sauces that will put you in a hospital. Others like it bland. You can find all kinds in Chinatown. If you like Chinese food, look at the clientele. If the place is largely patronized by white middle Americans raving about the food, I would recommend staying away as the food is guaranteed to be bland and lousy. If the place is patronized largely by Asians, then you might assume that the place is pretty authentic. The key is to be patient and develop the skill sets needed to ordering and be a customer. Ordering and being served in a Chinese restaurant take talents and many people go away angry because they don't have a clue on how to handle themselves. What has this got to do with New Asia? Everything if you're going there for Dim Sum. I didn't go there for Dim Sum (although I hope to someday). However I have gone there for banquets with at least 1,000 other people and that's what I'm going to rate. Do Chinese people eat here? You bet they do!! The events I've been to have been organized by the Six Companies and you can't get anymore authentic than that. Was the service good? You bet it was. Nine courses were served at regular intervals and at no time were the tables cluttered up with uneaten food. Was the food good? It was outstanding. Nothing was greasy or loaded up with putrid hoisan sauce. It was all hot (or cold if it was supposed to be cold) and was fresh and tasty. What particularly impressed me was the way they were able to serve over a 1000 people and get it right. The Chinese community establishment likes it and I Ike it. I'll be back for Dim Sum one of these days so stay tuned. 
P.S. There wasn't any sweet sour concoction, fried rice, chow mein or other traditional "American" concoctions in the food. However, the variety was sufficient to suit any palate.
author: Robert H.

description: if you come here this will be the dirtiest place you have ever been in. the utensils doesn't seem like it's been washed. the tables and chairs are all broken! the workers are pretty rude. i don't recommend this place to anyone.
author: Bella W.

description: I come for dim sum when I am in the City and the food has been consistent.  The shrimp dumplings and shrimp rice noodles with sweet soy are not as delicate as those found at Joy Luck down in Cupertino or Koi Palace near Serramonte, but the price is definitely cheaper and the location convenient to exploring Chinatown.  I have been enjoying New Asia Chinese Restaurant for over 3 decades (used to be Asia Garden), and have not been disappointed.  The line is long on the weekends and for holidays (mother's day, especially), so get there early!
author: Tosh L.

description: I forgot how good dim sum is. New Asia reminded me :)
author: Sue L.

description: The sweetie and I headed here on a Saturday and had maybe a 15-20 minute wait (not too bad).  The food was good -- of course, we had that well-earned, waited-for-dim-sum-hunger on, so by the time we found our table (literally, the hostess said, "Just go in the back!") I ordered 3 things from the first cart that came by.  (Luckily, fried shrimp, pork buns, and some kind of egg roll.)    I also recommend the taro stuff and the sesame balls. Overall, we liked the food and--despite not being guided to a table, which is slightly scary when one has low blood sugar and needs her shu mei, STAT--we will likely come back at some point.
author: M. H.

description:
we hold our family parties here... and that's a guest list usually of 1500 people or more. it's usually once a year to welcome in the new year. since the space is humungous... we can do almost anything here. there's a stage for the speakers and those who wanna karaoke later and of course there's enough room for the lion dancers.

the dim sum here is great. varieties are endless. plus you can always order specials from the kitchen during lunch time. since they have that many tables (and my fmaily knows the hostess) we get seated right away. i'd recommend this place to people from out of town.

yeah i agree with everyone about the bathroom. it's just disgusting.
author: Mei N.

description: Never have dim sum at 2 pm. My mom had told me a long time ago to go early and now I remember why. New Asia ran out of food, and the waitresses were in a hurry to clean up, so they would bypass our aisle and not serve us and other patrons. I saw one lady do this so I followed her method. Basically chase the cart down and pick my own food (I brought the bill so that it would get stamped by the server). I also got my own forks and we had to order the soup and water twice in order to get it at all. I felt like my mother,who tends to be very assertive in Chinese restaurants in order to get attention.  The bathrooms were also disgusting so I had to take my son to grandma's house (nearby) or find another public bathroom. Never again! My mom had told me not to go here (also expensive compared to other places). Like they say,  MOTHER KNOWS BEST!
author: Lulubelle L.

description: This is the dim sum restaurant you take your out-of-town friends, when you give them the SF tour. It decent enough, and they seem to really enjoy the ambiance and the food (because they don't know any better). But if you want the good stuff, go to Koi Palace.
author: Mary T.

description: I used to come here for dim sum a lot when I was younger but I haven't been back for a long time... We came here for a wedding banquet the other night... the place isn't really set up that great for one.  The wedding banquet only occupied the lower level but I think the entire restaurant was closed... The tables are really small and cramped and really close together.  The food is actually pretty good for banquet food.  We had this seabass that was really yummy!!  I heard they have dancing and dinner nights on Friday nights which is really cute... there aren't that many big restaurants in Chinatown anymore...
author: Kymberli C.

description:
sad to say, when i was young i thought this place was the best restaurant in CT and the biggest.  but how naive i was then.  i'm since grown up and developed a better palate. had dim sum here with a couple of friends who were visiting SF, my sister and my nephew.  dim sum isn't too bad but it isn't great.  if you want better dim sum, better look outside of CT  in Daly City or Sunset which is a definite upgrade.  wait wasn't too long though, maybe like 3 minutes tops? surely beats the hour wait at Koi Palace in Daly City.  

ever since i moved down to LA though, i've been spoiled by the good dim sum out in Rowland Heights so Koi Palace would probably be your best bet for dim sum if you're willing to deal with the wait
author: Tony L.

description: Good selection of dim sum, place gets really crowded.  But you can find similar dim sum places around the east bay and even south bay.  Cheap.  Only reservation is cleanliness, I've been to cleaner establishments.
author: Ryan B.

description: enormous multi-level dim sum estalishment......slow carts making rotations....ladies carrying trays of various small plates.....cart items seem steaming hot, yet the selection was lackin'....tray items often appeared cold and had been sitting for hours.....for $12 per person dim sum brunch....it won't break the bank....
author: Hen A.

description: New Asia for dim sum - Good Enough! It's not the cream of the crop in terms of Bay Area dim sum quality, but most things are satisfactory. It was THE place for dim-summing with family as I grew up, so I suspect that's why we're so loyal. It's huge, so there's always room to eat on weekdays. All the seniors still come here to have a few bites, cups of tea, and rounds of gossip. Siu mai is good and big. Ha gows are standard.
author: Emily L.

description: I'm not an expert on "siu lung bows" but good ones are hard to find in San Francisco. Most dim sum restaurants I go to are terrible, soupless and weird tasting. However, this restaurant has some pretty delicious ones filled with actual soup. The rest of the dimsum here is pretty good. Once they see a tourist, they sure go after them with weird plates.
author: Michael T.

description: Really good Dim Sum.  The fried chicken is great.  Sorry guys, but New Asia is a good dim sum place.  The pork buns, dumplings and sesame balls are all good.  Beware of the bathrooms..don't ask, but I think there are experiments going on in there.
author: Chris W J.

description: This is my favorite chinese dim sum restaurant in China Town. I've been coming here since I was a baby. The food is delicious, the price is average, and the service is wonderful. My brother once broke a teacup by dropping it by accident, they said it was okay and they cleaned it up and gave him a new one. They were really nice. Best Dim Sum around.
author: Claudia M.

description: I just went to a big banquet dinner here and it was everything I expected it to be:  dirty dishes and good seafood.  You just have to wash everything with hot tea like you do in the motherland.  The cuttlefish and jellyfish were awesome.  The fish with head intact was pretty good.  The reconstituted oysters were a little too much for some but I was in gnarly seafood heaven.  My biggest complaint was the dessert...no almond jello!  Just tiny dry cookies.  Maybe you have to ask.
author: Victoria G.

description: My family has been going to New Asia for many years but it's definitely gone down-hill recently. For starters, every dish seems so much more greasy than I had remembered from childhood. And I feel like they totally take advantage of you if you don't speak Chinese!! We had our orders tallied up and it came to $50!! Kind of expensive for 4 ppl and we didn't even have very much to eat (maybe 6-8 dishes??). Then the lady comes over and tells us we need to pay 10% on top of what we already paid for the "service charge." Total BS. My mom (who speaks fluent mandarin) was never charged this extra fee. To save face, we paid, but I am never going back for dim sum again. No one speaks english so it's not like we could have tried to argue with them. Bleh....just unfortunate b/c i used to love coming here.
author: Corrina S.

description: One of the last tea houses in SF 'old' Chinatown.  I haven't been here in a couple of years, but recently "yem cha'd."  I was surprised at how good it was.  The dim sum was succulent and delicious!  Although, I can't comprehend how this place can demand such a high price for their 'har gow' (shrimp dumpling ~$3.20) when every other place around town (with the exception of Koi Palace) are charging less than $2.50 for a plate.  The rent must be skyrocketing.  We sat on the 2nd floor and the traffic (of food carts) was not as plentiful as on the 1st floor.  I think we missed out on a lot of other goodies.  The restaurant is very large, which I never realized before.  Big enough for 2 wedding banquets.  Not bad for one of the 'old' kids on the block.
author: JeFF T.

description: Never again.  Terrible service and feel like we got taken. We were a party of 9  We walked in and it was super busy at 2:50. We were seated but they didn't tell us that it closes at 3:00 so we ended up getting cold, chewy dim sum. They asked if we wanted tea and said no but they put tea on our table and ended paying $9 for a pot of tea. Knowing Chinese would probably have helped as they seemed totally confused when we asked if we could see a menu to order some noodle dishes.  We saw the carts still with food but they never came back to our table. We decided to leave and eat elsewhere. Oh floors were filthy dirty. $45 later and still hungry. Waitress actually said we should leave a tip. As we were walking out we noticed that people who had come in after us were getting dishes from the kitchen so that really peeved us so we took our tip back. Will never go back. Terrible, terrible, unorganized service.
author: Sara M.

description: Came here yesterday with my parents who were in town and love them some dim sum.  It was solid but nothing out of the ordinary.  It did have these shrimp noodle things that I remember getting when I was a child but havent actually seen since then so that was a nice suprise.  Service was attentive if not a bit pushy.  I definately letft very satisfied.  Probably biggest complaint is that the pieces of dim sum were all huge which limited the variety we could order.
author: Robert U.

description: This place was amazing!  You have to know it's good when there's a 20 minute wait when there's 200 other chinese restaurants within 5 blocks.  Had Dim Sum on Labor day here and it blew us away.  Had a beer, tea, 6 or so dishes and we were stuffed.  Best part was when the bill came for $28.  Just go, you will be happy you did.
author: Alex A.

description: We were recommended this place by some locals in chinatown for some cheap but tasty dimsum bc my friend and i were really craving some. The service is fast and they had a good variety of seafood dim sum which hit the spot for both of us.
