The portions were big and flavorful and i thought it was pretty good in comparison to other dim sum places ive eaten at for the price we paid. He ate a lot more than i did, so I think he really enjoyed it. I thought it was good, and filled me up enough that we walked all the way to the pier and had a late lunch there. They also gave us a calendar for new years bc we went a few days after christmas.
author: Thao T.

description: Food is good, the service can be slow for the weekend but it was pretty packed
author: Coco L.

description: I love how crazy this place is.  It adds to the whole SF experience.  The food is good, the service is very surley and the people watching is so much fun!
author: Jacki W.

description: This feels like a traditional dim sum place. They do the overcrowded dining rooms that smell of grease with the carts coming by every few minutes. Felt like Hong Kong. Granted, the foot pales in comparison to the traditional stuff, they did do a few things well. Their siu mai & roast pork buns were good. Service wasn't amazing (water was a rare commodity), but what can you expect? This is chinatown & it's a dim sum restaurant, you don't come here for the service! The price was *amazing* my group of 8 ate until our stomachs were on the verge of exploding and still managed to only hit $117. Not bad, not bad at all.
author: linda t.

description: This was my first dim sum experience, my friends (all asians) said it was a really nice atmosphere because they still push around the carts and apparently they dont do that at most dim sum places anymore. some of the dishes were ok, some i almost puked, and i dont think that i will ever be eating dim sum again, at least not for awhile. while i normally love authentic chinese food, this is just not for me. ive heard that there were much better places to eat dim sum as well. and i thought it was hella spendy for the prices of other places in china town in oakland that my friends were telling me about, so basically i felt like for the little amount i ate, i could have be a lot more satisfied and spent a lot less at another place. plus the bathroom here sucked and smelled really bad, which is a turn off for food in my books.
author: Rachel L.

description: Good dim sum, in a large dinning area. However even with its large dinning area, it gets quit crowded. I felt squished. Gets crowded on the weekend during the lunch hours, probably not as bad on the off hours. I don't like the decor of the place and the bathrooms are small and can use more attention. Service is okay.
author: Leon C.

description: Went during the middle of the week, on a lunch date by myself ( I enjoy that at times) and while I was told the prices were great. . .I didn't think it was worth eating as I thought the Dim Sum was sub par.  I've had better. The venue is filled with cheesy decor and doesn't feel clean. Not my favorite.
author: Roseabelle M.

description:
Okay.... I have to admit in the past this restaurant was pretty filthy and falling apart.  But I recently had my wedding there, (900+ guests), probably the only Chinese restaurant in San Francisco that can hold that many people.  The manager was really nice, he agreed to fix the signage of the place and have someone dedicated to clean the restrooms during the banquet.  

The food was excellent, the traditional dishes usually served at a Chinese wedding, (Shark Fin's Soup, Lobster, etc)  actually came out hot.  This is usually unheard of at Chinese wedding and considering I had 900+guests this was even more impressive.

A little tip to New Asia.. You guys have a lot of potential if you just rennovate the place.. Get new flooring, change the decor a little.. Focus a little more on cleanliness.
author: Ethan C.

description: Excellent dim sum at 4x the price that you'll pay for something that is almost as good at one of the hole-in-the-wall places on Stockton.
author: Stu M.

description:
I went there for dim sum and was bored and disappointed. First of all, it was Friday, the place was packed, and there were only two dim sum carts going around. Throughout the whole time, they kept coming by, and there were not new selections added to any of them.

The dim sum options are not only scarce, they are not so great:
1. The platters contained minimum of 4 HUGE pieces (but frequently 6 or 8) of whatever dim sum you might be interested in. Having only 2 people at the table, that meant that we would get too full too soon to try out different versions and enjoy the variety. The fried noodles looked delicious, but I was sure that the huge size meant that we won't be able to try out anything else afterwards. 
2. The selection was poor, really, so no worries about not enjoying the variety. There were dim sums with only two types of fillings available: (A) multiple types of dim sum with pork and (B) two types of dim sum with shrimp. NOTHING else! Nothing with chicken. Nothing with beef. Nothing with fish. Green sprouts, but nothing else with veggies, even veggies inside dim sums mixed up with any meat.
3. Quality and taste was so-so. I know better dim sum places in SF, such as the Good Luck Dim Sum on Clement st., and the New Asia just does not compare in taste. The tea was not hot enough, and that's bad when you're having a fatty food. The shrimp inside the wrapper was disgustingly slimy. When I opened one of them, I discovered that it was surrounded with huge pieces of plain pork fat. It is frequently added to shrimp dim sums, but here it was done in a way to make the shrimp swim and squish in liquid pork fat. The pork dim sums were a-Okay, but I just wish they were not so huge. 

The service is so-so. While the host was trying to seat us at our table, the 1st lady with a cart arrived and scolded our host (or said to him something that sounded like rude scolding) and forced him to move out of her way from our table. Then, she moved into the space on the floor that he vacated, and started vigorously pushing her dim sums on us. I was not even seated yet, and since I was in the process of hanging my jacket and my purse, her very loud talking was really annoying and disorienting, given that I wanted to sit, take a breath after my long walk through the city, and maybe start with going to the restroom and washing my hands first. Also, whenever I asked either her or another lady about the contents, she would answer and, at the same time, push the platter onto my table and try to put a stamp into our order list, without waiting for me to tell her that I really want the platter. I even had to call a manager and tell him that I have gotten a dish that I did not ask for, though he removed it very quickly, apologized, and deleted the stamp from our list.
author: kira m.

description: My review is for the food itself. My school paid for our lunch here so I cannot assess the value or tell you if the food is worth the price, I don't know. The shrimp balls here are huge, definitely the biggest I've ever seen. The buns were average, and they did not come out very hot. The duck was pretty good, oily and slimey but that's the way I like it. The bbq pork was bad, hardly had any sauce on it and pretty tough and chewy. The fried rice and lo mein were decent, although a bit oily. The chinese brocoli (gailan) had waaay to much oyster sauce smother on it. The sesame buns were terrible, much too oily and dough-y. Overall this place is ok, but I have to assume there are better chinese restaurants out there, as this is San Francisco.
author: Byron C.

description: came here for dim sum on sunday with a group of 5.  pretty standard food/prices but i really like how they have carts (none of the places i go in SF seem to have this anymore and from growing up in HI, i've come to expect it as a staple of any dim sum experience!)  service was good even though they were busy but you do have to ask for water (and don't expect it to get refilled unless you remind them).
author: Sara H.

description: I was attending a wedding banquet at New Asia and with over 500 guests, so there was bound to be some sweat and humidity no matter how strong the A/C was. After the obligatory 2 litre bottle of 7up and apple cider was fully consumed, a friend went out to buy a can of ice cold Coke. And by far - it was the best can of Coke I've ever had in my life. Each sip was refreshing, the bubbles tingled my throat, and the sweetness lingered in my mouth. I almost forgot how hot and stuffy it was. All this talk about the Coke and not about the food - go figure.
author: Nancie T.

description: This place was a disaster.  Their dim sum was ok like the shrimp dumplings and bbq pork, but....the waitresses were rude and didnt help us out when we had a question.  The main "waitress" seemed as if she didnt want to bring us food and when we got our food is was horrible.  DO NOT get the house fried rice my party found a mystery ball of something in our food which smelled like rotten food.  On top of that they didnt bring us any water until the end of the meal.  Worst place ive ever been to.
author: Anthony S.

description: went to this restaurant on a Sunday for dim sum.. gotta say this place is really good and the dim sum carts just keep coming out with different type of dim sum..this place was pack still got seated right away and that was at 9 am!!!! if anyone goes to dim sum knows that if you show up anywhere after 830 9 10 o'clock you wont get a table for about at least an hour or longer....
author: Allan Y.

description: I've been coming to this establishment ever since I could walk.  Yes, the floors are a bit sticky, the bathrooms aren't the shiniest, and the customer service is poor... but the food is not bad.  For the price you pay, I think it's quite decent.  We paid $40 for 5 adults and a baby.  People who come to this restaurant have been coming for years - evidenced by the Chinese OGs and the elders sitting at the tables.  Nothing fancy here just people drinking tea and eatin' some dim sum.
author: Angie K.

description:
New Asia is an authentic dim sum experience. The food is good, the price is very affordable for the amount of food and service, and the atmosphere fun.  Be aware Chinese service means there are a horde of people walking around, and you have to flag someone down to be helped.  Once you do they are very fast.  There is not one server that will check in on you or anything.  Also you want to get there early in the day, because the best steamed dishes will run out during the afternoon.
The restaurant is huge and ladies in purple vests walk around with their specialty carts trying to get you to buy their items.  Some were very aggressive even plopping down dishes on our table with out us asking for it.  

The Shu mai and the shrimp dumplings are very tasty.   I prefer the traditional steamed cha xio bao but several in my party also like the baked variety with honey glaze on top.  Fresh tasty Chinese broccolli.  The shrimp and beef  He Fen (Long noodles) were bland and flavorless.  Excellent Dan Ta (Egg custard tartlett.)  Overall the food was average, they didn't have as much variety as you can get in San Gabriel (SoCal) so my favorites weren't there.  Too many deep fired variety and not enough steamed in my opinion.   

A fun experience and my first timer friends really enjoyed it.  we went with a group of 8 and got away with $12 per person and we were all stuffed
author: Maya C.

description: I'm not really a fan of Dim summing in SF because the food is always overpriced and the service sucks. Now with that said, This is THE dim sum spot for me and my friends IF and ONLY IF we are in the city. They've got a large space and you will almost always be able to get seated within 20 minutes. The dim sum cart pushers are could be called "dumb-sum cart pushers" because i remembered when my friends wanted to get some soda to drink and asked for a few cans of Sprite (yeah yeah .. represent!) and the lady kept saying "SEEE-pit" almost to the point that it sounded like Spit, but we just nodded, and she returns 5 minutes later with 7-Ups, how much easier would it be to just say seven up?
author: Kalvin C.

description: Not the New Asia Gardens of my childhood.   The food was okay, just not stellar as it used to be.  And they kept sending the same two women around with the same carts in our section.  I guess each section had their two women.  Stewed chicken feet never came out nor the sticky rice.  The Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce was as good as ever, but the su mis left much to be desired.  I couldn't taste the shrimp in the shrimp dumplings.  It seems more greasy.  And the atmosphere, though the place was packed, just seemed less festive than my memory.  It was fine, but not worth the trek to the belly of the beast of downtown traffic.  It also seemed more expensive than I remembered.
author: Eric K.

description: Yikes! We went with a 10-person group for a non-Dim Sum dinner. We were nearly the only people in the entire place. Rumor has it there was a shooting in the large dining hall a few years back. Maybe we should've taken that as a sign? Our variety of tofu, fish and chicken dishes were all-together bland. After only a few bites, I wanted to bail. I'm no Chinese food expert, but I hope there are better options in the area. The Dim Sum might be good, but I'm not willing to go back.
author: Dave K.

description: Not to be confused with Asia SF.  This spot is in Chinatown.  I had really good dim sum here once on a Saturday.  Then I went back for a banquet upstairs.  Predictably, the banquet food was poor.  The bathroom was horrifyingly dirty that day.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Horid! Food was not good and variety was little. They don't have red bean steamed buns! I wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Isaac T.

description: As far as the dim sum went, it is not great but generally very good. But what makes the difference is the pricing and the huge dining hall enabling a quick dim sum breakfast without having to wait long to get a table. We were able to feed two adults and three hungry kids, get in and out in 40 minutes or less, and all for about $30. A great deal.
author: Jeff L.

description: This was average dim sum place, I thought price was pretty cheap since I am big eater and I got full under 20 dollar.  Service is classic Chinese style, carts going around with servers constantly offering you food.  Apparently someone in the previous review was offended or bothered by it lol.  They can shove plates of food at me any day, I was happy to be see food everywhere!  Food was pretty good, but seriously people you don't go to Chinese restaurant for the service, you go for the food lol.
author: Seung O.

description: I just came back from New Asia for breakfast around 10:30.  I was seated at the table closest to the front doors, but furthest away from the kitchen. I do not advise for anyone to come on weekdays! There are not as much food going around, when food actually was going around it was mostly rice or buns. Come on the weekends instead when the place is bustling.
author: Jen P.

description: We came to this restaurant expecting great dim sum but were disappointed. The carts were few.  The whole restaurant had about 2-3 carts circulating leading to long wait before one may pick one's dishes.  The sizes of the dim sum were large but tasting just OK.  I recommend you wipe your own tea cups and chopsticks; they were just dirty and greasy.
author: addoo d.

description: Took out of town guest here; good environment to socialize in (busy but not too noisy) and dim sum was hot when served.  A bit difficult catching a waiter/waitress to order noodles, drinks, spicy mustard, etc; upon requesting the requests were immediately executed- yay!
author: jamie j.

description:
pretty good and pretty cheap.

paid ~12$ and left full

definitely get the white radish cake

sf parking is not so fun.
author: A M.

description: the place itself is pretty big and even has upstairs seating so it can accommodate a lot of people. the food here itself in general is average as nothing really distinguished itself and usually has a lot of oil as it tastes greasy. i would come again if i was desperate or if i was bring a large party of people.
author: Robert Y.

description: This place really depends on when you go. I went New Year's day, and the selection was awesome, the quality was so-so, and hte ambiance sucked. My family rejected it, and we now go to CityView, which is a compromise basically between Hong Kong style dim sum restaurants and Yank Sing, which is in authentic but great in its own way. New Asia was a destination for me at lunch wtih another firend that worked on Russian Hill. You will share your table if you are a small party, and you have to order right. It's a bit steeper than the cafe's, but far cheaper than the places catering to Caucasians.
author: Anna B.

description: I just took my aunt here for some dim sum with my family. She lives across the street, and it was perfect for her. Food was actually better than I remembered it, service was less rude, but the bathrooms still just as bad.  If you step in them I hope you're wearing boots. 1. Bring cash. 2. Have some of the chicken feet. 3. Don't expect too much.
author: kimberly l.

description: Oh man this place is dirty!  The floors are dirty, the bathrooms are dirty, the entrance way is dirty oh my god I don't even want to think about the food.  My parents used to take us here all the time as kids for dim sum and as kids, we didn't know any better.  Now that I have a better concept of what food cleanliness entails and what a health code is, it is safe to say that I will never return here on my own free will.  Don't get me wrong, the food is decent but my god it's so dirty.
author: Anna H.

description:
New Asia has been around forever (when it used to be Asia Garden) so it was a sentimental journey visiting the restaurant with some out-of-town visitors.
You need to get there before 11AM (after the morning breakfast crowd and before the lunch rush) to get a table as it is packed.
Make sure you also bring your Cantonese-speaking Auntie to ensure you don't get pushed around. It's tightly packed with patrons, and the servers are the standard "let's really push the dishes that have been on the cart all morning so I can get some new inventory before Noon"
I enjoyed the shrimp har-gow dumpling-full of shrimp (but Auntie complained that all it had was shrimp, but no other filler that she liked the minced bamboo shoots, water chestnut and other binders. Sheesh - can't win for trying as she used to previously complain about the lack of shrimp in the past...
The egg custard tart and baked cha-siu (pork bun) were winners, and the "dry-fried" beef and chow-fun noodles were tasty and not greasy.
The bathrooms and the route to them are fraught with peril:slippery, greasy and extremely hazardous to your olfactory and sense of cleanliness.
Not the most relaxing dining experience, but the dim sum fare was good and your typical Chinese brunch experience.
author: Gary L.

description: Not bad, not great. I'm still looking for my favorite dim-sum joint that doesn't cost a Yank-Sing fortune.
author: Rob T.

description:
Oh dear, where should I start...

I came here with a co-worker for lunch.  We were scoping out restaurants to bring clients to and I'm so glad we did.  Most of the food was COLD.  Like, cold chicken with oyster sauce slathered all over it and the bones in.  The dumplings were okay, but the waitresses tended to ask us if we wanted something, then decide we didn't know what we really wanted and switched the plates on us.  I'm sure you could get better service if you spoke Chinese, but we did not have that luxury.  The room was noisy, we didn't finish our meal but left feeling greasy, and the service left a lot to be desired.  Enough said.
author: Sarah H.

description: ehhh. honestly, their dim sum is subpar at best. selection is weak. only good thing is that we dont have to wait too long for a table. (i wonder why???) ..... price is cheap but service is horrible. i still have no idea why my grandparents still go back their for our occasional dim sum meal.
author: Frankie L.

description: horrible service and average food....the host had to ask us where the tip was as we were leaving. We were shocked......i wanted to slap him
author: Kevin L.

description: The dim sum is terrific, prices are higher than most.  If you go at 11am (opening time) expect slow service and limited choices on what you can order. The seven of us stayed from 11 to 1230pm and our bill was only $52.  The reason for that was only a few of the dim sum carts came our way and the ones that made it were half empty or out of what we wanted.  Good luck getting a waiter, some of the patrons had to go get their own forks or extra napkins.  No parking near restaurant.
author: j a.

description: I took my 65 year old mom on her first trip to San Francisco. She loved the dim sum here. She's traditional Cantonese and she said this was the best dim sum she ever had, much better than the ones in Monterey Park. We were there on a busy Saturday morning at 11 am. We waited about 20 min but it was worth the wait. The dim sum didn't have much msg. The restrooms were cleaned. The restaurant was clean. The portion was really huge, 4 jumbo har gow in a crate. The Shanghai dumplings had 6 in a crate. We had a total of 10 different crates and were really full. The bill for 4 people came to $40. Super cheap restaurant for great quality food. The food came really hot except the taro cake. The taro cake came out cold but it was still really good tasting.
author: lynn s.

description: First, I must mention that sitting on the first floor is often frigid, dirty, and crowded. For a much more pleasant eating experience, you must go upstairs. Second, in order to get a table without having to wait for an eternity you have to either go a bit before 11 or a little after 1. The time in between is  packed and you're lucky if your chair doesn't get rammed into by one of the dim sum carts. Having said that, I have quickly figured out that this place excels with non-traditional items. Eggrolls, eh, ok. Siu mai, alright, but a little meaty. The BBQ pork buns are good though, even the baked ones, which I am less of a fan of. If you want delicious, though, try their take on the taro. Typically filled with some sort of meat sauce and then fried, New Asia's version puts it in a bun. Or the fried shrimp with chilies and five spice. Salty with a little bit of bite. Yum. They also have a large variety of dumplings and chicken feet (although, I stay away from that, but have heard that they are good). Their desserts are quite delicate and not too sweet. So, if you're willing to endure a not-so-pleasant setting and stray from the norm, this may be the place for you.
author: Veronica W.

description: out of all the dim sum places i've been to for yum cha.... this place has the best egg tarts! they are big in size and the eggs.... mmmmm they taste good and just right!... the siu mai's here are alright.... the sticky rice here is superb!!!!..... one of the bestplaces you'll find in chinatown!
author: Lily X.

description:
we come here regularly for weekend dim sum because the prices are reasonable, food quality alone is 3.5 stars but consistent and they rarely run out of crucial stuff, and good stuff comes around til as late as 2 oclock.

plus this place always has dao-fu-fa, ginger tofu pudding. it's always so depressing when you can't get it, and i don't have to worry about that here.

ok it would be four stars because the bathroom is gross (the only place i ever had to take a dump in a stall with no door) but it pisses me off that so many people who have no clue about dim sum give bad stars to new asia.

ok just a few corrections to some other unfair 1-star reviews i saw--- BLOOD IN THE CHICKEN NEAR THE BONE: yeah but was the meat tender? many people think this is a neutral or positive condition for chicken. and no these people do not get sick from it. CASHIER LADY SAYING "MORE TIP:" uh that never happened to us. a 10% tip for dim sum is good, since it's not full service. but all you have to do is hold up your ticket and the higher-ranked floor staff will come over and total it for you, so i don't know why you were at the cashier in the first place. ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCORE IS NOW 75, WITH ALL VIOLATIONS SUCCESSFULLY ABATED: so they have cleaned up. and why would somebody have a great and enjoyable meal, not get sick, go home and look up the score, and then give the restaurant one star based on the score you saw online rather than your outstanding experience at the restaurant. i don't know anyone who's gotten sick here, and i've fallen ill from canton restaurant in soma which has a higher score of 79/82.
author: mikewong x.

description:
my wife & i are long time patrons of the new asia for dim sum.  the place has not changed for several years & has been pretty much a chinatown standard as dim sum places go.  the place is always crowded & packed on the weekend.  the decor is pretty standard for chinatown.  the selection & slow dim sum cart service from the dim sum ladies is pretty hit or miss but the thing about dim sum is that you are not here to eat quickly, but to relax & enjoy your company you are with.  the food selection is fairly large & pretty tasty.  do not be shy about getting a dim sum ladies attention if she is in the near by area on a dish she has or you are wanting, otherwise it may not be there when she finally makes her route to your table.  there are periodic specials that come out fresh out of the kitchen in limited quantities.  you can also make special request from the waitresses or order off the menu.  recommend the shanghai dumplings when they are fresh out of the kitchen as they are delicious.  

overall, the restaurant is a good place to go for dim sum.  the service is decent for chinatown.  the dim sum ladies are funny & fairly friendly.  best to go before 11 am on a weekend otherwise the lines can be quite long.  we have tried this place on a weekday & the selection is not so great so avoid.  avoid the bathroom unless it is absolutely necessary as it is pretty dirty a majority of the time.  street parking is mediocre at best, there are plenty of private pay parking lots in the area.
author: larry s.

description: best dim sum in chinatown, this is my spot when i don't feel like driving down to daly city for dim sum... the shrimp dumplings are really good...
author: Andrew N.

description: It was Sunday morning, and we were up early, so what should we do? eat dim sum! this is a very large restaurant, and it reminded me of the dim sum places in boston. We got there probably around ten, and it was already full, but they were able to seat us right away upstairs. Upstairs started out mostly empty, but by the time we left, it was full, and there was a line out the door to get in the whole restaurant. So if you don't come early, be prepared to wait.  For some reason we missed most of the dumpling dishes on this visit, but everything we did have was very yummy.  The staff was pretty helpful (even though it did take forever to get water).  The food came by frequently and seemed fresh.  We also ordered some fried rice off of the menu. Usually I hate fried rice, so I didn't believe b when he told me it was good,  but this was egg white fried rice, so it was all moist and clumpy and healthy tasting, very scalliony.  There were leftovers for dinner that night, and by Monday, j and I were already craving more.  So we'll definitely be back again.  including tip, it was about $50 for three of us, so very well priced.
author: Merredith L.

description: Eek. The only upside: it's a huge place. The downside: the food, which is what I assume people are going for.
author: Judy L.

description: My wife is from the Bay Area, so we always get some Chinatown action, when we are visiting.  One of the places we stop at eveytime, is New Asia.  It's not the prettiest or fanciest place, not the most expensive either.  Infact, it's kind of your average looking chinese place, minus the large size of it.  We like to go where the locals go, and we are usually the only "fair skinned" people in here when we go.  The first time I went, the service was ok, just fast paced.  The second summer we went, I taught myself mandarin just for our visit to chinatown.  The service was much better when I started spouting out mandarin.  Not sure if it was just by chance or what.  Anyway, the food is great, especially if you have an open mind and want to try new things.  My favs are the pork buns, shark fin shumai, shrimp balls, shrimp dumplings, and various others.  I'll definitely be back in April.  Can't wait!
author: Josh A.

description: My girl friend and I found this gem through the housekeeper at our hotel. We have tried many different dim sum places in New York City, and this place is one of top choices. Delicious food, HUGE portion, ( I have never seem a Giant shrimp dumplings before!!!), and reasonable price. (My friend thought it's pricer than the places NYC Chinatown, but for me it's reasonable for its size.) The room was filled with local Asians....we were glad that we made a right decision...not following the tourists!!!
author: Iris C.

description: the good ol dim sum stand by in chinatown.   not pretentious like yank sing where OMG the bathrooms are clean,  so i don't mind paying an arm and a leg for the same quality of dim sum as any other place.  these must be the same people who order grey goose and cranberry at a bar!?! :forehead slap:
author: Pickle R.

description: From the outside, this restaurant looked busy; so we thought it would be a good place for dim sum.   We were sorely disappointed.  The flavors were average for the five dishes we got, but we were even more shocked at the $20 bill.  Everything was a medium although in SoCal, most would have been a small dish worth $1.80.  Also, there must have been a different type of math applied to tourists.  They ran out of custard pie (dan ta?) by 1:30.  The only thing that saved the day was the sundae at Ghirardelli's Square.
author: J S.

description: WORST SERVICE EVER. ESPECIALLY IF YOU LOOK ASIAN BUT DON'T SPEAK CHINESE BECAUSE YOUR NOT CHINESE!!!!! I came in here with my cousin, her friend and my bestfriend who speaks mandarin, not cantonese and for us girls, we all speak vietnamese. Sorry just because we look chinese doesn't mean we can speak it. When we walked in and sat down, everyone came around us and offered us something to eat. That's probably about 3 waitresses? After there, we sat there for an hour trying to get at least ONE waitress to come to our table with some dim sum. Worst service ever. When I asked to speak to the manager after 10 minutes trying to explain to her what I was asking for, she said the manager was away and not here. AND she tried to charge 4 bucks for something nonsense. The bill only showed us the dishes we did have, the two cokes ordered, tax and four bucks out of no where. Honey, you can forget it! We didn't pay the four bucks for whatever the fuck it was. FOUR BUCKS FOR WATER?!?! psh. water is free bitch. Never coming back here again I hope it closes down!
author: Miss D.

description: if you want "ambience", go to any of the countless 'tourist' chinese places near north beach. if you want a steady stream of authentic dim sum that will utterly satisfy your dim sum cravings, new asia is the place to go.
author: Paul T.

description: i think new asia, gold mountain, and great eastern are the top 3 dim sum restaurants in chinatown. new asia is probably the biggest and most popular one. i think the variety is good and the food here is pretty tasty, especially the shanghai steamed dumplings (siu lung bao) and portugal egg custard (po tot). but the service is horrible. the waiters and managers are decent that's if you can get a hold of them. the dim sum cart ladies, on the other hand, are the just downright rude. a lot of times they just whiz by without calling out the items in their carts and they're annoyed when you ask them. then there are those who would park their carts to the side to chat with people they know. but i endure the bad service because ultimately i value this place. it's sad but there just aren't many choices for quality sit-down dim sum in san francisco chinatown anymore, so better cherish it while it's still here.
author: Doris Y.

description: Okay I'm giving it 3 stars cause I had such great memories of this place when I was a kid during the 80's.  We used to go every Sunday for dim sum kinda like how people have the Sunday brunch ritual.  So I just want to get it out there that the quality of food and service kinda went downhill after the original owners sold it.  This place used to be run and owned by Bob Yick (best restaurant designer in SF in my opinion).  After he passed away his family kept it going for a while.  Bob was a stickler for quality so it was always the best.  If you got a chance to go during the 80's you would know that Koi Palace couldn't even hold a candle to this place.  I mean he actually brought over two great chefs from HK and then found out their personalities didn't mesh.  So what did he do, he opened up Hong Kong Villa up the street for one of them to run the kitchen.  So I remember the wait used to be crazy insane long for these two restaurants but since my family were regulars we usually got a table right away (karma is a pain... always have to wait for my tables now.).  Must admit that it is pretty painful to see such a wonderful restaurant go downhill.
author: Alice K.
